The second is the regulated price fixation system of the current airlines monopoly which means that there is no competition in the industry and that the costs are simply passed on to the consumer. In that sort of circumstance the result that we are faced with here today is inevitable.

The accord has resulted in a massive exodus of skilled workers from the system. It has created shortages. For example, Qantas is no longer able to carry out the maintenance of its aircraft because the skilled workers have left the system. That is a direct result of the accord. Both graduates and skilled tradesmen have departed from traditional employment. They have got out of the system; they have run away from the accord. I see that Senator Collins is looking at me. I say to him that when I was inspecting a factory recently I came across a very skilled young man who was repairing computers. I praised him and made some comments about the skills that he must have. He said to me, `Senator, can you tell me why my mate who is a brickie's labourer is getting more money than I am?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has got a stronger union.

—It is all because of the accord and the fact that that person is in a stronger union. People have been locked in by the accord. As a result, people with skills, such as the young fellow I mentioned, are becoming brickie's labourers. That is what is happening in this country. The accord is deskilling this country.
—They're not, actually.

—There is not the slightest doubt that people are seeking all sorts of ways to avoid the accord. They are setting up their own consultancies and providing the same sort of service outside the system. The pilots dispute is simply one example of a group of people breaking out from the centralised wage system, a system which grants across the board increases irrespective of the needs of the employers and employees at the workface. Today Senator Button was critical of our policy. I say that such break-outs as this wage break-out can occur only in the Government's rigid centralised system. They would not happen under a coalition policy. They would not happen under a coalition policy. They just simply would not happen.

SPEECH.PARA: If our policies had been in place, if we had been elected in 1987, the pilots of Australia would not be in this position: they would either have remained in the industrial relations system with the effective enforcement provisions as outlined in the Bill which Senator Chaney introduced last week, and of which I gave notice this morning; or they would have negotiated a private agreement either on an individual basis, through a union or on some workplace basis which is binding on both parties and which would be enforceable by both parties. There would have been no wage break-out because we would not be worried, as is the Government because of the accord, of the flow-on.

That is what is worrying the Prime Minister. He recognises that under this stupid system the Government has established, if the pilots get a wage break-out it will flow right through the system. It will cause enormous economic havoc if the pilots get their wage increase under the Government's centralised system. It would not apply under our system. The Prime Minister's intervention and over-reaction has been thoroughly inept and he has simply inflamed the dispute to such a stage that, I might say, I believe his intervention has now become a major stumbling block to the negotiations.

I might add that it is quite clear also that the Prime Minister and this Government are operating under a set of double standards because there was no action by this Government when the waterside workers closed down the port of Melbourne for nearly a week. There was no action at all; we did not hear the Prime Minister jumping up and down and being Rambo about the waterside workers down in Port Melbourne. Nor did we hear the Government doing anything about it when the meat workers union imposed rolling bans and stoppages in pursuit of pay claims outside the wage principles. Of course they are outside the wage principles. If they do not get it one way they will have to get it another way. The pilots are demonstrating just one way of getting what they want outside the wage principles. When the Government opposed Senator Chaney's Bill recently what did Senator Aulich say in here? He is trying to justify himself today-incorrectly. I happen to have his speech, and it is quite clear that Senator Aulich was not at that stage in the debate last week saying what he said today. I will quote what Senator Aulich said last week:
In some ways I am not even pushing aside the viewpoint that has been expressed by members of the New Right. They had their viewpoints on particular disputes and taught us that in the end-
and listen to these words-

the worst possible thing to do to improve industrial relations in this country is to get people into the courts and the common law system. That is the worst possible way for people to go if, first, we are going to solve industrial disputes on the whole or, second, we are going to create a climate of industrial relations harmony that helps us as a country to maintain a reasonable reputation.

That is what Senator Aulich said during the debate here the week before last and yet the Prime Minister says, `That is exactly the way I am going to go'. Of course this hypocritical Prime Minister is in fact adopting our policies but he is trying to impose them upon a centralised wage system and they will not work in a centralised wage system.

This Government should immediately move to free up the industrial relations system. Senator Button said it in the course of an answer today when he said, `Of course there should be a more flexible system. There should not be wage rigidities. There should be a flexible wage system. There should be flexibilities in the industrial relations system'. Of course he knows the position. That is why I interjected, `Yes and in due course your Government will adopt-if you're here long enough-our flexible wage system. You will find some way of endeavouring to free up this system because it is too rigid and it is in effect deskilling this nation'. As far as the Prime Minister is concerned, he should swallow his pride and withdraw from this dispute.

Let us look at what is happening as a result of this dispute. Let us look at the tourism and hotel industries and see what is happening in those industries. The tourist industry is estimating known losses of $20m per day and a total cost estimated so far at about $600m already. We can see from the attitude of the pilots that this dispute will go on for a very long period of time. The Gold Coast is now in the peak of its tourist season. One-third of the tourists to the Gold Coast are air travellers. There have been 7,000 cancellations of conventions or groups recorded so far. Last Friday 2,200 delegates were lost from the Gold Coast.

The average loss of business on the Gold Coast currently is $2.5m per day in the 5-star hotel occupancy where the rates are estimated to be as low as 13 per cent in the peak of their season. We know that in the capital cities-Brisbane, Sydney, Melbourne -the figures are down for the hotel bookings. We know that the restaurants are suffering losses in Cairns; we have had reports of immediate cancellations of groups and conventions costing $2m and more coming in daily and costs of this order are being repeated in every State, with flow-ons to restaurants and the food industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is responsible?

—Who is responsible? Mr Hawke inflamed this dispute because let us remember the domestic pilots, while we do not approve of what they are doing, were actually providing a service of sorts, at least from 9 o'clock to 5 o'clock, when suddenly the Prime Minister opened his mouth and that is the finish of it.
—What about Tasmania?
—I agree with Senator Walters from Tasmania: tourism stopped in Tasmania. Hotel bookings have been cancelled and air freight has been stopped.
—It is catastrophic in the Northern Territory.
—And did the honourable senator say to come and look at the Northern Territory?
—It is catastrophic.

—Senator Collins is saying it is catastrophic in the Northern Territory. The damage to the economy is immeasurable because it will go on. The damage to the economy will go on for a long period. Of course there is a possibility that the bottom might fall out of the Australian dollar under this Government if it stays here much longer and then, of course, overseas tourism might come good again. If that is Senator Button's policy, believe me, Mr Acting Deputy President, we do not approve of that policy. But that looks to be the only chance for tourism under him because it will be years-three to five years; and I see Senator Collins agrees-before the tourism industry recovers from this disastrous strike. It is front page news in Japanese newspapers and I understand that some 25 Japanese tour operators have cancelled tours in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: There is another matter of grave concern, and that is the political pressure which we believe was imposed on the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) to grant immediate operational approval for a DC8-62 aircraft owned by Arrow Air Inc. to operate on a charter basis for freight flights in Australia. Australia's aviation safety record is at risk in relation to this matter. Normally it takes three months for CAA to grant operational approval for an aircraft. It has done this in a couple of days and we understand that is because it has been leaned on by someone in the Government. Arrow Air Inc., which is providing this aircraft, does not have an operational manual for Australia and it does not have an enviable safety record. I alert Senator Button and others in the chamber to that problem.

The Government has repeatedly said that the accord is the cornerstone of its economic policies. Well, the accord has failed; the Government's economic policies have failed. Look at the Moody's report today. We have net foreign debt of $108 billion. We have a current account deficit estimated to be over $20 billion this year. The Budget is predicting inflation at 7 1/2 per cent. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) is telling us that the high interest rates will go on for another two or three years. There is Moody's attack on not only the Government's credit rating, but also on all of these institutions in Australia today. Let there be not the slightest doubt that this Government's economic policies have failed. The accord has failed. The Government has failed and it is time it went.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always enlightening to hear Senator Lewis's rhetoric on some of these matters. I might just take him up on a couple of points and then deal with the issues relating to the air pilots strike, as he describes it. I suppose it is the Opposition's function to try to get a bit of mileage out of anything that goes, including a dispute in respect of which there might have been some hope for bipartisan approaches, instead of which the Opposition has engaged in grandstanding and pointless diversion.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Stone interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to be interrupted by Senator Stone interjecting with his catalogue of demonology which clouds his judgment in all these matters. The fact is that if ever there was a grandstanding effort it was the approach advanced by Senator Lewis a minute or two ago. I suppose what the Opposition has to try to establish-and Senator Lewis kept repeating it, but I did not hear a great ring of confidence in his voice-is that under its industrial relations policy this sort of thing would not happen. That is an article of faith with Senator Lewis. It is not an article based on any particular rational argument. He has got to try to establish that. Of course, his speech was directed towards solving the problems of many years of industrial relations in Australia. As he has done in previous speeches, he comes back to this chatty little conversation he had with a young man working on computers in a factory he once visited. We have all heard that story before. That young man asked him, `Why is my mate who is a bricklayer getting more than I am?'. There might be very obvious answers to that question, including the very high demand in the building industry. There are very obvious answers to that question. I hope Senator Lewis has heard of supply and demand in the labour market. That might be one of the answers.
—I am sure he will be delighted to hear that as your answer.

—If Senator Lewis knew anything about it and went back to the 1960s in this country and asked taxi drivers what they did before they took up taxi driving, they would tell him that they were skilled metal tradesmen.
—You could ask senators what they did before they became senators. They took up taxi driving.
—Taxi driving might have been a good course for Senator Lewis to take up instead of being here wasting 20 minutes of the time of the Senate with the speech we have just had.
—A damn good speech.

—I would be careful if I were you, Senator Boswell. We have been talking about aircraft today. There might be hangars involved, if Senator Boswell interjects too much! Of course, I share Senator Lewis's concern about the damage that this dispute is doing to various industries. I have seen some of it. I share his concern about all of that.
—Why don't you get the Prime Minister out of it then-and take yourself out of it too?

—We get such divergent advice from the Opposition on this issue that it is very hard. I am going to deal with that in a minute, if Senator Stone can wait. It is very hard to reach a conclusion about just what the Opposition thinks the Government should do.
—Get out of the way.

—Let us deal with it now. Senator Stone said that the Government should get out of the way in this dispute, a view firmly supported by his H. R. Nicholls Society mate, Mr Des Moore, who said that putting extra powers into the hands of the Industrial Relations Commission-which is what the Opposition is going to support here this week-is not the answer. He suggested that the Opposition should support the right of pilots to negotiate directly with their employers. That is what Senator Stone's friend from the H. R. Nicholls Society said. On the other hand, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Chaney, had this to say on 22 August:

SPEECH.PARA: The pilots and the employers could, I believe, work out a better arrangement than they've got at present. That's up to them.

But by today Senator Chaney, in his letter to the Australian Financial Review which Senator Lewis has tabled here today, was saying that effective arbitration is the only available option left if sensible direct discussions on what could be done to improve productivity collapses. The Opposition's spokesman on industrial relations has changed his view in one week. On the other hand, Mr Peacock, the Opposition Leader in the other place, has said:
It's a classic case where you've got to go beyond the employer-employee fight and look after the national interest. And the Government is correct.

There are three spokesmen, chosen at random, contributors to the Opposition's industrial relations policy, all with different views, one of them with two different views in the space of one week. Senator Lewis then comes in here today and gives us the outstanding revelation that in 1974 Bob Hawke, who was then leader of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), had a different position from that which he has 15 years later in totally different circumstances. Well done, Senator Lewis! He has identified the sins of Bob Hawke in 1974.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about solving the problem instead of scoring cheap points?
—They are not cheap points at all.
—The country is bleeding to death under your leadership.

—And the Opposition-this intellectually hydra-headed monster-has proposed this matter of public importance through the mouth of Senator Lewis. If Senator Chaney had been here, he might have changed his mind during the course of his own speech. He did that during the course of last week. He differs from Mr Peacock and Mr Moore. So who is the Opposition to propose matters of public importance, if it is really concerned about the public interest?
—Don't you think it is a matter of public importance?

—Of course I do. What I said is who are those opposite to move it, for goodness sake. The Opposition has to establish that it is going to have a better industrial relations policy which will resolve some of these problems. Senator Lewis kept on asserting it, and he cannot in any sense establish it. What he came back to saying again and again was that the accord had failed compared with previous years and compared with the future under some halcyon Liberal regime and that one will see how much it has failed. The accord is there because in 1982 a Liberal government responded to exactly the same sorts of economic pressures that this Government is under by granting 16 per cent wage claims.
—No, that was done by the Arbitration Commission.

—In 1981, Senator Stone, it was 14 per cent. That was because the Prime Minister of the day thought it more important to go to a royal wedding than to deal with a big wages claim on his Government's plate. The results of those enormous wage claims, conceded by that Government in 1982, were the highest unemployment we have had since the great depression and an economic downturn which has taken us years to recover from. All those things happened because of incompetence.
—Induced by the ACTU, by your mates.

—I referred to Senator Stone's demonology before. It is no good an intelligent man like Senator Stone repeating these rabid slogans-ACTU! ACTU!-as if it was `two legs good, four legs bad'. It is Orwellian stuff. It is not a very intellectual or intelligent response from a man like Senator Stone to a serious argument.
—It just happens to be true.

—Senator Stone knows better than this. As somebody once said, it is not the despair that worries me, it is the hope that hurts. One always hopes that Senator Stone will justify his substantial reputation as a thinker about these matters and not resort to those mindbending slogans-ACTU! ACTU! If the Senator Stone is going to be associated with the proposing of matters of public importance in the Senate which attack the Government for its wages policy, he cannot in relation to 1982 say it was not the Government's fault but the fault of the then Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, of the ACTU, or of somebody else. Senator Stone cannot have it both ways. He cannot be third speaker on this issue and have it both ways. It was the Government's fault in 1982 if it is the Government's fault now, as he says. He cannot have it both ways.

SPEECH.PARA: On the question of the accord failing, I make the point that real unit labour costs in this country have seen substantial reductions under the life of this Government as distinct from what happened in 1981 and 1982. There has been a generally improved performance in industrial relations and, in terms of flexibility in the wages system, which I referred to in my speech on this issue 10 days ago in the Senate, companies which have taken advantage of the agreement route provided in industrial relations legislation and reached agreements with their employees and had them ratified by the arbitration Commission are enjoying the flexibility which is inherent in the present system as a step forward towards greater flexibility. It is no good talking about that issue, of course, in relation to the airline pilots, because they decided very early on to take themselves outside the system.

The reason why the pilots dispute undermines the credibility of the Opposition on this issue is that the pilots have rejected one crucial part of what I regard as the legitimate preferred approach of the Opposition; that is, the pilots do not wish to have their current 30 per cent wage claim linked to productivity increases. They will not talk about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let them talk to their lawyers about that. Why are you deciding it for them?

—I am not deciding anything for them; I am telling Senator Stone what the facts are. The pilots will not agree to discuss productivity increases in their current 30 per cent wage claim, preferring instead to get the increase purely on the basis of industrial muscle and their bargaining position. Now that is the difference.
—How do you know that? You haven't had any conversations with them.

—It is a public position. The Opposition's policy is designed to create the conditions for voluntary industry based agreements between employees and employers on wages and conditions, linked to productivity. What happens to this sort of policy when some organisation attempts to implement it? The Opposition says now, `Oh, the Industrial Relations Commission should come in and sort this out'. That is implicit in Senator Chaney's Bill.
—No.
—Yes, it is.
—No, it's not. Under the other system--

—Senator Lewis has had his go-come on. The fact of the matter is that in this dispute the parties have decided to opt out of the system. The Commission cannot deal with the dispute and cannot make the directions now desired by the Opposition under the Bill which was introduced 10 days ago and about which Andrew Peacock goes around saying, `If the Government had passed that Bill it would have been all right'. That is a lot of bunkum, not surprisingly from Andrew Peacock. It is absolute rubbish that it would have been all right if we had passed that bit of legislation in the Senate. The pilots have resigned; their award has been cancelled. There can be no dispute to be settled if pilots are no longer employees.

SPEECH.PARA: What should flow from the Opposition's industrial relations policy is support for the processes followed in the pilots dispute to date. The companies acted swiftly when the dispute begun by the pilots pulled them out of the wages system. They went over the head of the union to deal directly with their own employees-a desired element, Senator Chaney has told us in many debates in this place. They went over the head of the union and dealt directly with their own employees. When this approach failed, they then resorted to court action against individual pilots. This is a model case under the Opposition's proposed industrial relations system. Instead of supporting what the airlines have done in this case, the Opposition now wants to bring the dispute back into the wages system. I am very surprised that, with the level of confusion shown by the Opposition, it wanted to debate this question here today. That is, after all, collective bargaining in action.

I have referred already to the considerable confusion shown by various Opposition spokesmen in relation to this dispute. Senator Chaney said, `The pilots and the employers could . . . have worked out a better arrangement than they've got at present. That's up to them'. Later he changed that to say, `We want a system where they are subject to the Industrial Relations Commission and the sanctions of that Commission'. Another friend of Senator Stone, Mr McLachlan, said 10 days ago, `There should be no constraint, other than common law constraints, on these contracts'. In that case he was talking about contracts between stevedoring companies, watersiders and so on.

The pilots dispute is a very serious dispute. It is regrettable that the Opposition has seen it as an issue for grandstanding. As I have said in the course of debates here with Senator Lewis on a number of occasions, no government in the current economic circumstances in Australia can ignore the consequences of aggregate wage outcomes. No government can be unconcerned about claims for 30 per cent salary increases which are couched in such terms as, `We want it now and we will not discuss productivity issues in order to get it'. Quite simply, that is the way it is put by the pilots. While that frame of mind remains with one party to the industrial relations system as regards the airlines, while I hope that those clear positions can be reconciled between the airlines and the pilots on some of the issues in question, particularly the productivity one, unless they are so reconciled there is not much hope of a quick and satisfactory settlement of this dispute.

Senator Stone told me by way of interjection that the Government should keep out of this issue. We cannot keep out of it in the Senate when we have before us a matter of public importance which is designed to tell us what to do, but I think there is something to be said for that advice. Senator Lewis came in here today and made a speech as Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, saying that the Government should call the parties together, should do all of these things.

TALK.START.PARA: —He just asked you whether you were doing anything at all constructive. We know all the destructive things you are doing.

—That is what he said. Senator Stone can get up and make a speech about Bob Hawke when he was President of the ACTU and Bob Hawke saying silly things and put all the views that he might want to put forward.
—You wouldn't deny it, would you, really?
—Order! Senator Stone, you will have a quarter of an hour in which to speak shortly.

—Senator Stone will get a quarter of an hour and will be able to do all those things in that time. I do not think it is much good, in trying to work to a constructive solution to this problem, setting up whipping boys on either side and going on with that sort of process. What is of utmost concern is that as soon as possible the airlines and the individual pilots whom they employ work out a satisfactory solution to this problem in order that the very real damage which is being done across the country to various industries and to individuals in their business and domestic lives be fixed up as quickly as possible. To that extent the Government supports the last bit of Senator Lewis's comments about the importance of trying to obtain a resolution to this dispute, but certainly not in the words in which this matter of public importance is couched, which are nothing but grandstanding and do nothing towards a sensible solution to this issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -We are debating today a matter of public importance brought into the Senate by Senator Lewis in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Hawke Government's industrial relations policy which has led to the massive disruption caused by the airline pilots dispute.

I certainly agree with one part of that and that is that massive destruction has been caused by the airline pilots dispute. It is undeniable that it has been one of the most destructive of strikes that we have seen in this country for a very long time and that the effects of this industrial action will not only be felt immediately by hundreds if not thousands of businesses around Australia, but will indeed be felt for many years to come in terms of the bankruptcy of many of those businesses and the destroyed life chances of hundreds, if not thousands, of Australians. However, I cannot agree with the notion that an industrial relations policy can actually lead to a strike. Considering the antecedents of this strike, I am old-fashioned enough to believe that it ought to be seen in terms of what normally occurs in strikes-that is, people endeavouring to increase their pay or improve their conditions of work.

One can point to three major items with respect to the airline pilots dispute. First, there is the worldwide shortage of experienced airline pilots and, therefore, Australian pilots see comparative wage differences between themselves and their overseas counterparts. Secondly, the pilots undoubtedly have industrial clout in a capital-intensive industry. At the moment, the airlines are losing millions of dollars a day while the cost of paying that extra 30 per cent would have amounted to about $100,000 a day. That disparity fairly obviously gives the pilots an enormous amount of clout. Thirdly, the pilots have pointed to the comparative wage justice given to Australian executives who are outside the accord and who have achieved average wage increases of 50 per cent. They have compared those people with others who have been subject to the accord. The airline pilots argue that they wish to compare themselves with Australian executives. One might argue alternatively that executives ought to be subjected to the accord rather than being outside it. Be that as it may, they are the three major points which could be said, after a dispassionate analysis, to have led to this dispute.

There has been some discussion about the role of the accord in regard to this exercise. One has to look at its history and note that between 1983, when the accord was established, and the end of 1987 strike activity fell by 82 per cent. One would have to accept that that, in itself, has contributed millions of dollars to the Australian economy, and hence there have been gains. Likewise, comments have been made in Australia and overseas about our accord. The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has seen value in the accord, as have other countries. The President of South Korea recently invited an Australian delegation to his country to discuss the accord. The South Korean economy has experienced industrial unrest and currently wage claims in the vicinity of 40 to 50 per cent are being looked at. One would have to say that South Korea is going through that problem because it started off at a very low industrial base and moved very rapidly to a very high industrial base while seeking democratisation. One of the down sides of freedom is that we permit people to strike and value their right to do so.

The coalition raised a number of items here today and suggested that its alternative policies would have worked whereas the current ones do not. I am not at all sure that there is a great deal of substance in that. I make exactly the same point that Senator Button made. If a group of people resigned, if they are no longer employed, no industrial policy is of any worth. If they stay within the system and strike, we can definitely compare systems. But we cannot have a system which compels people to work unless we introduce some sort of slavery. If people choose to resign from their jobs, they are using the ultimate weapon they have, although it is a pretty drastic weapon for any individual to use. Once people use that weapon, they are outside the system in toto and the industrial relations system is irrelevant from that point onwards. This dispute will not be settled under this system.

Yesterday, a very good article in the Australian Financial Review by Pamela Williams raised a number of matters put forward by the Opposition. In her analysis, she made five points. She said that there had been a secret ballot before the initiation of the pilots' action. Secondly, the Opposition's policy is that people should be allowed to opt out of the system. Indeed, after the cancellation of the pilots' award, there was an opting out of the system. Thirdly, the Opposition's policy seeks direct negotiations between employer and employees. That undoubtedly is currently available and has been available to date. Fourthly, the Opposition's policy urges the use of the common law. That use is currently under way. Indeed, at the end of the day, the pilots may wish they had never heard of common law. Many tourism operators in Queensland who are losing millions of dollars a day are not likely to be bound by any resolution made by other groups and discontinue their claims. Many of those tourist operations will continue with their lawsuits willy-nilly. I am not sure that the pilots knew what they were letting themselves in for in that respect. Fifthly, the Opposition's policy talks about wage gains being achieved for productivity.

In terms of that analysis, one might say that the dispute has followed the essential lines set out in the Liberal and National parties' industrial relations policy. I fail to see how the Opposition's policy would have meant that the situation would have been different, unless there had been an agreement to the 30 per cent wage rise. As I do not read all the newspapers in Australia, I am unaware of the Liberal and National parties' position on the wage rise itself. However, unless the wage rise were granted, under any system we would be where we are today because the pilots were willing to push ahead and use the resignation weapon so early in the dispute. Few other groups would even dare to use that weapon because of the very difficult situation it puts the individual in, particularly those who do not have great resources.

If one looks at the industrial relations atmosphere in Australia, one has to admit that in recent years some changes have not been for the best. Indeed, when the first Willis Bill was introduced in 1987 the Australian Democrats expressed their support for it. The Bill contained non-compliance provisions and retained the ability to go to common law. But it was proposed that a one-stop shop be introduced through the notion of a labour court. As a result of a very strong campaign run against that proposal by the New Right, the Labor Government backed off that Bill and introduced a much weaker Bill which was less able to deal with the types of problems we are facing today. I believe that the original Bill would have been a far better Bill to deal with the current situation. It would have been a far better Bill in terms of industrial relations, particularly as it proposed a more effective, more certain, and certainly cheaper method of operation than exists under the current system.

Australia could move away from the adversarial system of industrial relations, but it is unlikely to do so for a number of reasons, not the least of which is that the entire political climate of this country is based on the adversarial system and that, in effect, flows through to many of the other major operating systems in this country. It is fascinating that politicians never want to take any blame for anything that happens; they want to take credit only for the good things. The political system is probably one of the things that lead to the type of industrial relations that we have in this country. Rarely, on any issue, even for the good of the country and for the benefit of the Australian population, can one get a bipartisan or tripartisan operation.

The exercise that we are currently facing suggests a number of points. We need to be extremely careful when we are pushing the idea of enterprise based unions to make sure that we do not in fact take on some of the very real problems that are inherent in such an exercise. It has a great deal of merit but it also raises some problems, one of which is interesting in terms of the current dispute. I refer to the productivity debate: There are limits to the move in terms of productivity. To mention one that, obviously, I have an interest in, how might we gauge the move to productivity with regard to teachers? Are we to gauge it by more teaching hours, larger classes or better results? There are limits and one has to be careful in a service based economy, which is basically what Australia is. In a labour intensive exercise, one of the easiest ways to get an increase in productivity is to shed labour. That is very difficult to do when one is trying to keep up the labour force participation.

Enterprise based unions tend to encourage a more inflexible work force, with people staying within the same company structures for a long period. To use the Japanese example, at the end of the day companies then take on a much greater role in a high range of areas, such as social security and pensions. I am not sure that many employers in this country would be terribly happy with that. But they are some of the things that it seems would flow from those enterprise based structures that do not flow from the current industrial base. So one can often hypothesise about alternative systems providing us with a better exercise but in thinking through these matters one always has to point out that, unfortunately, in this area there are always downsides to every gain that we are going to get; that industrial relations is a hard slog area.

I would like to make one final point. If we are to compare ourselves with our foreign counterparts, as the pilots are currently doing, we have to accept the fact that Australia is no longer one of the wealthiest countries in the world and the comparative international remuneration, whether it be for car workers, teachers, pilots or judges, is simply not on any longer. It is highly likely that by the year 2000 Australia will have one of the lowest living standards in the Asian region. I think what we will be required to do is pay within the Australian context. If we are able to offer a high quality of life while we may have a lower living standard, people may very well wish to live here for that reason and accept a lower income. If they do want the higher incomes, it is probably inevitable that pilots and other skilled workers will go overseas to seek them in the international wage arena.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to begin by referring to a couple of remarks from the government side of the chamber this afternoon. I refer in particular to what was described as a personal explanation by Senator Aulich when he rose to his feet after Question Time to attempt to explain how he had been misrepresented in one of the questions asked from this side. Senator Aulich waxed quite eloquent. While admitting-I think he conceded it-that the quotation given by our side of the House from his speech here 10 or 11 days ago was accurate, he put the view to the Senate that it was not a complete presentation of his position and that other things that he said subsequently or in some other part of his speech, differed from that and made it plain that he was not in any way ruling out the possibility of taking industrial disputes into the courts of the land and using common law and things of that kind.

SPEECH.PARA: I have subsequently had a look at the transcript of what Senator Aulich said that day and I have to say that, with the best will in the world I cannot find anything in his speech which conforms to what he has told us he said. Now maybe I got an inaccurate transcript, but it is in the Senate Hansard. I hope I am wrong, but it seems to me on the face of it that Senator Aulich has not been fully straightforward with us about this matter. I will leave that matter there. I have found however, by going back to look at his speech, a couple of things that he did say and is clearly on the record as having said which I would like to put on the record again. The first is the statement which was accurately quoted earlier, when he said:
We must have learnt from experience, through industrial relations history, that enforced compliance with the law or with the spirit of good industrial relations is not the solution . . .

I do not altogether agree with what Senator Aulich had to say at that point because there are some situations in industrial relations where compliance with the law is absolutely necessary. I refer to the simple law of contract for a start. That is why we have had some argument in recent times about the use of law of industrial tort in such cases as the Dollar Sweets and Mudginberri disputes and so on. I think section 45d of the Trade Practices Act was used in the case of Mudginberri. That is the first of Senator Aulich's comments to which I draw attention. The second comment that I would like to recall for the Senate is the following:

. . . taught us that in the end the worst possible thing to do to improve industrial relations in this country is to get people into the courts and the common law system. That is the worst possible way for people to go . . .

I do not agree with what Senator Aulich said, but the point that was being made in the question in which Senator Aulich said he was being misrepresented was that this is exactly what the Government is now saying the airline companies and, indeed, anybody else who is prepared to put up his hand and pay a good barrister for the purpose, should now be doing to the airline pilots. I personally think that is highly questionable in this case, but what Senator Aulich is doing is apparently approving it in this case, even though less than fortnight ago he said it was a stupid or very silly thing to do, or words to that effect.
To do justice to Senator Aulich, let me pick up one other statement from his speech on that occasion when he said:

That box seat in most industrial disputes is generally held by the employer in the sense that employee organisations and the individual employees have nothing to negotiate with but their labour. That labour can be withdrawn: that is the only weapon they have.

I will come to my view of the airline pilots in a moment, but let us at least be fair enough to say that that is precisely what the airline pilots have said. They have said, `We agree with Senator Aulich. Our labour is the only thing that we can withdraw. That is the only weapon we have'. Let us be clear about what Senator Aulich's views are. I wish I could think Senator Aulich was equally clear about them. Let me also pick up a comment by Senator Button this afternoon in responding to Senator Lewis when he, I think quite shamefully, misrepresented the position of Senator Chaney. I regret that I have to say that, because I do not think Senator Button is normally guilty of that sin. He first of all quoted from something that Senator Chaney said on 22 August which suggested that the best thing was for talks to occur. Then Senator Button said that in a letter in the Australian Financial Review of 29 August Senator Chaney had said that effective arbitration was the answer. Let me just read what Senator Chaney actually said in that letter of 29 August. He was referring to his comments on the Face to Face program last Sunday. In his letter he said:

Consistent with this, I said only yesterday on the Face to Face programme that I saw two courses available in the current dispute. The first was for sensible direct discussion on what could be done to improve productivity to form a basis for a proper wage rise for the pilots. This I described as the constructive option.

Senator Button did not acknowledge in any way that Senator Chaney had said that in the paragraph immediately preceding the paragraph that Senator Button proceeded to quote totally out of context in a fairly clear and, I must say deliberate, attempt to misrepresent Senator Chaney-an extraordinary effort on Senator Button's part. I am very surprised. Senator Chaney continued:
I went on to say that if that was not acceptable to the parties then, and only then, you would need to look to effective arbitration.
I do not want to spend further time on Senator Button's misrepresentations, but that is as gross a misrepresentation as I have come across.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just done that.

—Yes, but Senator Button did not acknowledge in any way that Senator Chaney had said that in the paragraph immediately preceding the paragraph that Senator Button proceeded to quote, totally out of context, in a fairly clear and, I must say, deliberate attempt to misrepresent Senator Chaney. That was an extraordinary effort on the part of Senator Button and I am very surprised by it. Senator Chaney, in his letter, continued:

SPEECH.PARA: I went on to say that if that was not acceptable to the parties then, and only then, you would need to look to effective arbitration.

I do not want to spend any further item on Senator Button's misrepresentations, but I do want to say that that is as gross a misrepresentation as I have come across in this place since I have been here, which is not all that long, I suppose. I turn to the matter of public importance itself, which is:
The failure of the Hawke Government's industrial relations policy which has led to the massive disruption caused by the airline pilots' dispute.

Let us be quite clear: that is what the present situation is about. It is about the failure of the Hawke Government's industrial relations policy. We have got a massive overreaction from the Government because it sees that the accord is failing, is breaking down, and that, if the pilots are allowed to win, it will be the major signal-along with all the more minor ones which have already occurred-of that breakdown. No longer will the Government be able to go around the country boasting and trumpeting about its masterly economic instrument, the accord-that masterly economic instrument which has brought this Government $108 billion in foreign debt to 30 June, as announced today.

Nevertheless, because this Government has so much political capital-I almost said `intellectual capital', except it is a contradiction in terms as far as this Government is concerned-invested in this accord, which it now sees is breaking down, it is desperate and will do anything to stop this breakout by the pilots. It has done most things already. We had the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), for goodness sake, intervening in this industrial dispute between the airlines and the pilots. Look at the way he has intervened. Everything he has done, everything he has said from beginning to end-not the end, because unfortunately we are not near the end of this matter, but up to this time-has been disastrous. Every personal intervention by the Prime Minister has been disastrous. We have, after all, I think most people would agree, what is certainly shaping up to be one of the worst industrial disputes in this country's history.

TALK.START.PARA: —No question.

—I see Senator Collins agreeing with me. There is no question about that. This dispute will make the shearers strike look like peanuts by the time it is finished if it is allowed to continue in the way it is going at the present time under the direction and masterminding-under the baton-of the Prime Minister. Everything this Prime Minister has done has been counterproductive. First of all, he described the pilots as `glorified bus drivers'. I do not want to say anything at all about bus drivers, but one will not find an honest bus driver in this country who will compare himself to a pilot. That is for certain. They are far more honest about this matter than is the Prime Minister.
—Are you saying that caused the dispute?

—No. I am saying it helped to inflame the dispute further. There is no doubt about that. Secondly, the Prime Minister talked in a ridiculous way about it being easy to learn to fly. He talked about learning to fly in the university air squadron at Oxford-flying chipmunks, or something like that. How ridiculous can one get? This is the Prime Minister of this country again inflaming this dispute. On Ray Martin's Midday Show he threatened the pilots and took out the big waddy. He said, `If you go out now, boys, it's war', again taking out his field marshal's baton.
—It was the pilots who invaded Parliament.

—I quite agree with Senator Collins; they have taken him at his word. I want to make it clear that the Opposition holds no particular brief for the pilots. We do not believe they are necessarily entitled to a 30 per cent salary increase. If they can show productivity gains to justify that increase, of course they will be worth it. They might be worth more than that. It is possible that they could get more than that if they went through proper productivity discussions with their employers, if the Government would get out of the way and stop protecting Bill Kelty, the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and the failed accord. This is something which should be determined in the end only between the pilots and their employers, and Mr Hawke has no part to play in that ring. The Opposition certainly does not support the disruption to the lives of the travelling Australian public that has been caused by this dispute. We certainly vigorously deplore the costs to tourism and other industries caused by this breakdown in industrial common sense stimulated, enforced and reinforced by the Prime Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: What is this Government's policy, apart from bullying and threatening? Where is it going now? It has produced the situation of following the policy of the ACTU-the age-old policy of the trade union bosses in this to bluff, bluster, threaten, bully and stand over people in the belief that in the end might is right and muscle will win. Unfortunately, that has often been the case in the history of industrial relations in this country, but I put it to Government senators opposite that this time the Government may have met, in the pilots, a body of men and women who are prepared to stand up to the bluff, bluster, bullying, threatening and standover tactics of the Prime Minister and of this Government, and of the airlines.

What are the Prime Minister's objectives? They are to prop up the ridiculous decision of the Industrial Relations Commission a few weeks ago, and the position of Bill Kelty. I wonder who the apprentice is now. Bill Kelty used to be described as the sorcerer's apprentice-Bob Hawke's apprentice. I think it should be the other way around at the present time. The Prime Minister's objectives are to prop up the ACTU, which is losing membership and is desperately concerned about that fact. It is no accident that the Australian Federation of Air Pilots is not a member of the ACTU, so the response seems to be, `Let's smash them, boys, because they have the impertinence not to join the ACTU'.

We have had one solution from the Prime Minister. First of all, the Royal Australian Air Force was going to carry everybody; it is carrying 2 to 3 per cent of total passengers in this country. Then the passengers were to be carried by the foreign airlines coming through this country on their normal flights. They are carrying a few people, and I am glad to see that-it is at least something-but everybody knows they are carrying only 7 to 8 per cent of total would-be passengers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course. It is always the weapon the pilots have had.

—I ask those such as Senator Collins, who is interjecting on the other side: What will this Government do if this dispute drags on and on? Is it going to clap the pilots in irons and put them back at the joysticks, or whatever they are called these days? I am back in Bob Hawke's Oxford days in speaking about joysticks. This is the question the Government is refusing to answer. Has it got a policy, or has it been pushed into this situation by another compact, another little mini-accord, between the Prime Minister and Bill Kelty and, in turn, between them and Sir Peter Abeles and Mr Harris, the Prime Minister's tennis-playing friend?

SPEECH.PARA: I put it to the Government that this is an extraordinarily bad industrial dispute. The balance of payments will go further and further into the red down the track. If Moody's Investors Service rerates us, it will be not AA2 but AA3 or worse. On today, of all days, when we have the new figure for the foreign debt of this country of $108 billion, this Government's representatives in this chamber are saying that it is not a matter of public importance to discuss the failure of the Hawke Government's industrial relations policy which has led to the massive disruption caused by the airline pilots dispute. They have no answers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Both Senator Stone and Senator Lewis need a lesson in history. The Australian Federation of Air Pilots is far too professional and hard-headed a union, and has been for many years, to be in the slightest way affected by anything the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) might say or, indeed, anything said in this Parliament. The escalation of the dispute has been a matter of tit for tat on both sides, between the employers and employees, and the Opposition knows it. The reality is that there are many people in the Australian community at the moment asking why the Federation is behaving like a bunch of bloody-minded thugs.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two very good reasons why it is. Firstly, it has always behaved like a bunch of bloody-minded thugs and, secondly, it has always worked. The Air Pilots Federation in fact is, and always has been, the most militant white-collar union in Australia. In terms of its membership, it is also the most highly paid association in Australia. As a comment I must say that when I was researching this debate I had a look at all of the material that was available on industrial relations in the airline business, and there is very little of it about. I am indebted to the enterprise and efforts of Di Yerbury and her monograph entitled Collective Negotiations and the Airline Pilots, 1946-67 and to the particularly comprehensive work-and there is not much of it about, I can tell you-entitled Industrial Relations in the Air by Dr Nicholas Blain, a Western Australian academic and expert in industrial relations. Just to show how little things have changed, Senator Lewis, I quote from this book a statement by the then conservative Minister, the Hon. L. H. E. Bury, when he said about a former dispute:

For years, relationships between the Pilots' Association and later the Federation were in a pretty constant state of ferment. While many factors contributed to this unfortunate situation, one of them was the disposition of the pilots' body to exploit to the full their unique bargaining position, irrespective of the consequences for the industry and the public.

Nothing has changed. There had in fact been many disputes, strikes and regulation strikes similar to the nine to five strike in recent days in the years up to this point. The worst was the 28-day Qantas strike of 1966. The events which led to this strike began in 1958, when the Federation demanded a 28 per cent increase in domestic pilots' salaries, only a couple of per cent less than they are asking for now. In terms of further parallels with the current dispute, the airlines at that time offered a 10 per cent increase, to which the Federation did not respond, despite its failure to provide any convincing evidence to support its 28 per cent claim-also similar to the current dispute. In response to the threat of a nationwide strike, the airlines buckled and paid up.

One of the lasting outcomes of that agreement, which is relevant to the current dispute, was the replacement of duty rosters prepared by management with the current system of incentive bidding which still operates for Australian pilots, although in a far more beneficial way, as I will now explain, than it does for pilots in its place of origin, the United States of America. The introduction of this system as a result of the dispute led to an actual increase at the time in pilots' salaries of 35 per cent rather than the 26 per cent that had been agreed upon. The flow-on of this decision for domestic pilots to industrial action by Qantas was almost instant.

In the face of the refusal of Qantas to comply with the demands, and with the addition of a number of issues ostensibly related to safety but widely accepted as being a front for the main agenda-money-the strike began on 25 November, lasted for 28 days and had catastrophic consequences for the airlines. Indeed, Mr President, there must be many rank and file members, a number of whom I know personally, of the Air Pilots Federation that are starting to be alarmed at the results of their bloody-minded industrial action on the whole of the Australian community, because it is starting to get very smelly indeed. I am sure that many of those people are trying to cope with this current dispute by holding their noses and thinking of money.

At the time of this dispute I have just mentioned-it is of some interest for Opposition members perhaps to note-the then responsible Minister, Billy McMahon, even considered at one stage during the strike using the Federal Crimes Act against the pilots. The strike was finally settled by the company and the Government as usual capitulating to the demands of the Federation and the pilots then receiving salary increases of between 21 and 36 per cent. Following these two major victories, an indication of how the Federation viewed itself, and still views itself, in relation to the rest of the Australian community was provided by its then President, and indeed longest serving President, Captain R. Holt, when he welcomed the Minister for Civil Aviation, Reg Swartz, as the guest of honour to the Federation's convention in the same year as this dispute. This is what he said-and it is pretty extraordinary stuff-when he introduced the Minister as the guest of honour:
This Federation has an industrial strength that is unique. We can do anything that we like-we can do anything lawful that we like.

The political consequence of the 28-day strike was the decision by the then conservative Government to introduce legislation bringing the pilots back under jurisdiction of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. The years that followed were marked by frequent disputes and industrial actions resulting in big advances in both pay and conditions for pilots. One of the interesting features, I might add, of the major 1974 dispute, over a claim for a 27 per cent increase on that occasion, was the ban that was imposed by the Federation on flights to Canberra and the threatened selective ban on carrying on any aircraft any Labor members of parliament. The Federation stated that the ban would be lifted only if the Prime Minister sacked both the Minister for Labour and the Minister for Transport. The arrogance of these people really knows no bounds, and nothing has changed. The pilots, among other things, claimed that these Ministers had referred to the pilots as `bloody bushrangers', `greedy bastards' and `elitist fat cats'. Well, nothing has changed there either. The reason I mention this, Mr Deputy President, is that it is very reminiscent of the quite extraordinary statements made recently by the President of the Federation, Brian McCarthy, that the Prime Minister should stay out of the dispute.

TALK.START.PARA: —So he should.

—The honourable senator agrees. I do not think the public do, Senator. The pilots have so far crippled this country's entire civil aviation industry, are destroying the country's biggest export earner, its tourist industry, are directly threatening the jobs of 20,000 of their fellow workers in the aviation industry, and are sending thousands of other Australians on a fraction of their pay and conditions to the wall-and they instruct the Prime Minister of Australia, in the face of all of that, that this dispute has got nothing to do with him. The arrogance of these blokes really does know no bounds.

SPEECH.PARA: The two constants, in fact, that I have discovered in all of the industrial action pursued by the Federation over the years were that the Federation never hesitated to behave like thugs and always went for double figures. As Blain's book noted, one of the crucial factors in the negotiating stance, so-called, of the Federation was its insistence, on all occasions, that its salary demands be met virtually in full. It was able to achieve this by ruthlessly exploiting the fact that pilots were almost irreplaceable in the short term, and still are, because of the technological stranglehold they have on the airlines by being able to bring their operations to an instant halt with the massive financial consequences to the airlines if they do not instantly comply with their demands. The pilots have been very successful indeed in the years since in bringing about a situation which those opposite are all cheerfully ignoring in terms of the references to their being able to go overseas and compete on the international marketplace-as a result of this industrial action and this unique position, they have successfully negotiated the most beneficial system of pay and conditions for pilots in the world. If those opposite do not believe me, believe the Federation. I seek leave to table, for the benefit of honourable senators, an advice sent out by the Federation in 1988 advising its members that this is precisely the case.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy President. The Federation told its members, among other things, that this document-that is, the agreement:

SPEECH.PARA: maintains some of the best working conditions in the world of aviation and allows pilots to increase their pay without downgrading promotional opportunity.
It went on to say, in direct reference to the pay and conditions of pilots in the United States and overseas:
There is no other pilot group in the world that enjoys your overall standard of pay protection.
So what the Federation wants is the best standard in the world plus 30 per cent. It is an outrageous demand, and it should not get it.

Mr Deputy President, I seek leave also to table, for the benefit of honourable senators and others, a document entitled Deadline 1989 which was issued by the Federation to its membership several months before the dispute instructing them on how to get ready for this prolonged dispute and which states, among other things, in the final couple of paragraphs, that this is an excellent opportunity to complete many of the tasks around the house that have not been done for years; an excellent opportunity to have a complete break from the house and go fishing, work on the car, or start a lawn mowing business, while others may decide it is an excellent time to become involved in the unions activities, et cetera.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, time does not allow me to give the Federation the attention it so richly deserves, but I would like to conclude by talking about the proposed solution to this problem by the Opposition, as advanced by Senator Chaney: wave a wand, introduce amendments that will give sanctions to the conciliation Commission, and that will fix the dispute. The reality is that that approach leaves an impression that the law as a whole is inadequate and in need of reform, but those opposite have not actually stated that this is their view and they have not actually stated-and I have had a careful look at everything that has been said-that it will solve the airline pilots dispute. In all the interviews that Senator Chaney has given this is the impression that he has created.

SPEECH.PARA: At present, the Opposition is saying that the amendments to the Act proposed will extend the power of the Commission to deal with the matter. Let us look at what is currently available. In terms of invoking sanctions, the Commission currently has available the following options: sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act, which deal with secondary and primary boycotts; the so-called common law industrial torts that permit actions for damages; sections 30j and 30k of the Crimes Act 1914, which deal with serious industrial disturbances interfering with interstate and overseas trade and commerce-which were the sections that Billy McMahon was going to use against the pilots; the bans clause procedures under sections 125 and 181 to 186 of the Industrial Relations Act; cancellation or suspension of awards under section 187; deregistration under section 294; under a new provision inserted in the 1988 Act the Commission may also refuse to deal with a matter raised by an organisation in breach of an award or direction of the Commission; and the discretionary power of the Commission to withhold national wage increases from parties which breach or fail to give `no extra claims' commitments under the wage fixing principles.

This is a pretty hefty range of sanctions. It should also be mentioned that the present law in Australia is tougher than the legislation enacted throughout all of the years of the Thatcher Government in the United Kingdom, where unions which gain majority support for industrial action in a secret ballot held prior to taking such action have limited immunity from common law actions. Moreover, in the United Kingdom the size of the fines for industrial action is subject to a statutory limitation. Common law action in Australia is not subject to any such statutory limits. Given this array of sanctions, Senator Chaney has been impelled to argue that the sanctions available to the Commission under the Industrial Relations Act are inadequate.

But does this really matter? Clearly, from the point of view of fines and statutory penalties, in the current dispute it matters very little whether they are contained in the Industrial Relations Act or the Trade Practices Act. Actions for enforcement of such penalties, because of the separation of powers doctrine, must ultimately be brought through the Federal Court. The Commission has no power to enforce directly its own decisions other than through denying parties access to it, and it is beyond this Parliament's power-it is about time someone said it-short of a referendum changing the Constitution, to change this situation.

Similarly, it is entirely a matter between the employers and their now ex-employees as to how they respectively go about enforcing or limiting common law rights and duties. The sorts of damages to which Senator Stone referred that in the past have been awarded against unions would appear to represent a sufficient deterrent to any form of industrial action. Likewise breaches of section 45D (1A) of the Trade Practices Act, which deals specifically with primary boycotts affecting interstate trade, would leave individual pilots open to fines of $50,000 and their union to fines of $250,000 for each separate offence. If the courts were to impose an injunction which was ignored by the pilots, the pilots or the union might also be liable for fines for contempt of court. The Opposition amendments are totally ineffective as a means of resolving this current dispute.
While I have the time I will correct an article written by Pamela Williams in the Australian Financial Review yesterday about the sanctions proposed by the Opposition. It states that they:
. . . will have no effect whatever in the. . . dispute as the pilots are no longer in the system.
This is not strictly correct. Because of past disputes involving the pilots, the Commission has a special or extended jurisdiction to deal with disputes in the airline industry.
In conclusion I once again refer to the policy section in Blain's book. It might be relevant to everyone, including the pilots, to read it. Written in 1984, it states:

The pilots' resort to militant action, especially in the period 1957 to 1966, demonstrates their ability to inflict heavy economic penalties on their employers. The 1966 28 day Qantas strike is the most obvious example. A shorter strike may well have produced similar gains for the pilots; the more restrained use of the strike since 1966 has shown that pilots can still make substantial gains by limiting the duration of their strikes. Even though it is 16 years since it occurred, the 28 day Qantas strikes should serve as a salient reminder to present day pilots both that strikes should not be unnecessarily prolonged and that arbitration can always be used as a final step in dispute settlement. This reminder is particularly timely in the light of the imminent introduction of new generation aircraft by the domestic carriers.
Mr Deputy President, I concur.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in support of this matter of public importance before the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Hawke Government's industrial relations policy which has led to the massive disruption caused by the airline pilots' dispute.

As Senator Stone said, Australia is suffering under one of the most grievous industrial disputes in our history-a dispute which shows no sign of ending, which is running at enormous cost with the nation bleeding to death. Not one Australian Labor Party senator or Australian Democrat senator has made one constructive suggestion as to how this disaster can be remedied. It is a disaster which is the consequence of the policies of those who sit on the Government benches. It is customary at this time in a debate to deal with the points raised by the speakers with the opposing point of view. Unfortunately, there has been no such contribution for me to debate.

Senator Stone expressed surprise at the dissembling that came from Senator Button. I am not surprised because I have been here a lot longer than Senator Stone has. If there is one person in this place who distorts and deflects the truth, it is Senator Button. Today Senator Button-and in a lesser way Senator Collins-did in misrepresenting what Senator Chaney and other Opposition speakers have said about industrial relations policy is just par for the course. It is crucial that Government senators do that because one Achilles heel of this Government is its archaic industrial relations policy.

The Government knows that the Opposition has a workable and practical industrial relations policy; it knows the Australian community is tired of strikes, tired of the effect of those strikes on our standard of living. The community is tired of seeing in report after report that the nearest comparable Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) country to Australia has 2 1/2 times fewer strikes than we have. Countries like Japan and Germany have about one-fiftieth of the strikes that we have. So it is absolutely crucial to the Labor Party that our position on industrial relations be debased, ridiculed and misrepresented. If the Government does not destroy that position it knows that the public will accept our policy at the polls.

There are four points I wish to touch on briefly. First of all I want to go to the heart of the problem-the reason for the strike-which is simply the Labor Party's system of an inflexible and inappropriate centralised wage fixing. Secondly I want to talk about the consequences of the strike-the tragic consequences for Australia, the huge debt position we are in, the way that this debt is accelerating and the way that this strike is lighting the powder fuse under that debt. Thirdly I will specify what needs to be done. Finally I want to spend a little bit of time on the Government's actions-the way a Labor Government has acted as strike breakers in this dispute by using the Royal Australian Air Force, by using the charter operators of Australia, by allowing overseas operators to come in and break the strike. That is something that goes to the very heart of the Labor Party ethos and that the Government, in its hypocrisy, is quite happy to do. I want to talk too about the double standards adopted by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Government in the way they have handled this dispute.

First of all, let us look at the heart of the problem. The reason for the problem is simply that we are stuck with the great socialist dream: the belief of the Labor Party that it can control a national economy; the belief that it can dot every i and cross every t, and control and manage every aspect of the huge variations that exist in the economy. It is a great socialist dream that the Government can control all of this.

The accord is a total failure-a failure that has cost Australia, as Senator Stone said, a debt position of $125 billion to $130 billion, depending on how we calculate the exchange rate. The accord fails because it is a centralised wage controlling system. The Labor Party is forced to support the accord because it is supporting the dinosaurs of a trade union movement which is going out of business fast. Its membership is falling. I think its national membership figures for the work force are 32 to 35 per cent. Some decades ago the figure was well over 50 per cent. The Australian Labor Party is the parliamentary arm of the trade union movement. So it is vitally important that the ex-union secretaries and the schoolteachers here representing the Labor Party must reflect in their policies support for the Australian Council of Trade Unions, which wants the accord held because it is central to maintaining the place of the ACTU in Australia and preserving this archaic union structure which is dragging down our standard of living day by day.

The Liberal Party and the National Party offer an alternative. We know there is a better way and the Australian people know there is a better way. They know that we ought to have voluntary unionism. If people want to join a union that is their civil right. But unions should not have any power to coerce people to join unions. They should not have any power to set up closed shops. We also believe that the unions should not be craft based. They should be enterprise based, so that the survival of the whole enterprise is directly related to the individual efforts of those people involved, a process of cause and effect. But the Labor Party is stuck with this inflexible, archaic system.

One of the consequences of the present system, and what Senator Collins is terrified of, is the flow-on effect. Under the present rigid system, if someone somewhere gets a wage rise, the rest of the union members must get it and the people in other unions must get it. So the whole of the Australian economy becomes inflated, irrespective of the ability of an industry or an employer to pay. Obviously, the system is unworkable. The Labor Party knows this. We have seen spurious productivity gains in the last few years under the accord. Productivity has not gone up at all; it has only been fiddled by the Labor Party, which has used the excuse of productivity awards to grant wage rises.

As well as maintaining the fixed 6 per cent wage rise, unions have indulged in deceitful, covert activities. Site allowances for the Builders Labourers Federation, for example, have resulted in people getting wage rises far beyond what the airline pilots are asking for at present. The Labor system cannot work. There is a better way-voluntary agreements, which any mature industrial society must have.

What are the consequences of what the Labor Party has done in regard to this dispute? Firstly, let us consider the fact that we have a huge foreign debt. It was $32 billion when the Labor Party came to power. It is running close to $128 billion, or $130 billion, today. It is out of control. During the last sitting week the Treasurer (Mr Keating) brought down his Budget. We all recall that, the year before, the treasury estimate of the deficit was $9.5 billion. In reality, on 31 June this year it turned out to be $17.5 billion. This year the Treasurer said that the deficit would be $18.5 billion. The deficit position of this country is out of control, and this is at a time when we have the best conditions facing us: high commodity prices, good world markets and a strong world economy. The only response the Government has made to this chaotic situation is to enforce a very high interest rates policy which suppresses industry and denies our import competition.

At the end of the day it will be the Liberal Party and the National Party, in government, which will have to clean up and pay back the huge debt that will have been left to us. But a bigger problem than paying back that debt will be interest payments. When I went out to earn a living, one of the first things that was said to me by one of my elders was that borrowing money is not the problem; the real problem is paying the interest on it. That is the real killer for Australia today-the interest on the $130 billion-odd that we owe. It is utterly irrelevant for the Labor Party to say that most of that debt is private, that it is not government debt. It is all a charge against the Australian dollar. We saw proof of that in the statement of the Reserve Bank of Australia a couple of weeks ago. It pointed to the grave dangers we were in under the present policy of this Government. Only last night we heard that Moody's Investor Services Inc. had downgraded Australia's credit rating. Goodness knows where we are going to end up on its scale. We have gone from AAA to AA2. We might well end up at ZZZ if Mr Keating is around long enough. I quote one sentence from Moody's report:
Nonetheless we believe that the Budget fails-
referring to the Federal Budget of a couple of weeks ago-
to decisively address the issues of external imbalance and productivity, and that lies at the heart of the Australian problem.

The Australian population is frightened by this debt position, and well it might be. This Government is making it worse by the minute by not coming up with any constructive solutions to end the pilots strike. One of the key industries involved is the tourism industry, which last week reported record earnings of $6.5 billion, eclipsing coal, at $6 billion, as Australia's biggest export earner. The importance of that lies in two dimensions: firstly, in its vulnerability and, secondly, in the fact that it is not all profit. We have made a huge investment in the tourism industry in the last three to five years. In other words, unlike the cattle industry and the coal industry, which we bought in the prices of decades ago, and amortised the cost, we have made our investment in the tourism industry in today's prices and at today's interest rates, and we are crucially dependent on traffic flow through them to pay them off, let alone to earn money for us.

The other thing about Australia's tourism industry is that it is a vulnerable industry because we are a long way from anywhere. Fares to Australia are high. We cannot afford to charge the top world market rate for our hotels because, if we do, the economics of a holiday in Australia for tourists becomes uneconomic. The important thing in relation to tourist trade is predictability. Unlike Australian employees, who enjoy six weeks holiday with 17 1/2 per cent loading, many employees in the United States have to work for a couple of years before they are entitled to holidays, and then it is only 10 days or 14 days. A similar position applies in Japan. For American or Japanese tourists to come out here on their holidays, they have to know with absolute certainty that on the Monday morning after their holiday they will be back in their work place, otherwise they lose their job.

The tourism industry, which employs 480,000 people, is currently estimated to be losing something like $5m a day as a consequence of this strike, to say nothing of the money that is going out on the overseas carriers which are acting as strike breakers. We are bleeding to death. What we require is a rapid resolution of this dispute. The dispute is going to be resolved but, if one listens to the Labor Party, one would believe it never was. It is going to be resolved in the only way possible: by talks between the employers and the employees. I do not want to take sides on who is to blame. I think fault lies on both sides. One certainly cannot have preconditions put on those talks by employees if one is to expect employees to come to them but, at the end of the day, we have to get back to commercial reality.

The pilots are prepared to talk. Their productivity must go up. I agree with those who say that.
