But, in fairness to the pilots, their low productivity does not result simply from their bloody-mindedness. It results from this Government's great degree of over-regulation. Civil aviation regulations prevent any employer from extracting much over 60 per cent of the nominal hours to be worked.

The other factor is the poor management of the airlines. I am the only person left on this side of the chamber who voted against the two-airline Bill. I voted against it at the time because it did not provide any competition at all between the airlines; it did not provide for commercial reality. One of the consequences has been that air fares have gone up beyond the reach of most people. Another consequence has been that the management of the airlines have been able to run on a cost-plus basis. They have not addressed the matter of productivity with the pilots, the way they should have in the past.

What has the Government done? All we have had from the Government is irrational statements from Mr Hawke, publicly abusing his opponents and trying to score some cheap political points by acting like a latter day cardboard Rambo. I am very interested in Mr Hawke's deprecation of pilots as bus drivers and in his talking about his own experience in this field. I challenge Mr Hawke to table his log books in the Parliament so that we can see how many hours he actually flew. My advice was that he was scrubbed off the course at Oxford because he could not pass his trial introductory flight. At the end of the day, we have this Government acting as strike breakers. We have this Government leaning on the Civil Aviation Authority, granting licences to carriers like Arrow Air, which has a dubious safety record, in a matter of hours when normally it would take a matter of months.

This country is bleeding to death. The Government knew that this problem was coming. It did nothing to pre-empt it. It did no contingency planning to avoid it. It has no way of helping the employers or the employees to settle their dispute. But, hopefully, all this is just the death throes of the dinosaurs of the trade union movement and, though we pay a high price for it, I hope that Australia benefits ultimately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by giving credit to Senator MacGibbon who has managed to speak in this debate for a quarter of an hour about the Hawke Government's industrial relations policy and the airline pilots dispute and has mentioned either matter on only one or two occasions. Senator MacGibbon correctly identified the fact that he and the Opposition are on a real loser in this debate. Senator Lewis deserves congratulations for having the courage to debate this matter this afternoon. Throughout the airline pilots dispute it has been the Opposition's industrial relations policy that has been under the microscope, not the Government's. We find ourselves in a position where on the one hand the Industrial Relations Commission, the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), the Government, the airlines, the travelling public in Australia and ordinary Australian workers are united in their opposition to the demands of the airline pilots and, on the other hand, the Australian Federation of Airline Pilots is demanding a 29.47 per cent wage increase which we all know our nation cannot afford. Somewhere in between these two we find the Opposition, the Liberal Party and the National Party, floundering as usual because its industrial relations policy is exposed. In the unlikely event of the Opposition ever being elected to government we would have hundreds of these sorts of disputes. There would be unmitigated industrial chaos. This matter of public importance proposed by Senator Lewis claims two things: firstly, that the Hawke Government's industrial relations policy has failed and, secondly, that the Government's industrial relations policy has led to the disruption caused by the pilots dispute. I hope that in the time I have available to me I can address both those issues. The key assumption of Senator Lewis is that the Hawke Government's industrial policies over the past 6 1/2 years have failed. Of course, it is a false assumption and one which can be easily debunked by an examination of the Government's record.
—It is disastrous.

—The honourable senator says it is disastrous but, in fact, the industrial relations record of this Government is one of its greatest achievements. The cornerstone of its success has been the prices and incomes accord which established an effective mechanism of consultation and cooperation between government, employers and trade unions in the wage fixing process. I know that Senator Stone and others have an obsession with the accord. They have to realise that the accord emerged out of the economic shambles and the industrial disputation of the Fraser years. I accept that it has resulted in the Government and the trade union movement working for common objectives. It is worth looking at the effectiveness of the Government's industrial relations policy and comparing it to the disastrous reality of the Fraser Government-the Liberal Party in government during the Fraser years.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us take inflation. The consumer price index to the June quarter 1989 was 7.6 per cent. It was 11.5 per cent in the Fraser Government's last year. The average weekly earnings to May 1989 delivered under this Government's industrial relations policy rose by 7.5 per cent. In the last year of the Fraser Government it was 11.6 per cent. The real unit labour cost index is down 13.9 per cent under Labor with productivity up 1.2 per cent per annum since 1982-83. Under the Hawke Government 1.5 million new jobs have been created, which is a 23.9 per cent increase during its term of office. Conversely, unemployment is down from 10.1 per cent under the Fraser Government in early 1983 to 6.1 per cent now. Again, it is all under Labor's industrial relations policy. Real gross domestic product is up 3.3 per cent in 1988-89. During the period of the Fraser Government the average increase was 2.1 per cent. I suppose the trump statistic, when talking about the Hawke Government's industrial relations policy, shows that industrial disputes are down by a massive 59 per cent under this Labor Government. It appears to me that it is this record of achievement that Senator Lewis is so keen to condemn. The Opposition wants to ignore the pathetic efforts made during the Fraser years but condemns Labor's outstanding record. The facts speak for themselves.

I referred earlier to the Opposition's nervousness in this whole issue. I think this nervousness is fully justified because the Opposition has a real dilemma. It wants to make political capital but it knows that the issue is likely to turn back on it and on its bankrupt industrial relations policy. I have to say that the Opposition is very brave in bringing on this debate and exposing the weakness of its position. In fact, it is pretty obvious that it is the Opposition's industrial relations policy that we are looking at and which is on trial in this dispute, not the Government's. Senator Macklin mentioned the excellent article written by Pamela Williams in the Australian Financial Review yesterday. She said:
The dispute between the airlines and the pilots has been a microcosm of the central planks of the Liberal Party's industrial relations policy--
She went on to say:

Observers waited in vain for the plaudits to fall from the Opposition's lips as the companies acted swiftly on the industrial action, pulled the pilots out of the wage system, sought direct bargaining with individuals and then pressed the pilots towards the courts with lightning speed--

How embarrassing it is for the Opposition to be exposed like this! So-called enterprise bargaining with the right to opt out of the centralised wage fixing system is the central theme of the Liberal and National parties industrial relations policy. What about enterprise bargaining? Is not that just what the pilots have done? The result of it is there for all to see.

It has also been interesting to note Senator Chaney's response to this matter. Far from praising the pilots for following his Party's industrial relations policy, he has criticised them severely for opting out of the system and seems intent on getting them back in. He said in one of his press releases:
The pilots have access to arbitration and yet they thumb their noses at the Industrial Relations Commission when it orders them not to engage in stoppages.

This sounds to me very much like an endorsement of the Industrial Relations Commission and a repudiation of his own policy. It is an admission right from the start that the Liberal Party's industrial relations policy is unworkable.

In the short amount of time that is available to me I would like briefly to look at the merits or otherwise of the pilots claim. I say at the outset that their claim is totally unjustified. The increases that they are asking for equal the annual income of the average Australian worker, and pilots already enjoy very high salaries. As the much quoted Captain Fitzsimons, the former President of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, said in a bulletin to Ansett pilots:
There is no other group of pilots in the world that enjoy your overall standard of pay protection.

It seems to me that the pilots do not seem to have a real understanding of what they could have achieved under the centralised system. They should look at what other aviation industry workers have achieved-that is, up to 12 per cent increases with productivity and work practice concessions. The pilots are being absolutely unreasonable because they want their 29.47 per cent claim granted before any trade-offs are discussed, and, of course, that would then mean there was no longer any need for them to concede anything at all.

In conclusion, what I would like to stress is that this dispute with the airline pilots has demonstrated the bankruptcy of the Opposition's industrial relations policy. I say that the nation cannot afford the wage demands of the airlines pilots and more importantly the nation cannot afford the chaos that would result from the implementation of the Liberal and National parties' industrial relations policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the Government's policy information paper on the national HIV-AIDS strategy and seek leave to make a statement relating to the paper.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, you will recall that just over nine months ago, on 22 November 1988, the Government tabled its discussion paper on AIDS-`A Time To Care, A Time To Act'. That paper presented the wide range of issues and options relevant to the HIV epidemic in Australia as a basis for consultation, discussion and formulation of a national strategy on AIDS for the foreseeable future.

SPEECH.PARA: At that time my colleague, the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), promised the members of this Parliament and the people of Australia that he would return in the 1989-90 Budget context with a clear, broad strategy to guide Australia in the management of AIDS during the next stages of the epidemic, and that the Australian community would have the opportunity to participate in the consultative process. That process is now complete.

The policy information paper presented today sets out the policies and programs which the Federal Government believes are appropriate to deal with the HIV epidemic into the 1990s, as well as the parameters for funding, administering, coordinating and monitoring this country's AIDS programs and activities. The national strategy encompasses complex medical, scientific, economic, legal and moral issues within a framework in which the protection of public health is always paramount.

It has absorbed and reflects a wide range of views obtained from the comprehensive consultation process which involved State governments and authorities, the research community, those who care for people with HIV, the private sector, unions, people with HIV, the Australian National Council on AIDS, the Intergovernmental Committee on Aids, the Australian Federation of AIDS Organisations, the Parliamentary Liaison Group on AIDS, concerned individuals and representatives of many community groups.

The cornerstone of this process was the six working panels which Dr Blewett established early this year to provide a forum for public consultation. Those six panels-which included members and senators from both sides of this Parliament-held 38 meetings and met with 1,800 people from Perth to Cairns, Hobart to Darwin, Alice Springs to Palm Island, and visited prisons in Sydney, Brisbane and Perth. The reports of the panels were published in May this year and, along with the written submissions received, provided a broad-based and bipartisan input to development of the national strategy.

The policy information paper, or White Paper, is not just a document for governments, people with AIDS or those who care for people with AIDS. The policies and programs it contains are designed to reach and influence all members of the community because AIDS has the potential to touch the lives of all Australians. When Dr Blewett addressed parliamentarians on this issue last November, he informed us that 1,100 cases of aids had been reported in Australia, that 538 of those people had died, and that the number of cases continued to mount inexorably.

On every day since then, at least one new case of AIDS has been reported. On almost every day since then, another life has been lost to the disease. As at 9 August 1989, there have been 1,414 cases of AIDS reported in Australia, and 733 of those people have died, nine out of 10 of those Australians who have contracted the disease are or were under 50 years old.

It is a fact, Mr Acting Deputy President, that homosexual or bisexual transmission continues to account for the overwhelming number of AIDS cases in this country, some 88 per cent. However, incidence of the disease among intravenous drug users, including homosexual and bisexual intravenous drug users, has risen to 3.8 per cent and heterosexual transmission has increased to 1.6 per cent of reported cases.

While prevalence of AIDS remains relatively low among these latter groups, the experiences of overseas countries, particularly the United States of America, demonstrate starkly the incipient threat which AIDS continues to pose to the wider community. In the United States, HIV infection is as high as 30 per cent among intravenous drug users and is steadily increasing in the heterosexual community. In New York city, for example, AIDS is the biggest killer of women under 30 years and, tragically, one in 60 babies is born with the virus.

Surveys carried out in Sydney show increasing rates of infection among intravenous drug users from less than one per cent to more than 10 per cent over the past two years. With the estimated number of drug users in Australia ranging from 90,000 to 130,000, the potential for spread through the drug conduit among the heterosexual community is, therefore, inescapably significant. Denial of that threat now would be unwise and ultimately, of course, tragic.

Unfortunately, Mr Acting Deputy President, there are some people in positions of influence within our community who are encouraging others to deny the potential for transmission of the virus among the heterosexual population. Rather than viewing the currently low prevalence of heterosexual infection as an opportunity to modify behaviour pre-emptively, and thus turn good fortune to good management, they choose to use data showing what was happening yesterday as an excuse to deny that a real problem exists today.

It is these same people who seek to undermine Australia's consensual approach to AIDS with allegations that our policies to deal with this epidemic have been hijacked by the homosexual lobby. It was just such divisive and damaging tactics which Johathan Mann, Director of the World Health Organisation's global program on AIDS, spoke about at the fifth international conference on AIDS in Montreal in June. Dr Mann warned that a third epidemic of social, cultural, economic and political reaction and response to AIDS:
. . . in which the twisted bring forward their twisted ideas of massive cover-ups and AIDS conspiracies . . .
He goes on to say that this:
. . . threatens increasingly to overshadow and overwhelm the epidemics of HIV and AIDS themselves.

Dr Mann said that this third epidemic could be as important to our future as the virus itself if complacency, fatalism and marginalisation were allowed to reduce the commitment to or change the course of efforts to protect public health.

The people who peddle these myths about gay conspiracies, who prefer the potentially fatal consequences of denial to the guarded optimism of realism, either fail or refuse to understand that the cooperation of the victims of AIDS-in this country to date, predominantly homosexuals-is essential to our ability to stem the epidemic. We have never disguised the rationale of our efforts to give people with AIDS confidence in the health services of this country through our emphasis on privacy, on confidentiality, on anti-discrimination, on adequate counselling, on opposition to compulsory testing, on endeavours to reduce the stigmatisation associated with AIDS. None of these steps has been taken primarily on the grounds of civil liberties or human rights, but on the grounds of public health.

The Government has always believed that the protection of public health, rather than the preservation of individual rights, must be the overriding concern in developing and implementing AIDS policies; that public health and individual rights march hand in hand on the AIDS issue because the health and well-being of the many is dependent upon the cooperation of the few. In the words of Admiral J. D. Watkins, in his landmark report on AIDS in the United States, effective anti-discrimination protection is, paradoxically, the sine qua non of an effective HIV containment policy. That paradox is possibly the most important thing we have learned about management of the AIDS epidemic since Dr Blewett first addressed the Parliament on AIDS more than four years ago.

We have also learned that history holds no simple truths for combating AIDS, and that there are no easy answers to this awesome health crisis. AIDS is a new disease presenting a unique set of public health problems. But there have been a few shafts of light. We have learned that the overwhelming number of Australians have the strength to resist the temptation to succumb to draconian measures offered as facile and ineffectual `quick-fixes' to the disease and that we possess the individual and collective commonsense and will to take the superficially less attractive, but potentially much more effective decisions demanded by AIDS.

Australia has become internationally acclaimed for its approach to the dilemmas posed by the disease, leading most countries in the world in terms of the development of logical, cohesive and effective containment policies. Our efforts have won praise because, from the beginning of the epidemic, we have taken a cooperative approach involving the development of an unprecedented partnership and level of trust between all levels of Government, all political parties and the affected community groups. The production of this policy information paper is another first for Australia among the developed nations of the world.

The twin goal of Australia's unique national HIV/AIDS strategy is to eliminate transmission of the virus and to minimise the personal and social impact of HIV. It is ambitious and purposely so. The Government believes it would be derelict in its responsibility for the public health of Australians if it were to be anything less. The goal is supported by 10 principles developed to guide the formulation of policy and appropriate program responses. They are that:
1. Transmission of HIV is preventable through changes in individual behaviour; education and prevention programs are necessary to bring about such changes.
2. Each person must accept responsibility for preventing himself becoming infected through sexual intercourse or the sharing of needles and for preventing further transmission of the virus.
3. The community as a whole has the right to appropriate protection against infection.
4. The law should complement and assist education and other public health measures.
5. Public health objectives will be most effectively realised if the cooperation of people with HIV infection and those most at risk is maintained.

6. Specific informed consent should be obtained before any task is performed to diagnose a person's HIV infection status. The result should remain confidential, and appropriate pre- and post-test counselling should be provided.

7. People infected with HIV retain the right to participate in the community without discrimination, and have the same right to comprehensive and appropriate health care, income support and community services as other members of the community.

8. Professional care-givers have a duty to care for infected individuals; governments, employers and unions have a responsibility to provide working conditions and training programs which minimise the risk of occupational transmission.
9. Research into the epidemic is essential to the management of the epidemic.
10. General principles of public health, service provision and the legal system should be applied to the HIV epidemic; special measures or services require justification.

The national strategy has six key elements-education; prevention; treatment, care and counselling; access and participation; research; and international cooperation. It is based on our best scientific knowledge at this time. Obviously, if a cure or vaccine were to become available, or if radically new treatments became available, or if the nature or progression of the virus were to alter significantly, the Government would need to reconsider the appropriateness of the national strategy. The education and prevention strategies outlined in the paper are premised on the basis that transmission of the AIDS virus is preventable and that education remains the most effective means of prevention.

I would like to place on record, specifically for the benefit of people who continue to argue that our AIDS education efforts to date have been improperly targeted to the whole community rather than to people most at risk, that the Government spends approximately $7.50 per head on AIDS education within high-risk groups, compared to approximately 27c per head on AIDS education on the whole community. It will be heartening for all senators to note that major studies indicate a decline in the rate of infection in homosexual men and a significant behavioural change among homosexual and bisexual men. While none of this is reason for complacency, nor any indication that the epidemic has peaked or stabilised, it does indicate that the emphasis we have placed on, and hopes we place in, preventive education are not misplaced.
The education strategy outlined in our policy statement has three broad target groups:
People whose activities place them at greater risk of infection than the general community and those infected;
carers of people with HIV, including professional care-givers; and
the general community.

A new national media campaign will have two specific purposes. First, it will address the specific educational needs of groups which might not be reached through community-based programs, including bisexual men, non-dependent drug users and people of non-English speaking background. Second, the campaign will be used to raise the level of awareness in the general community about modes of transmission and to allay fears and prejudice about the virus. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission will be consulted in developing a public education campaign directed against AIDS-related prejudice and discrimination.

The new Commonwealth AIDS prevention and education-CAPE-program will replace the former existing community education grants to provide funds to community-based organisations which develop nationally relevant prevention and education programs for priority groups identified in the national strategy. Funds will be earmarked for grants to organisations developing programs for Aboriginal and Islander communities, people of non-English speaking background and services for tertiary students. The States will receive substantially increased education and prevention funds to meet State priorities. Some of this matched funding will be tied-for example, the Government is asking the States to ensure that education programs are introduced for prisoners and prison staff, people in residential institutions and their families and carers, homeless young people and children in detention centres, police and other State employees.

Education must start with the young. It is essential that the young people of Australia are aware of the facts about HIV and the risks of transmission and that they are sensitive to the issues which cause prejudice and fear. Accordingly, included in the funding for the States is an amount to be directed to the Curriculum Corporation of Australia, a company owned jointly by the State and Commonwealth Ministers of Education. The Curriculum Corporation will assess and, where necessary, develop HIV-related curricula and provide teaching material for schools. By providing funds for this purpose, the Commonwealth is demonstrating its commitment to providing appropriate public health education to young Australians.

A key issue which was identified by many groups in the consultative process was the need to provide educational opportunities for people in the work force, especially professional care-givers. A Commonwealth AIDS work force, information, standards and exchange-or CAWISE-program has been designed to ensure that the work force has access to information and resource materials, retraining and skills development programs and development of guidelines and standards. Grants will be provided to unions, professional and employee associations and employers. Funds have been earmarked for the development of guidelines on nutrition and HIV infection, a national code of practice for counsellors and a care model for Aboriginal and Islander people.

Another new initiative, HIV study grants, to be cost-shared with the States, will be available to professional care-givers to undertake short term training and development in another State's hospital system. This will particularly give professional care-givers in States with low AIDS caseloads an opportunity to learn on the ground from the experience of their colleagues in States and hospitals with high caseloads.

While education is a key preventative strategy which is critical to elimination of the virus, other prevention strategies require the agreement and cooperation of governments or relate to personal choices. Significant among these issues is testing for the virus. The Government will continue to encourage testing, with the specific informed consent of the individual and with pre- and post-test counselling. Knowledge of one's HIV status provides an opportunity to encourage changes in lifestyle and behaviour and to provide the earliest possible treatment and care. Testing and counselling is already widely available, but could be made more so, and State governments will be asked to improve community access to testing with counselling by expanding the availability through family planning clinics and other community health centres. People whose activities place them at greater risk of infection will be strongly encouraged to fulfil their duty to be tested.

Mr President, there are some situations where the public interest demands that people be prohibited from participation in certain activities unless they accept testing and are found to be negative. Such mandatory testing will continue to apply for donors of blood, tissue, organs and semen. The Government considers compulsory testing to be applicable in only four situations, namely: testing of prisoners on exit from prison; testing of persons charged with a sexual offence where requested by the alleged victim; testing of a person where necessary to determine medical treatment of another person-for example, in providing treatment in the event of a needlestick injury; and testing of a person suspected of being HIV-positive who is placing others at risk of infection. In the last three situations, testing should be implemented as a last resort and should be ordered only by a judge in a closed court.

This also applies in confining an individual who is wilfully or knowingly placing others at risk of infection and who is likely to continue to behave in such a way despite appropriate counselling. Hearings in such cases should be conducted in a closed court with restriction orders given for a fixed period and subject to rights of review and appeal.

Guidelines on the testing of patients for surgical procedures, based on the interim guidelines established by the Australian Health Ministers Conference earlier this year and endorsed by the Australian Medical Association, are set out in the national strategy. In essence, these guidelines state that testing should be encouraged where clinically relevant to the patient or where the patient is believed to be at high risk, and that such testing should be performed only with the patient's consent and with follow-up counselling if the result is positive. The Minister for Community Services and Health and the medical profession are confident that, when patients are advised of the relevance of the test in appropriate clinical situations, the response of patients will be overwhelmingly positive.

Mr President, some of the testing policies I have just outlined are primarily the responsibility of the States and require changes to legislation or, in some instances, new legislative measures. All these issues are to be examined by a subcommittee of the Intergovernmental Committee on AIDS, comprising officers from the departments of Health and Attorney-General, with a view to bringing consensus and uniformity to legislative initiatives arising from the national strategy. Rarely has there been so great a need for uniform policies throughout the nation. The virus does not recognise State boundaries. We should not allow such boundaries to interfere with an effective national response.

Other issues to be covered by the legal review include: legal sanctions which impede the operation of needle and syringe distribution and disposal programs; legal sanctions which might impede the changing of personal use patterns of drugs which are not administered by intravenous methods; and laws which impede public health programs promoting safer sex, especially amongst homosexuals and prostitutes.

In considering the testing of immigrants to Australia, the national strategy makes a distinction between applicants for permanent residence and applicants for temporary residence and tourist or other short-term visas. People who wish to migrate to Australia are currently tested for the virus if there are medical or other indications of infection. The Government has decided that mandatory HIV testing will be introduced for all applicants for permanent residence.

This is unlikely to have a significant impact on the spread of HIV infection, but HIV infection status, as with other medical conditions, is a factor to be considered when assessing applications on the grounds that there are considerable potential costs to the Australian community. But a positive result will not automatically exclude applicants from permanent residency; scope will be retained to approve applications where justified by compassionate or other circumstances.

I have already stressed the importance of avoiding discrimination against people with AIDS, but it remains a fact that many people with HIV, their relatives, friends and carers have faced discrimination. Some have been dismissed from employment, some evicted from accommodation, others refused medical or dental treatment or perhaps harassed by the media. The Government is asking the States to establish, extend or clarify anti-discrimination legislation, to provide redress for people with HIV, their families and carers in basic areas such as employment, education and training, accommodation and supply of goods and services and to prohibit discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation or imputed sexual orientation.

This issue will also be included in the legal review and will seek to ensure that people with HIV are treated fairly and equitably, and on the same basis as people with other life-threatening conditions. As a first step, the Government will bring forward amendments to section 33 of the Public Service Act and regulations under the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Act.

Research is vital to our understanding and knowledge of the AIDS virus and in the search for a vaccine or therapy. Grants for AIDS research have been managed through the Commonwealth AIDS Research Grant Committee, a subcommittee of the Government's AIDS advisory body, the Australian National Council on AIDS, known as ANCA. The two special research units on AIDS virology and AIDS epidemiology and clinical research will be continued under the auspices of ANCA, and the Government has decided to establish a third ANCA special research centre on HIV social research. The new centre will be responsible for coordinating research into the social and psychological effects of the epidemic, identifying further educational and training needs and examining the impact of projects and policy initiatives.

As part of our regional responsibility, Australia will publish results of AIDS research for dissemination within Australia and western Pacific, South East Asian and Indian Ocean nations. A new national clinician-laboratory surveillance scheme will be promoted through the ANCA special research centre for AIDS epidemiology and clinical research to improve the database on HIV infection in Australia.

Some good has already come out of this terrible epidemic in that it has inspired an extraordinary level of international cooperation. Despite the many issues which divide humanity, we have all united in our defence against AIDS. Developed nations are assisting less developed nations to combat the disease, some in the form of financial assistance and others by providing medical and scientific expertise. The Australian Government will provide $1m to the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau to provide help to our regional neighbours for activities such as securing the blood supply and study grants. In addition, Australia, in association with the World Health Organisation, will host a conference on AIDS in Asia and the Pacific in Canberra next August.

Mr President, I have briefly outlined some of the major issues in the national HIV/AIDS strategy. The Government has allocated $318.5m over the next four years to implement the national strategy. In this, the first year, funds of $60.9m have been made available, an increase of 43.6 per cent on the previous financial year. Details of these funds are included in the national strategy document.

In closing, Mr President, on behalf of Dr Blewett, I would like to thank everyone who has been involved in the preparation of the national strategy, particularly those honourable senators from the Opposition parties who gave so generously of their time, and who have ensured that both the spirit and the practice of bipartisanship have been preserved. They have helped to formulate policies which put the public health of Australians above all other considerations, but which recognise the aspirations of all citizens of this country to a dignified and secure way of life to a society which is free of prejudice and to a society which is caring, just and humane. Effectiveness of the national strategy will, of course, depend on cooperation between a wide range of sectors of Australian society, across the three levels of government, between government and non-government sectors, between unions and employers and between all these parties and people infected with the virus.

Mr President, it would be somewhat ingenuous to believe that everyone will agree with all that is in this national strategy. As Dr Blewett said in his speech to the Parliament in November, there will continue to be diversity of opinion between different States, different communities, different organisations and different individuals, and that diversity will be reflected in the range of programs established to respond to the virus. The Government believes that such diversity will continue to assist our national offensive against AIDS, provided it is underpinned by a solidarity of purpose. Solidarity gives us the confidence to face up to the challenge of AIDS and deal openly and honestly with the difficult and controversial issues it presents. I commend the national HIV/AIDS strategy to the Parliament and to the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

The Opposition welcomes this ministerial statement on the acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS). In particular, we welcome the opportunity to indicate our continuation of a bipartisan approach to dealing with Australia's principal public health problem of the moment. In his comments today the shadow Minister for health, Mr Peter Shack, extended his congratulations to the Government for the production of a White Paper. In a statement today, he said that the Opposition offered a continuation of bipartisan support for the AIDS initiatives outlined in the Government's AIDS White Paper which, by and large, endorses the same policy objectives already laid down by the Liberal and National parties in the document on AIDS policy which we published in June this year. Mr Shack went on to deal with a number of matters, one of which I particularly highlight at this stage. In his statement, he said:

However, in view of widespread evidence that IV drug users pose the greatest threat to the infection being transmitted to the wider community it is imperative that the Government pays close attention to the need for extensive research into the development of a foolproof single shot, non-reusable syringe.
Until such time as a suitable device is found, however, we are in accord with the Government's view that IV drug users should have ready access to needle exchange and drug rehabilitation programs.

The overriding goal of any policy on AIDS must be that which we spelt out in our policy, and that is to eliminate the transmission of HIV infection to ensure that no more Australians than is the case now will be affected by the disease.

I wish to return in due course to the question of drug use and intravenous (IV) drug users. As I said, in June this year the Liberal and National parties published their own policy statement on AIDS. I am glad to say that the differences, such as they are, between our policy statement and that which has now been put down by the Government are very minor. They tend to be ones of emphasis and ones of particular specific matters that we want to highlight rather than any substantial disagreement between the political parties on the way in which we as a nation should respond to this epidemic.

As the statement presented by the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) makes clear, a very extensive process of consultation was undertaken in developing this strategy. We saw initially the publication of the so-called Green Paper, a discussion paper entitled AIDS: A Time to Care, a Time to Act. A series of working parties was then established to examine that paper. The Minister indicated the effort that they made. There were some 372 written submissions and responses to the Green Paper; something like 1,800 people at 38 public meetings throughout Australia took part in the consultative process; prisons were visited in three States; and the working parties made contact with people who previously had not been drawn into the process of consultation in the formulation of government policy. I had the great honour to chair one of the working parties, namely that which was responsible for looking at the question of `Testing for HIV Infections'. My distinguished colleague Senator Peter Baume had the responsibility of chairing one of the panels which dealt with the very vexatious question of IV drug users. A number of honourable senators and members of the House of Representatives from both sides of the Parliament participated very actively in the work of these panels.

Some 15,000 Australians are believed to be infected with HIV. The World Health Organisation has estimated that between five million and 10 million people are affected worldwide. There are, however, some significant difficulties in obtaining precise data. There are difficulties in knowing whether the rate of infection is increasing, whether it is stabilising or whether it is declining. Indeed, studies undertaken in Sydney by Professor Cooper and others have indicated that perhaps there is some evidence that the rate of new infections may be declining. At the same time, a report prepared by the National Centre for Epidemiology and Population Health at the Australian National University entitled Predicting the course of AIDS in Australia and evaluating the effects of AZT indicates that the incidence of, and number of people infected with, the virus could still be increasing. We have seen comments by research workers at the Macfarlane Burnet Centre for Medical Research that there are new estimates about the rate of infectivity, that in fact there are changes in the analysis of the time that it takes between initial infection and the onset of clinical symptoms of the disease. For example, in the Melbourne Herald of 21 August it was reported that one of the senior researchers at that centre had said that researchers now suspected that 12 weeks was becoming the normal period between becoming infected with the virus and antibodies being identified by the standard test-the so-called `window' period-and that it appeared that there was a mean time of 9.8 years between being identified as antibody positive and becoming ill. If that is the case, we are talking about up to 10 years before we will be in a position to make a reasonable evaluation of what is happening today. We are now looking at a picture the origins of which may lie 10 years back in history. We simply have no capacity other than best available estimates to know exactly what it is we are dealing with as far as the precise nature of this epidemic is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is still a social premium on non-detection, too.
—My colleague very rightly points out that there is a social premium on the question of non-detection. I hope to have time to refer to that later this evening.

SPEECH.PARA: We also know that there are changes within the population of persons who are infected. We know from quite reliable data that there has been a major change in the behaviour of certain groups in the community. We know from cohort studies that, by and large, the male homosexual groups in Sydney have undergone a quite significant change in their behavioural attitudes. The latest figures reflect a particularly disturbing trend of a 12.4 per cent increase in transmission of AIDS through IV drug use and a 25.6 per cent increase in transmission by vaginal sex in the past 12 months. Again, we are therefore dealing with a permanently shifting series of issues to be addressed. Policy and policy responses need to be sufficiently flexible to cope with those changes as they take place. We know, for example, that there is an increased interest now in the effectiveness or otherwise of azidothymidine (AZT). Governments have to adjust to strategies which determine the most effective use of that drug therapy.

We know that there is an increased interest in alternative methods and alternative ways of dealing with this infection. Trials are being undertaken in Sydney in a program known as the community AIDS trials network. Some of the fast-tracking processes are being put into place which may require us to modify the fairly strict protocols and standards which have otherwise been put in place for drug evaluation. There is a lively debate in the community about the nature of education programs. I want to say something about that later because this is absolutely central to the way in which we will address the challenges of this epidemic in the years ahead. An article in the 22 April 1988 edition of the Journal of the American Medical Association, entitled `Preventing the Heterosexual Spread of AIDS' and written by Hearst and Hulley, raises some questions about the nature of the message being given in terms of addressing the heterosexual community as to whether patients are being given the best advice about the infection and strategies to combat it.

I wish to draw a couple of points from the Minister's tabling statement. I refer particularly to the need to recognise the extent of the problem in Australia. The number of cases has now risen to 1,414 in Australia and 733 of those persons have died, the overwhelming majority being under 50 years of age. As with the United States, we are seeing an increasing problem in terms of intravenous drug users and in terms of the impact that this disease is having on the female population and on the number of children being born either HIV-infected or at risk of contracting HIV infection. The Minister's tabling statement makes it clear that there must be a strategy based upon both education and prevention on the one hand and the necessary investment in research on the other. But the point is made that none of these programs is going to succeed unless there is a sound basis in terms of community support and of voluntary groups in the community playing a significant role in coming to grips with this as a matter of national priority.

Steps have been taken to address the very vexatious questions of the treatment of people in the medical setting and the Minister's statement indicates that the guidelines of testing patients for surgical procedures have been based on the interim guidelines established by the Australian Health Ministers Conference earlier this year and subsequently endorsed by the Australian Medical Association. I endorse that and and I am glad to see that some of the difficulties that have been occasioned in that area are being addressed.

I think it would be wrong, however, not to indicate that not everything in this statement is greeted in a totally uncritical fashion by the Opposition. We have, for example, expressed some disappointment that the base grant budget allocation to the Australian Federation of AIDS Organisations under the excellent chairmanship of Dr David Plummer, which serves as an umbrella for all of the grassroots and community organisations to which I earlier made reference, will remain at only half a million dollars, indexed to the consumer price index until 1992-93. Paragraph 10.5.10 of the report sets out the Government's arguments as far as that is concerned. However, I believe that the Government would have done better to invest more money in support of AFAO and would have got better value for its public health dollar by seeking to put more directly into community organisations and somewhat less into the bureaucratic structures which are now starting to take on a life and a dynamic of their own and perhaps in some respect impose a bureaucratic solution on a problem which is essentially and quintessentially one which is not going to respond to traditional bureaucratic and health department methods of approach. I have some concerns in that regard.

I turn, therefore, to the White Paper itself. The White Paper is useful in that it sets out clearly a set of goals. My colleague Senator Peter Baume has often regaled the Senate with the necessity in such matters as public health policies of setting down clearly the goals, the desired outcomes, of a program. The goal is established in paragraph 3.2.1 of the report, in which it is stated:
Recognising that the human immunodeficiency virus may impinge on the lives of all Australians, the national HIV/AIDS strategy aims
to eliminate transmission of the virus; and
to minimise the personal and social impact of HIV infection.

The White Paper then goes on to set out a series of 10 guiding principles. I will not repeat all of those, as they were encompassed in the Minister's statement a few moments ago, but they involve some of the issues to which I have already referred. First of all, the White Paper states:
Transmission of HIV is preventable through changes in individual behaviour; education and prevention programs are necessary to bring about such changes.

I again make the point about education. I am concerned that we should not allow the education strategies to become entirely monopolised by the bureaucracy and by bureaucratic ways of going about this. The report is quite correct in saying in paragraph 4.1.6:

Programs for specific groups may not be suitable for general consumption, but appropriate information should be available to all Australians regardless of risk status. It is particularly important to maintain awareness when the risk level is perceived to be low for the majority of the community.

That makes the point that some of the AIDS education programs and prevention strategies will need to be specifically targeted to particular groups, whether they happen to be gay men, intravenous drug users, or whoever else. Many people in the community will find those programs offensive, distasteful and disturbing; nevertheless, unless they are specifically targeted in a manner which the target groups understand, respond to and are prepared to encompass in a way which causes them to make behavioural changes, they will not be successful. It is very important, therefore, that the community involvement of which I spoke earlier is quite central to the way in which the Government goes about dealing with this problem. Another of the guiding principles is as follows:
The law should complement and assist education and other public health measures.
Again, that is very important. The report says at paragraph 5.7.11:

Laws regulating and/or penalising homosexual activity and prostitution impede public health programs promoting safer sex to prevent HIV transmission, by driving underground many of the people most at risk of infection.
On page 18 of my own panel report entitled `Testing for HIV/AIDS', the testing panel makes the following recommendation:
The Commonwealth should take a leadership role in relation to the removal of major disincentives to testing including:
Laws which maintain homosexuality, prostitution and the possession of syringes as a criminal offence;
Inadequacy of privacy laws; and
Lack of anti-discrimination laws.

This is one of the recommendations among many from the six testing panels which has found its way though into the White Paper, and I am particularly gratified to see that. The other point I want to draw out from the guiding principles is that which relates to consent for testing, a point to which I will return briefly. The White Paper says, as principle No. 6:

Specific informed consent should be obtained before any test is performed to diagnose a person's HIV infection status. The result should remain confidential, and appropriate pre and post-test counselling should be provided.

That, of course, is absolutely critical. As I said, there is clear evidence that a number of the people perceived to be engaging in high risk behaviour have modified their behaviour and have acted responsibly in so doing. Paragraph 4.2.2. onwards of the report draws attention to the extent to which homosexual men in particular have modified their behaviour, and the report goes on in 4.2.5 to say:
Research conducted by Macquarie University and the AIDS Council of NSW concluded that nearly 80 per cent of homosexual men in that study had modified their behaviour in response to AIDS.
A group which is frequently abused in the public debate, namely sex industry workers, is clearly identified as people who have also modified their behaviour. The report says in paragraph 4.2.19:
Australia has a low prevalence of HIV among sex industry workers.

It indicates the extent to which people in that industry, largely due to peer education, advocacy and support initiatives by sex workers' representative organisations, together with the knowledge of sexually transmitted diseases which many adult sex workers had prior to the HIV epidemic, have played a significant role in that regard.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —The next issue to which I wish to turn relates to the series of points raised in the White Paper about mandatory or compulsory testing of people who are or who might be suspected of being HIV positive. In paragraph 5.2.10 the White Paper indicates two areas in which the Government has determined-in relation to the first, I think, quite properly-that there should be mandatory testing of people to establish the presence of HIV antibodies. This first issue is the question of testing blood products and donated tissue, organs and semen. I think nobody would have the slightest difficulty as far as that is concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the second area in which the Government has determined that there will be mandatory testing is for applicants for permanent residence in Australia. That raises one unanswered question, that is: At whose cost? The White Paper is silent on the question of who has to bear the cost of undertaking these tests. Quite clearly, there will be some circumstances in which the reliability of the tests will be a matter of dispute. I believe there are certain places around the world where the medical standards and, indeed, the incorruptibility of medical practitioners are not necessarily as high as in Australia and in most of the countries from which we will be drawing applications for permanent residence. I hope the Government will look very carefully at the questions of the validation of the results, of the integrity of the tests, and of who bears the cost of undertaking these tests. The Opposition does not, in any sense, object to the principle that there should be mandatory testing for permanent residence. In fact, that is comprehended in the policy document which the Liberal and National parties have already published. I make the point that the Government quite clearly and properly concedes that a positive test result will not, in itself, automatically disqualify an applicant from being granted permanent resident status where it is believed that there are overwhelming compassionate or other compelling grounds which should allow the applicant, nevertheless, to come to Australia.

The next point about testing is that all testing should be accompanied by appropriate pre-test and post-test counselling, especially where people have been encouraged to undertake the test voluntarily. Again, that is not only entirely proper but also consistent with the policy that the Opposition has laid down, and is entirely consistent with the recommendations which the testing panel made to the Government through the consultative process about which I have already spoken.

However, there are a number of other circumstances in which the Government is proposing that there should be some system of compulsory testing. In a number of those circumstances-and I do not have the time this evening to go through them all in detail-it is proposed that those tests shall be undertaken in circumstances in which an application may be made to a judge, and a judge, in closed session, will be able to determine whether a compulsory test should be conducted. Those circumstances include the testing of persons charged with a sexual offence, where the request is made by the alleged victim; the testing of a person, where necessary, to determine the medical treatment of another person-and the example given here, which I think is somewhat tendentious but which I do not have time to discuss this evening, is providing treatment in the event of a needle-stick injury; and, finally, testing of a person suspected of being HIV positive who is placing others at risk of infection. In those situations the application will have to be made to a judge who will hear it in closed court and make a determination. As far as the testing of persons suspected of being HIV positive is concerned, we presume this means suspected under the aegis of the public health laws of the States concerned. I would certainly be extremely concerned if it were to be assumed that a person might be suspected of being HIV positive by, for example, a policeman or a law enforcement officer and, on the basis of that person's suspicion, dragged before a judge to be potentially tested for the presence of the AIDS antibodies. I hope that will be clarified quickly by the States.

The one area where it is quite clear that there will be testing in a fully compulsory sense is in terms of the testing of prisoners on their exit from prison. I might say that, on this occasion, this actually runs contrary to the specific recommendation made by the testing panel. When it looked at this particular matter the panel which I chaired did not favour the compulsory testing of the entire prison population, nor any system of compulsory testing in terms of the point of exist from prison. A couple of points need to be made. The first is that presumably this testing will be done not at the very point of exit but at a reasonable time in advance of exit so that the window period problem can be addressed. Secondly, there will be a major legal problem arising with a system whereby some States test prisoners on entry to the prison system, if they are negative at that stage, and, when they leave the prison system, they are tested again and found to be positive. The question arises of what their redress is against the State if they claim that they have become antibody positive as a result of the negligence of the State in relation to such questions as homosexual rape within the prison system. These points raise some very significant questions.

The final points which I want to make in relation to this matter before I conclude are these: the report is properly very positive about the approach that needs to be taken as a matter of urgency to deal with the question of intravenous drug users. My colleague Senator Peter Baume has made a number of comments about this, and his panel's report ought to be read by everybody who is interested in an understanding of this problem. There are something in the order of 130,000 drug users in Australia. Most of those are so-called recreational users who, from time to time only, share needles. In many respects, these people are more at risk than the people who are regarded by the community as hard-core regular intravenous drug users. Programs need to be properly designed to deal with the circumstances in which these people find themselves. That is terribly important.

The question of the spread of AIDS into the wider community through intravenous drug use is so poorly understood at the moment that it really requires the Government to make this a major focus for its attention. The whole question of the Government's drug strategy needs to be thoroughly re-examined. I do not think it is working. I do not think it can work on the premises that have been laid down at the moment. Yet, if it is not addressed quickly, it will become the major problem before we are capable of responding to it. I raise that as a critical issue.

The final point I want to make is this: underpinning all of this strategy will be the need for effective antidiscrimination legislation throughout this country. Admiral Watkins submitted his report entitled Report of The Presidential Commission on the Human Immunodeficiency Virus Epidemic to the President of the United States of America on 24 June 1988. That is a most important document because it identifies clearly the necessity to have in place legal protection and legal regimes regarding the question of anti-discrimination policies to underpin the degree of voluntary cooperation and consent which is necessary to get people to support government strategies in this regard.

We have not had the time this evening to examine the question of AZT, how its use is to be funded, how it is to be provided, and what indeed are the critical therapeutic and social science issues arising as far as that is concerned. I therefore conclude on this point: changing the behaviour of people is absolutely fundamental to getting the AIDS strategy right. Behavioural change is a question of social arrangements and social attitudes. It is incumbent upon the Parliament, the Government, the Opposition-all political parties-to work together to bring about the climate of changes in social attitudes which will allow people to cooperate, to participate and to make their contributions to dealing with the AIDS epidemic in Australia. That is the challenge which faces us all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Puplick for his penultimate point and for the point he made immediately before the penultimate point, namely, that the intravenous (IV) drug user is one point on which a great deal more attention needs to be placed. I want to return heavily to that in the remarks that I want to make. Secondly, while he did not quite put it in these terms, I think he was saying in his penultimate point that the emphasis in the treatment of AIDS and in relation to intravenous drug use must be seen in relation to those factors as threats to the public health. We need to get that clearly into focus and attempt to put aside questions of morality and of judgment and the other social and judgmental-type matters which are often raised with respect to both these questions. I think that is a point that needs a great deal of emphasis.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I seriously begin, though, I noticed that Senator Puplick used the term `needlestick injury'. Could I just make a minor point: I personally object to the invention and the introduction of totally unnecessary new words into the English language. When somebody gets stabbed with a knife we do not talk about a knifestick injury, or when they get stabbed with a sword we do not talk about a swordstick injury. I do not know why we talk about a needlestick injury. Why not a needle injury? I hope that one can adopt that use instead of putting another unnecessary word into the language.

Of course, AIDS is indeed a very serious threat to the public health, and I believe the seriousness of that threat is not properly realised either by the public or indeed by many politicians. Honourable senators will recall that last year I raised as an urgency debate the matter of the provision of intravenous drugs under controlled conditions to intravenous users, specifically with the idea of controlling the spread of AIDS in the community. In the course of that debate Senator Knowles labelled that proposition as grossly premature. I was interested to note that, within several weeks of that debate, in which both the Government and the Opposition voted against my urgency motion, Mr Shack, the Opposition shadow Minister for health, was in fact making exactly the same point-that this really was the way to go with respect to the control of the spread of AIDS. In the same debate Senator Rosemary Crowley said:
any prospect of moving towards what is proposed in Senator Coulter's motion is down the line. It is being considered only as a prospect for a pilot study.
Earlier in her remarks she had said:
I wonder whether this really is a matter of urgency.

So I reflect on some of my colleagues, because I think they are not, even so, recognising the great seriousness of this threat to the community posed by AIDS. I believe that, if we fail to understand and respond appropriately to this rapid increase in the numbers of HIV-positive people and people with frank AIDS, the consequences will be serious indeed.

The Minister for Resources (Senator Cook), in his statement points out that, while 88 per cent of AIDS cases are accounted for in the homosexual or bisexual community, 3.8 per cent are present in the intravenous drug users and 1.6 per cent already are among the heterosexual community. Going on from that, the Minister drew attention to the fact that in the United States the HIV infection is as high as 30 per cent among intravenous drug users and is steadily increasing in the heterosexual community. In New York City, for example, the Minister said, AIDS is the biggest killer of women under 30 years of age and tragically one in 60 babies is born with the virus.

The HIV virus has emerged very recently as a human pathogen. Since its first detection the number of infected people has increased rapidly. The acquired immune deficiency syndrome was first reported in the United States in 1981, only eight years ago. One case was reported in Australia in 1982. That person is now dead. Six were reported in 1983. All are now dead. Forty-two cases were reported in 1984, of whom 41 are now dead; 113 in 1985-96 now dead; 224 in 1986-174 dead; and 345 in 1987, with 160 already dead. Picking up on the Minister's figures again, he points out that by late 1988 there were 1,100 cases-that is the totally integrated number over all time-of whom 538 have already died. By August this year there were 1,414 cases, with 733 dead-52 per cent in all.

Of course, the point is often made that, notwithstanding those numbers we know about, the numbers infected and not yet showing signs or symptoms are probably much larger, and it is suggested that that number may be perhaps 20 to 30 times larger than the number showing symptoms; that is, the number of HIV-positive people in Australia probably already lies between some 10,000 and 40,000 people. It has been suggested in a number of papers that all those who are HIV-positive will sooner or later develop AIDS and that, of those 1,414 who have developed AIDS in Australia and the 733 who have already died, 90 per cent of those diagnosed in 1985 and 98 per cent of those diagnosed in 1984 are now dead. I repeat again that 52 per cent of all those diagnosed have already died.

So far in Australia most of the cases and most of the transmission have been in homosexual men. This is the first phase of the infection. The HIV virus is spread very effectively through unsterilised needles, and we know that for a fact. The virus has not got a natural predilection for men. In fact, in some papers it is suggested that, if anything, women are probably more prone to acquire the infection after being exposed than men are. So through the intravenous drug route the virus is being spread to the female and then into the heterosexual male population.

Infection of IV drug users is the second phase that is now developing. It has already been developed in the United States, and this phase will provide the link to the heterosexual community, thence to women, and thence to the unborn. The difficulty I have with the Minister's statement is that, while it deals well with questions of research and of overcoming problems of discrimination against those people who are infected and problems of education to prevent infection, it does not really seriously address this problem of closing the window of infection through the intravenous drug user. It is this IV drug link which must be broken. Again I stress the figures from America. In the Minister's statement we find that the number of infected people in Sydney has increased. The Minister says that the numbers have increased from one per cent to 10 per cent of intravenous drug users in the past two years. In other words, we have already seen a substantial increase in that group of people and it will be the link between the homosexual group and the heterosexual group, the more general community.

It is important to stress something about the HI virus because the Minister picks up the vain hope that some type of a vaccine is likely to be developed. The HI virus is an RNA virus. Most cells have DNA in their genetic library. DNA is reproduced by cells with a very high degree of genetic reliability, the sequence integrity is very highly preserved. When an RNA virus gets into a cell it must back-translate the RNA into DNA. It uses an enzyme called reverse transcriptase to do that. Reverse transcriptase is notoriously error prone. It makes a great deal of errors when it is translating the RNA into DNA. These RNA viruses are extremely subject to mutation. For that reason it is extremely likely that the virus will present itself in a great number of different forms. The possibility of preparing a vaccine against it is certainly as difficult, if not more difficult, than the problem of preparing vaccines against the flu virus, another virus which is notoriously mutable.

A single patient has been found with as many as three different strains of the AIDS virus. The virus has almost certainly mutated so quickly that those strains have derived from the one strain within the single patient. It is possible-I stress this-to imagine that the AIDS virus could mutate to a form which could be transmitted by non-sexual means. We need to think about that and recognise that this virus is so mutable that it is one which presents an enormously potential threat to the community-one which needs to be taken a lot more seriously than we have taken it.

Last November I moved a matter of urgency in this place calling for the Federal Government to provide intravenous drug users with their drugs of addiction in ways which did not involve the sharing of needles and the consequent risk of spreading the AIDS virus. I then argued that this would have a number of other benefits both for the drug user and for the community as a whole. We must think about drug addiction and the spread of AIDS essentially as public health problems. We must put aside questions of judgment and morality. We must think of addicts as people needing help and not as criminals to be punished. We must think of a society in which more people are turning to drugs as a sick society needing treatment and not one merely needing more gaols and stricter penalties for the victims of its social and economic ills. We must conceptualise the drug addiction-AIDS situation as a medical problem, not as a criminal one.

A survey conducted last year showed that 5 per cent of adult Australians, or 80,000 people, had injected drugs at some stage of their lives and 2 per cent, or 30,000 people, has done so within the last 12 months. Both the Minister and Senator Puplick mentioned the figure of 130,000 possible drug addicts Australia-wide. Intravenous drug use ranges from the once only experiment to the occasional user through to those who may inject themselves as many as eight times a day. Thus we are not just talking about drug addicts. The majority of drug users are occasional users. While drugs remain illegal, these occasional users are most likely to obtain their drugs through sharing with those who are more regular users. It is estimated that some 3 to 5 per cent of homosexual-bisexual men are intravenous drug users. Sharing needles is a much more effective way of transmitting the HI virus than either homosexual or heterosexual intercourse.

There are a number of causes of death among intravenous drug users. The most common of all will soon be AIDS. Only about 2 per cent of IV drug users died each year from their drug use-that is, pre-AIDS. In New York 20 to 30 per cent of intravenous drug users will develop AIDS within five years and will then live, on average, for one year. The greatest risk to the IV drug user is not the drug but the risk of getting AIDS. The greatest health risk posed to the community by the IV drug user is the risk of spreading AIDS. AIDS also places on the community a large and growing financial burden. There is no cure. Nursing care and hospitalisation are expensive. The only treatments are palliative not curative. AZT presently costs about $10,000 a year per patient. The 1988 cost of treating and caring for the 500 or so then living AIDS victims including other treatment costs and the associated AIDS dedicated expenditure by the Commonwealth was estimated to be approaching $50m. If no effective action is taken now this figure is likely to amount to $1 billion by 1993. I reflect on the Minister's statement which says that the number of IV drug users in Sydney has mounted very rapidly from one per cent to 10 per cent in as little as two years. If money to address this problem is not found the quality of care will deteriorate and our efforts to control the further spread of AIDS will falter. By that time it will be too late. We are already losing too much time in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did the figure of 10 out of 100 New South Wales residents come from?

—This is the figure the Minister gives on page five of his statement. He says that one per cent of the AIDS cases were intravenous drug users and that figure has risen to 10 per cent in the last two years. The statement says:

SPEECH.PARA: Surveys carried out in Sydney show increasing rates of infection among intravenous drug users from less than one per cent to more than 10 per cent over the past two years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ten per cent of infected people.

—We have a larger population in absolute terms that is infected and we have a larger proportion of that population in the IV drug user category. The numbers are going up quite rapidly. We have a very short period in which to make an attack on this disease. I believe that the Minister's statement does not properly address this question of the spread of AIDS through the IV drug user. There is not sufficient emphasis placed on that point. The way to proceed is to make IV drugs available in suitable places, in suitable facilities. The facilities may be stationary or mobile, clean and non-threatening, friendly and non-judgmental. This extends the concept of needle exchange for drug addicts.
—For drug users.

—Yes. Preferably the drugs would be used in these facilities and would not leave these places or as second best-this was hinted at by the Minister-drugs could be provided in non-reusable, single dose syringes. I prefer that they would be either self-administered or administered to the drug user on the site so that the drugs would not leave that place. Other advantages flow from that proposition. If these facilities could be set up in non-threatening and non-judgmental ways information, counselling and all the other services which these people need could be provided both with respect to their drug addiction and with respect to the risk which they face from taking drugs on the street. Many more intravenous drug users are also likely to turn to oral substitutes, such as methadone, because it would bring them into contact with these alternatives. In New South Wales, some 3,800 people are already in a methadone program. The demand exceeds the number of places. Only in Queensland has the methadone program managed to meet the demand. Clearly, the methadone part of a treatment regimen needs to be greatly increased, as under the proposal which I put forward last year and which I repeat now, it is expected that many more people would seek methadone as a substitute for intravenous drugs. These facilities would provide the sorts of education that the Minister talked about. They would be places where people would come face to face with the ability to get information about drug addiction and about AIDS.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Health and Medical Research Council has suggested a limited provision of intravenous drugs as an experiment. This does not seem to get a mention in the Minister's statement. But I believe-and I pointed out last year-that a trial in only one area would not succeed because that area would attract intravenous drug users from other areas. It would appear that, in keeping the data on such a trial, one had produced an increase in drug addiction. I believe that nothing less than a national trial over a reasonable number of years is necessary to prove the efficacy of such a proposal. This would provide an alternative source of drugs and would tend to reduce the illegal supply of drugs and all the other costly associated problems.

Drug use and addiction, I believe, must come to be viewed as a medical social phenomenon requiring medical and social management, not criminal sanctions. There is good reason to believe that the same cultural restraints that prevent the majority of us from becoming alcoholics, despite a ready availability of alcohol, would also operate to control the use of intravenous drugs if the Government accepted a proposal that intravenous drugs be supplied, under the conditions I have outlined, to intravenous drug users.

Society faces a large, rapidly growing and deadly threat from the AIDS virus, a threat which I believe, even in the Minister's statement, is underestimated. The doorway through which the virus is passing into the general community is the intravenous drug user. We must close that door now. The only way that is practically available to us is the safe, controlled provision of injectable drugs by the state. The Minister's statement talks about research. It is good to see an emphasis on a research program, particularly one directed to HIV social research and the factors which lead to the spread of this virus. The Minister's statement talks about education. Of course, education is important. The statement talks about anti-discrimination. That is also important.

The Australian Democrats support these initiatives, but they are not enough. They are less than 50 per cent of what needs to be done. They do not tackle the window through which AIDS is spreading into the heterosexual and wider community. Shall we continue to wring our hands in inactivity in this area while we collect a perfect set of statistics confirming the spread of a virus that we can now so accurately predict?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to welcome the Government's national HIV/AIDS strategy and to speak in support of the motion to take note of the Minister's statement. It is a pleasure to welcome what is a powerful, sensitive, relevant and timely paper. It has been pointed out by previous speakers that the document is not perfect, and neither it is. It is not perfect. But it represents a great advance on anything available to us previously; it represents a great advance on anything available within any State jurisdiction; and it is a worthy development from the Green Paper, which was produced 10 months ago or thereabouts, called AIDS: A Time to Care, A Time to Act. This document does provide a basis, it does provide a blueprint for action, it does identify goals, it does identify programs and it does identify desirable outcomes. For all those things we should be very grateful.

SPEECH.PARA: May I declare a couple of interests. I enter the debate having chaired a working panel on intravenous drug use. I was interested to hear the comments of Senator Coulter. They were very brave. I think honourable senators may not have understood just how radical and how right his suggestions were.
