As I have said, I was chairman of that working panel on intravenous drug use and HIV/AIDS. I advise honourable senators of that because they may wish to discount some of what I say now. Further, I have a small business interest which involves me advising people on HIV/AIDS, and I want my colleagues to know about that.

I am a member of the Parliamentary liaison group and I am a consultant for the World Health Organisation. I have consulted in several Pacific countries. When I consulted in Papua New Guinea last year it became apparent very quickly that it had no secure blood supply. It is to the credit of Australia and the Minister for Health, as he then was, I think, that within days after having brought the report back, a senior official was in Port Moresby working to help our neighbours secure their blood transfusion supply.

Some people would like to respond to the epidemic that faces us by denial and avoidance. But that is like living in a house on a ridge and seeing black smoke bellow out of the valley, seeing sparks around you but not wanting to face the fact that there is a fire somewhere. It simply will not do. Avoidance will not work as a strategy. Yet many people in the community still want to use avoidance. They want to say, `We won't be infected, and those near and dear to us won't be affected. So let us assume it is the result of things that are done by people we do not like, doing things we do not approve of and let us respond with punishment, with quarantine and with isolation'.

The working panel which I chaired had public meetings all around Australia. We had one public meeting in Cairns at which a professionally qualified gentleman, a veterinarian, came before us and said, `In veterinary science we have a simple rule. We cull and shoot'. That was his going-in position as to how we should deal with HIV infection. It will not do. It will not work for reasons which colleagues have pointed out. It simply is not an option. It is like saying that we will pretend that homelessness among youth does not exist. It is like saying that we will ignore the fact or that we will pretend that we do not understand why between 7 and 10 per cent of all male Australians are homosexuals.

Some people will say `Let us just ignore it. It is an inconvenient fact'. Such an approval will not work. It is to the credit of the Government that its approach to this problem has not been to go down that route. It has not tried avoidance. Neither has it tried denial, pretending that there is no problem, pretending that we can just close our eyes and that it will all go away-because it will not. Neither has the Government gone down the road of saying, `What we simply need is harsher social control, a whole range of social control policies; more punishment, more rules, more regulations, or to find an island off the coast of Australia and send people there'. That was put to the committee. I said to the witnesses, `What happens if I am a member of a close knit family and I turn out to be infected?'. They said, `That's tough'. That kind of policy will not work. Within the document a number of quite difficult issues are addressed, and are addressed well.

I would like to spend a few moments saying something about intravenous drug use. It has been referred to by earlier speakers. The pattern of intravenous drug use is well described and has been well reported by other honourable senators. The stereotypes of intravenous drug use are simply wrong. If we make policies based on these stereotypes they will continue to be as ineffective as all our policies on intravenous drug use have been over as many years as we have been making them. I remind honourable senators that one of the leading psychiatrists in Australia, an exciting person, John Ellard-the doyen of Australian psychiatry-published a book of essays last week with the rather intriguing title Some Rules for Killing People. The title was taken from one of the essays which dealt with capital punishment in Australia. Another essay on drugs and imprisonment addressed the question of the use of narcotics and other injectable substances.

Ellard makes the point that the model we have chosen to use in this country traditionally, a model of prohibition and punishment, has never worked, is not working now, and will never work. He asks the question: What goals are we seeking to achieve with such a program? If the goal is to punish wicked people, he says that is fair enough. If, however, the goal is to avoid some of the adverse effects of intravenous drug use, the present policies do not work. If the goal is to prevent the use of these substances, the present policies do not work. If the goal is to prevent some of the harm that will flow from intravenous drug use, of which HIV infection is now the latest and most awful evidence of harm, these present policies will not work. If they will not work, why do we stick to them? Senator Coulter is quite right to ask that question and, in his own way, to say that the policies will not work and that they need to be changed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be a novel experience for Senator Coulter to be quite right.

—Senator Coulter was quite right. The working panel on which I served made a number of recommendations designed to have us re-examine some of the ways in which we do things in this country in relation to drug use. We did not go as far as Senator Coulter and some of our recommendations have been rather cautiously included in this statement. I hope they are taken up. For example, the laws of some of the States put in jeopardy those people who are trying to run needle exchange programs. What do we think we are doing? If needle exchange will reduce the spread of the virus, people engaged in those programs should not be put at risk of arrest, yet the current laws put them at that risk. There are some States where the current laws make it difficult for people to use methadone. If methadone, given orally, can lead people to use fewer injectable drugs, that may help us avoid the spread of the virus, and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: Ellard in his excellent book draws attention to the situation in our prisons in Australia. If we had sought to design a system to facilitate the spread of the virus our prisons are that. Approximately 50 per cent of our prisoners are there for drug related matters. The percentage of prisoners who use drugs is very high and because of the laws of supply and demand, of which my market orientated friends remind me occasionally, it is not surprising that injectables get into prisons. All that happens is that a price is put on them. They get into prisons and they are available.

We were given evidence on the working panel that at one time there was so much injectable material in Pentridge Gaol that some of it was exported back to the streets of St Kilda for sale. Our prisons are awash with this material. The only thing the prisoners do not have is injecting equipment. We had evidence that up to 70 people share one needle and syringe. We have already heard that there is no more effective way to spread the virus than blood to blood spread. If miserable people are put into our prisons with a drug habit-people who share equipment while in those prisons-it is very likely that they will come out with the virus. Is that what we want to do? I hope it is not. It will not do just to insist that our prisons will be drug free, because they are not. One of the points that Dr Ellard makes in his book is that those prisoners who have used opiates are generally stuporose and are no trouble. The trouble comes from those who have been able to get some vegemite, or some other yeast containing compound, to make themselves alcohol inside the prisons which, of course, is quite easy to do. They become argumentative and obstreperous, and they tend to fight.

I make the point that the question of intravenous drug use is not just an isolated issue which a few funny people in the community think we are getting wrong. It is now a matter of vital and immediate concern to Australia as a society. If we get this one wrong we could end up like New York city where the majority of intravenous drug users are now infected with this virus, where there will be tens of thousands of people dying a horrible death from this disease, and where the laws of New York State make it certain, make it unavoidable, that the infections will continue to spread. What is required is law reform. What is required is a new look at the social arrangements we have for controlling intravenous drug use and for managing this problem. If I have any criticism of this document-and it is a very small one-it is that it is a little tentative in taking what I think are necessary and radical steps in this particular area.

Another matter that worries me is that I think we are using denial in another way. I fear that we are scared of being labelled racists. I fear that many of us are underestimating the terrible risk that may face our indigenous population. I fear that because of associated health problems and some of the living conditions which people face, the risk of spread may be greater than is generally acknowledged.

I was attracted to an article in the Brisbane Sun of 17 August in which the hospital superintendent from Thursday Island, Dr Peter Holt, expressed his fear that AIDS may sweep through his Torres Strait community in the coming decades for a variety of reasons which have to do with underlying health, with the present incidence of sexually transmitted diseases, with poverty and with many other factors. I would hate to see us unwilling to say what is happening because of undue sensitivity-that certain of our Aboriginal and Islander colleagues may find it difficult to accept certain things. Finally, we are denying the likelihood of the spread of the virus into the heterosexual community. Of course, the illness has been mainly a male homosexual illness in its first wave. No-one denies that, but it is not a disease--

TALK.START.PARA: —It has not been denied by any government program.

—It is not denied by anyone, Senator Stone. The disease is not produced by male homosexuality. It is produced by certain activities, by certain behaviours. Honourable senators would be aware that in a survey taken in Brisbane not so long ago, 16 per cent of women reported by questionnaire that they had had anal intercourse, that they had been part of an act of anal intercourse.
—Who did that survey?

—It is reported in the Green Paper. I can get the reference for the honourable senator. It was also reported that 4 per cent had had that experience fairly recently. All that says is that there are groups within our society with particular cultural behavioural patterns. It is the behaviour that is dangerous, not the group to which one is said to belong.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many unresolved problems remaining before us in this attempt to manage, control and minimise the dreadful epidemic that lies ahead. There are problems which are technical and I do not care to try to comment on the whole range of technical matters. We are aware that there are technical problems, some of which we are overcoming. There are problems of confidentiality and I think this may be the major unresolved problem in Australian society. I used to work in a large public hospital. I knew the rules for confidentiality and so do we all. If someone came in with an interesting illness, on a bad day it might take 30 minutes for the information to get right around the hospital. So much for confidentiality!

It may be impossible, in spite of all the rules that are made, to preserve the rights of individual citizens. For example, if for perfectly good reasons we require testing of certain people, and if they are then found to be positive, I want to know that our large institutions will not only carry out proper cross-infection control but also will try to preserve the civil rights of those citizens. Otherwise, they are likely to be made scapegoats or discriminated against. At the present time our social arrangements are such that there is great danger in allowing anyone to know that one is HIV-positive. No-one here is unaware of the little girl who lived at Erina out of Gosford. Little Eve was found to be HIV-positive and so as a result of that information she had to leave her preschool, her family had to leave their home, her father had to leave his job and in the end the family had to leave Australia. Confidentiality is a major issue. Confidentiality is one of the major issues to be addressed in respect of employment and solutions have to be found.

It is a question of a balance of rights. Again, if put my doctor's hat on, some of the concerns of the medical profession are not unreasonable. There are concerns about dangers in treating people who might give one a fatal illness. There are good reasons for wanting to test people in hospital before surgery is undertaken. The treatment that I offer to a person may be affected by certain knowledge. If I know that someone's immune system is damaged, I may want to vary the treatment I give him. I may wish to avoid certain treatment. I may wish to advise him differently. So there are actual benefits for the person. But this question of balance of rights is still before us and has to be argued through.

I want a policy that will be effective in achieving the goals which have been identified in the paper. I agree with Senator Puplick that there are goals which we need to accept as desirable outcomes. Our goal is to prevent new infections. If we can do that, we will have gone a long way. The way to avoid new infections is to seek to encourage people to change their behaviour. Another goal is to minimise the adverse effects on those already infected; we can seek to do that as well. I do not mind if the Government says it will now test all intending migrants. The White Paper makes it clear that that is done at least in part as a matter of cost containment. That is okay; that is the right of government. I do not mind if we determine to test all prisoners. But I agree with Senator Puplick that we should test people not only on exit but on entry to prisons. A person should be able to say to the States who incarcerate them, under social arrangements which we support, `If I go into that prison free of infection and come out infected, I will sue the State for its failure to exercise its duty of care'. The parents of young Jamie Partlic are now suing the State of New South Wales-quite properly-for what happened to their boy when he was bashed in Long Bay gaol. The question of duty of care is one which our State prison authorities are going to have to address and which we as a Commonwealth are going to have to consider because there are Commonwealth prisoners in State prison systems.

I do not want an HIV-AIDS policy that works on the principle of allocating blame, of making certain groups, scapegoats or of attaching bad motives to some of those who are infected or might be infected. I am not really interested in people's power games-people who have come into the public debate with an agenda that has to do with whether or not they will be able to attract and control more resources. Of course, some of the players do give that impression. I want to see those who are infected supported properly. I want to see the Commonwealth go down the road it has outlined and seek to cooperate with others, particularly with the State governments who have so many of the day to day management decisions to make. I want this policy to work.

The crisis is so great that if we do not master this disease now it will decimate our society. I know that even if no new infections occur-and that is an impossible ideal-things will become very much worse over the next 10 years in terms of people already infected. The Opposition policy released last June, which was set out and described by Senator Puplick, fits well with this Government policy. I believe that we have a multi-partisan political approach to this illness. I hope that the policies go well together but I hope most of all that we can make them work effectively.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have always considered that the tragic death toll and suffering caused by the acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) in Australia requires absolute frankness and commitment to the truth. There is a great need in the educational arena to tell the facts of life and that ought to be at the basis of Government policy. I am not intimidated by people who might suggest that I am being judgmental or that I make moral judgments. Those who know me would know that this allegation is completely untrue. Most of them would be aware of my strongly held view that no human being has a right to judge the interior disposition of another and that AIDS sufferers are entitled to our unconditional care and support.

SPEECH.PARA: As for making moral decisions-and I think Senator Coulter was quite wrong-we have to make moral decisions. We are required on the basis of the threat which this disease is posing to the national health to do what is best. If choosing what is best done and what is best avoided is a moral decision, then I am happy, and everybody else ought to be happy, to be accused of making a moral decision. What is a moral decision but to choose what is better or best? We all have a responsibility to work for the care of AIDS sufferers, for the prevention of the disease and for the creation of a social atmosphere which will avoid the spread of the disease.

I have had some other pressing matters to attend to today, as no doubt other senators have, and I am not in a position to deal with all of the paper. The AIDS White Paper contains some very welcome initiatives, but it has aspects which I consider will entrench the very sexual promiscuity which is a major cause of the spread of AIDS. I refer to the latest epidemiological figures. In regard to the relating to the transmission categories of known cases of AIDS, homosexual-bisexual transmission represents 88.4 per cent of the total; transmission through IV drug use, 1.1 per cent; through homosexual-bisexual IV drug use, 2.7 per cent; through blood transfusions, 3.9 per cent; in haemophilia cases, 1.1 per cent; heterosexual transmission, 1.6 per cent; causes under investigation, 0.4 per cent; and none of the above, 0.8 per cent. These figures clearly reveal that of all AIDS cases in Australia 91 per cent have a homosexual cause. That is a fact that one must acknowledge and deal with. The question is whether the educational strategies are dealing with this. There is a trend in some surveys relating to IV drug users. One survey suggested that there are a large number of IV drug users at risk, but such surveys are inadequate. Nevertheless, we should address those problems.

I raise a number of issues concerning the White Paper, particularly in regard to the educational strategy, which is directed towards three groups-people whose activities place them at a greater risk of infection than the general community and those infected; carers of people with HIV, including professional care-givers; and the general community. Chapter 4, paragraph 4.2.1, which concerns education for the general community, says:

Education for the general community will explain the facts of transmission of HIV, address fears and misconceptions and stress the need for men and women to take responsibility for safer sexual practices and other behaviour which may lead to infection.
The stress will be on the need for men and women to take responsibility for safer sexual practices. On page 42 `Safer Sex Practices' are explained. It is stated at paragraph 5.3.1:
The promotion of safer sex practices as a preventive measure has been integral to the general community education campaign. Safer sex practices include:
sexual activity not involving intercourse; or
the proper use of condoms during intercourse.

It goes on to explain what the first point means. Honourable senators ought to read that paragraph on page 42 as an indication of what we are likely to expect from the Government's AIDS education campaign over television and radio stations. The whole push is going to relate to safer sex practices. Any policy that addresses the problem of sexually transmitted AIDS without warning against promiscuous behaviour and which implies to young people that homosexual acts are just another way of life is deceptive and will create the climate for the continued spread of AIDS in the future. The White Paper states on page 31:
Sexually active young people
4.2.15 The key messages to be conveyed to young people in relation to their sexual activity are that risk can be eliminated through:
abstinence from sexual activity;
sexual activity only within a mutually monogamous relationship with an uninfected partner; or
safer sex practices.
The first two options are important and valid for many in our society. However, there is a need to be realistic about the behaviour of young people, and their freedom within the law.

Mention of the first two matters was made in the Minister's original statement to the Parliament, but those matters have not really been stressed in any of the education campaigns thus far. Indeed, the Government is now talking about being realistic. I am particularly concerned that, in the interests of what the White Paper calls `realistic' education, our youth will end up receiving a message that they can do what they like whenever they like and with whom they like provided they use a condom. This would have devastating and deadly results. It would attack the efforts made by parents to ensure that their children lead mature and flourishing lives. At paragraph 4.2.17 on page 32, the White Paper says:

The States can contribute to the education of young people by using curricula for schools which are honest, explicit and comprehensive about the options available for preventing HIV infection and about the care and treatment of HIV-infected students. The Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) will arrange for assessment of the curriculum, and development of teaching materials for teachers and students through the Curriculum Corporation of Australia, a jointly-owned company formed by the Commonwealth and State Ministers of Education. The curricula will be developed further as necessary. DEET, in conjunction with DCSH, will report an implementation of HIV-related curricula in schools. The States should ensure that HIV-related education is provided at the appropriate school level.

Where do the parents come into any of this? The White Paper's treatment of AIDS education in schools ignores the rights of parents who do not even rate a mention in the development or approval of AIDS curricula let alone their right in regard to their children's education. I am sure that, given what is in this White Paper and what has taken place so far, the facts of life still will not be told. The students will not be told the simple fact that homosexual acts are deadly and that any young man who tries homosexual acts, even with condoms, is running a deadly risk. The figures are there. That is not a judgment on the interior disposition of homosexuals. It is a question of telling the truth-and the truth is being hidden.
I come to the position of parents or headmasters who may object to what is being taught to the students in the name of prevention of AIDS or safe sex. It is stated in paragraph 5.7.8 on page 47:
Protection is required for education and prevention workers from any liability which might exist for associated offences, such as aiding and abetting or counselling to perform illegal acts.
Later on, in paragraph 5.7.11 it is stated:

Laws regulating and/or penalising homosexual activity and prostitution impede public health programs promoting safer sex to prevent HIV transmission, by driving underground many of the people most at risk of an infection.

That is an assertion. In regard to homosexual activity where is the proof of that? I have not studied the situation so far as the prostitution side of it is concerned, but where is the proof in regard to homosexual acts? There is none. When was the last time any State legislation has been utilised in this regard? One of the protections that headmasters and parents have against the propaganda of the homosexual lobby into schools is this defence that it is against the law. And here is a recommendation in this document that educators should not be liable if they are aiding and abetting or counselling the performance of illegal acts.

Mr Acting Deputy President, there are a large number of other things that could be said about this report but let us be clear on it so far as this education program is concerned. I refer to page 48 of the document where it says this about dissemination of information:

Information about minimising transmission of HIV is sensitive and may need to be explicit to be effective in the media. For this reason, the Commonwealth will review laws relating to censorship and, in relation to broadcasting standards, will consult with the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to consider removing any unreasonable impediments to education and prevention programs, and to ensure the promotion of such programs in a non-discriminatory manner.

So they are going to review the censorship laws. Once the Government's AIDS campaign programs go to air, all of us are going to get calls from our constituents. What are we going to say? Are we going to say we did not get up here and object to what is proposed? I think we ought to know what is going on. On the one hand the Government says there is a danger that censorship laws are preventing the information being disseminated. What sort of information is it? What sort of explicit information is to be shown on television and at what times? The Government suggests that it will review laws relating to censorship. Senator Peter Baume talked about anal sex. Many of the X-rated videos, which this Commonwealth Government under its censorship laws allows, promote this high risk AIDS behaviour. If the Government is going to look at censorship laws, best it look at those.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you will recall that on a previous occasion I spoke of my concerns about the suggestion that was in the AIDS policy discussion paper that unborn babies should be aborted on the grounds that they have or might have AIDS. I then asked: What kind of caring AIDS policy is it that would foster a public attitude that defenceless, unborn human beings do not deserve to live simply because they have or may contract AIDS? That is the ultimate in discrimination. But the White Paper does not mention that. But I want to know what it means when it talks on page 38 about testing and counselling being currently widely available. It is stated in paragraph 5.2.5:

Testing and counselling is currently widely available, but could be made more so to assist individuals in their choice. State governments should improve community access to testing with counselling by expanding the availability through family planning clinics and other community health centres.

The fact is that the more money over the last five years that has been given to the family planning associations the higher the abortion rate has been. I want some guarantee from the Government that no family clinic will recommend or counsel for the abortion of any unborn child on the grounds that that unborn child has or may contract AIDS. Apart from the fact that about 80 per cent of unborn babies of HIV-infected women are born without the virus, what sort of caring society are we if we have a policy of killing off an unborn human being, of saying that an unborn human being does not deserve to live because it might contract AIDS?

Finally, I come back to the overall theme of the educational program thus far. I consider it to have been inadequate and I fear that this White Paper will only exacerbate the situation. By inferring that the sexually liberated fast lane way of life is okay, we endorse the mentality of instant gratification which has led to the despair of drug addiction and the perversion of homosexuality. I fear that we could run the danger of sanctioning a way of life that is literally killing our young people. In addition to the many deaths, there is the trail of ruined lives and broken families which the dead leave behind. Those who teach people allegedly safe techniques of blowing their minds on sex or drugs delude them into thinking that they can take the leap into drugs or sexual promiscuity without suffering consequences. That is not being judgmental about the interior dispositions of people; it is stating a fact of life. No matter how safe the sexual licence or how safe the resort to drugs, the life spent in the pursuit of desperate self-gratification will lead ultimately to despair and, in one way or another, to death. What is more, experience teaches that the person who is desperate for gratification in the last resort will pay no heed to safety.

I fear that if this sort of education goes into the schools it will only promote further destruction in the ranks of the young. I fear that the campaign would serve to attack the efforts made by parents to ensure that their children lead mature and flourishing lives. As I said, nowhere in this document so far as curriculum development in schools is concerned do the parents rate a mention, let alone a recognition of their rights in regard to the education and upbringing of their children.

I hope that we can together approach this subject as it deserves to be approached, that as a caring society we can give unconditional care to the AIDS sufferers, that as a society we can ensure that the facts are told and that the policy is not unduly influenced by the homosexual lobby group which would have us believe that the homosexual lifestyle is equally as valid as the heterosexual. I consider that it would be totally unfair to our young people to introduce into schools a compulsory AIDS education program based on the philosophy of this White Paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not proposed to speak in response to the statement on the acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) presented by the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) this afternoon, but coming into the Senate this evening for another reason I was moved to peruse the statement. As a consequence, I will make a couple of comments about it. I see that Senator Walsh, the Minister for Finance, is in the chamber. It will no doubt be a matter of interest and concern to him that the Government has allocated $318.5m over the next four years to implement this national strategy on AIDS. The statement reads:

SPEECH.PARA: In this, the first year, funds of $60.9m have been made available, an increase of 43.6 per cent on the previous financial year.

I know that if I hunted assiduously through the Budget Papers I may find some other items on which the expenditure has increased at a similar rate, but I think I would be very hard pressed to do so. The size of the increase being provided in this area is extraordinary. I say that because a couple of months ago the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) gave us what some people have dubbed the world's greatest environmental statement which was obviously targeted at the interest groups he thought would be influenced by a statement on that matter. The Prime Minister went to Wentworth and planted some trees. I have seen some photographs which show that those trees are now under water. Once again, the Prime Minister chose his mark there with the same degree of judgment and accuracy which actuated him in his administration of the pilots dispute.

After the environmental statement, we had the multicultural statement, again targeting another interest group in the community, again with the thought of an election not so far away down the track-a very cynical exercise in what one might these days call niche politics. Both of these statements place upon the taxpayers of this country considerable financial burdens. At a meeting in South Australia I was asked about these two statements by concerned citizens who had the same apprehension about them as I had, namely, that they appeared to be directed towards winning the next election for the Australian Labor Party at the expense of the taxpayers of this country. I agreed that that was probably a fair assessment of the quality of the two statements and predicted that there would be a lot more such statements in the months to come.

I predicted that there would be a statement directed to the Aboriginal lobby. Indeed, we have seen that both in the Budget and in the extraordinary spectacle to which we are being subjected in the Senate at present-the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill, a totally ill-judged piece of legislation which will take up an inordinate amount of time of the Senate. The legislation is directed to an objective which, when Australians as a whole come to understand what is proposed by this Government, will be rejected out of hand-I make no pun there-by most of them. So we have the Aboriginal statement, which I predicted at that time.

I also predicted at that time that we would have a pensioner statement, and indeed we saw that in the Budget. I predicted that we would have a sporting community statement, and we have just seen that. In fact, it was referred to today by Senator Lewis when he was referring to the other rort which the Government has recently introduced-the provision of $30,000 a year postal allowance for members of the House of Representatives so that the Labor Party can go about a direct mail campaign operation in all marginal electorates around this country.

I also predicted that we would have a homosexual lobby statement, and that is what we have got today in this document placed before us. Do not misunderstand me, Mr Acting Deputy President. I am not suggesting that all the concerns of this document or all the concerns about the dreadful AIDS disease are to do only with the homosexual community, although that has principally been the case and remains the case to this day. But there is not the slightest doubt that that is what this statement is principally directed towards.

I think my predictions in that regard have been well borne out by events, but in that connection I just draw attention-and this is my second and last point-to a couple of passages only in this document. There are many other passages which I think could be addressed and which no doubt have been addressed by previous speakers before I came into the chamber. I refer to page 21 of the Minister's statement: The Government has decided-and one wonders why it has taken it so long to decide-that mandatory HIV testing will be introduced for all applicants for permanent residence in this country. How long has the Government been directing its attention to the development and spread of AIDS in this country and how long has it taken, therefore, for it to finally come to the decision, which has been pressed upon it for years by concerned citizens of this country, to adopt a policy of this kind? How long has it taken it to stand up to the misguided civil liberty groups in this country who, in their misplaced zeal, have argued that Australians should be concerned about the civil liberties of people wishing to become Australians, and not just Australians, even though those people-or at least a very minute proportion of them, I should say, to be correct-may indeed be harbouring, may have harboured, and certainly have harboured the HIV virus before coming into this country and providing a new centre of infection for those unfortunate enough to be in contact with them? But the Minister goes on in his statement, having announced that at last the Government has conceded what common sense has long demanded, to say:
A positive result will not automatically exclude applicants from permanent residency. Scope will be retained to approve applications where justified by compassionate or other circumstances.

I wonder to whom the compassion should be directed-to the applicant or to the citizens of this country among whom the infected applicant will be free to spread the AIDS virus? We recently had news, which I suspect has had an impact in producing this belated decision by Dr Blewett, that 10 African immigrants, after having been admitted to this country, had been found on testing to be suffering from AIDS. That, of course, says nothing about the many others, no doubt, of whom the same could have been said. The Minister goes on in his statement to develop this same concern, this same process of putting the interests of some above others-I almost said the interests of the criminal against the interests of the community, which seems to be a commonly accepted doctrine these days. I do not wish to say that AIDS sufferers are criminals, but it is the same syndrome of concern-misplaced concern for some, but no concern for the innocent. The Minister goes on to say:
I have already stressed the importance of avoiding discrimination against people with AIDS.
I will say he `stressed' it. He spent the last two or three years stressing it, to the exclusion, I should have thought, of some of his other responsibilities in this area. He goes on to say:

But it remains a fact that many people with HIV, their relatives, friends and carers have faced discrimination. Some have been dismissed from employment, some evicted for accommodation, others refused medical or dental treatment, or perhaps harassed by the media.

I have to say to all that no doubt that is all very distressing, but it is very likely that Australians will continue to shun-rightly or wrongly-people with a disease which is known to be fatal, which no-one has yet survived. Despite all the assurances of many people in the medical profession, citizens may continue to harbour doubts about the transmission of the disease.
I go on to the next point, which is really the point I am going to conclude on. The Minister then says:

The Government is asking the States to establish, extend or clarify anti-discrimination legislation to provide redress for people with HIV, their families and carers in basic areas such as employment, education and training, accommodation and supply of goods and services and to prohibit discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation or imputed sexual orientation.

All I want to say about that is that it reminds me very much of the famous story of Russia in the 1930s when Stalin was having people sent off to the gulags. The head of the NKVD, or whatever it was called in those days-perhaps the OGPU-came to Stalin to confess that he could not meet his quota: he was not sending enough people to Siberia, or not as many as Stalin was demanding. Stalin said: `There is no problem. If we want more criminals, we simply create more laws'. I predict that, if these laws were created, they would certainly create many criminals. I warn the Minister, and I warn the Government, that Australians will not go on putting up with governments which continue to legislate about morality or about behaviour in this way. They will not put up with it. They will not only throw governments out, but they will begin to ignore the law and put the law into contempt; and governments which legislate in such a way as to bring the law into contempt deserve themselves to be brought into contempt, as this one will be.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum and I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill amends several Acts within the Attorney-General's portfolio.

The Bill contains amendments of a minor policy nature or which correct existing legislation. None of the amendments concern major new policy proposals or sensitive policy issues. Only the amendments to the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 to provide for reference appeals in the Australian Capital Territory will have any financial impact, increasing the expenditure of the Director of Public Prosecutions by an estimated $21,000 per year (less if outside counsel are not engaged).
The proposed amendments are explained in the explanatory memorandum circulated with the Bill. I propose to confine my remarks to the more noteworthy amendments.
Amendments to the Crimes Act 1914

The Bill will insert two new offences into the new Part VIIB of the Crimes Act 1914 which deals with offences relating to telecommunications services. The offences will proscribe unauthorised call-switching devices and unauthorised interception devices.

The unauthorised call-switching devices have been found to be used in conjunction with the commission of betting offences and are capable of defeating attempts to trace the calls of those involved in the commission of such offences. The new offence will prohibit the manufacture, possession, use, sale, offering for sale or advertising of unauthorised call-switching devices.

Turning to interception devices, whilst the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 currently prohibits, subject to certain exceptions, the interception of telecommunications, it does not contain a prohibition relating to devices by means of which interceptions are affected.

The Joint Select Committee on Telecommunications Interception recommended such a prohibition in its report tabled on 20 November 1986. In introducing the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill 1987 on 30 April 1987, the Attorney-General indicated that the Government was not at that stage in a position to act on the Joint Select Committee's recommendation.

The amendment to the Crimes Act 1914 gives effect to the Government's decision on this issue. It makes it an offence for a person to manufacture, advertise, display or offer for sale, sell or possess devices used to effect interceptions in contravention of the Interception Act. The new offence will not apply unless the device could reasonably be regarded as having been designed for the purpose of intercepting in contravention of the Interception Act. There is an exemption where a person is in possession of a device in the course of his or her duties where the Interception Act contemplates the lawful interception of communications. Further, there is provision for regulations to prescribe circumstances to which the new offence will not apply, for example, to allow manufacturers to develop and supply devices so that interceptions may be made as provided by the Interception Act.
Offences triable on indictment only

Amendments to the Crimes (Aircraft) Act 1963, the Crimes (Foreign Incursions and Recruitment) Act 1978 and the Crimes (Protection of Aircraft) Act 1973 included in the Bill will ensure that, for reasons of the sensitive nature of proceedings for offences against these Acts, which may involve high matters of state or foreign policy, prosecutions for these offences can only be brought on indictment.
Attorney-General's consent to prosecutions

Amendments to the Crimes (Foreign Incursions and Recruitment) Act 1978 and the Crimes (Aircraft) Act 1963 will ensure that the requirement that the consent of the Attorney-General, or (in the latter Act) a person authorised by the Attorney-General, be obtained for the institution of proceedings for an offence against either Act is extended to proceedings for `'related'' offences under the Crimes Act 1914, for example, attempting or conspiring to commit such an offence.
Amendment to the Crimes (Internationally Protected Persons) Act 1977

The Act provides that a verdict of guilty of the lesser offence of committing an attack on an internationally protected person may be brought, as an alternative, at the trial of a person for murdering or kidnapping an internationally protected person. The amendment will enable the alternative verdict to be brought on the trial of a person for attempting to murder or kidnap an internationally protected person, and is intended to correct a problem highlighted by the Federal Court in Duffy v. R.
Amendments to the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981

The Act is to be amended to allow the Federal Police Disciplinary Tribunal, or the Commissioner when that Tribunal has remitted disciplinary proceedings to him for imposition of penalty, to reduce in rank or dismiss from the Australian Federal Police a commissioned officer found guilty of a breach of discipline, without the necessity of seeking the approval of the Governor-General.
Amendment to the Custom Act 1901

Under provisions of the Act, a listening device warrant, issued by a judge to the Australian Federal Police or the National Crime Authority to assist in the investigation of a narcotics offence, may authorise entry on premises for the purpose of installing, maintaining, using or recovering the device. A definition of ``premises'' is to be inserted to make it clear that ``premises'' includes any area of land, structure, building, ship, vehicle or aircraft.
Amendments to the Evidence Act 1905

An amendment will authorise superior courts, when ordering that evidence be taken abroad under Part IIIB, to give directions for the use of that evidence in a committal hearing, a criminal trial or a proceeding for a civil remedy arising out of that matter.

Currently, the evidence of a witness abroad must be taken each time in separate proceedings for use at committal hearings, any resulting trial on indictment, and related civil proceedings. This is a wasteful procedure, and the Director of Public Prosecutions has requested the amendment to enable evidence taken abroad to be used successively in proceedings of this kind.

The orders will be discretionary. The court hearing a proceeding will also have a discretion whether or not to admit the evidence obtained abroad. The amendment will give superior courts the power to rescind or vary orders made under Part IIIB. It will be possible, for example, for a defendant to seek a fresh examination of a witness located abroad to deal with issues that emerge at the committal hearing or afterwards.

The Act is also to be amended to allow the Attorney-General to prohibit evidence being given in Australia for use in civil or commercial proceedings in foreign courts, where the taking of the evidence would be prejudicial to Australia's security.
Amendments to the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976

Amendments to the Act will confer jurisdiction on the Federal Court to hear `reference' appeals in respect of any question of law arising from a trial on indictment in the Supreme Court of the Australian Capital Territory. A reference appeal is one whereby a question of law can be submitted to an appeal court after acquittal, without the liberty of the defendant being affected.

The amendment will bring the Australian Capital Territory law into line with most of the States and the Northern Territory and will ensure that the correct view of the relevant law is established as a precedent, thereby ensuring that errors at the trial level are not repeated in later cases.
Amendments to the Privacy Act 1988

The Act is to be amended to enable Ombudsman's offices around Australia to receive and handle privacy complaints on behalf of the Privacy Commissioner. This is a cost-effective way of enabling the Privacy Commissioner to be represented Australia-wide and will provide individuals with convenient access to his office.
Amendments to the State and Territorial Laws and Records Recognition Act 1901

The amendments in the Bill adapt the operation of the Act to take account of the grant of self-government to the Australian Capital Territory, the Northern Territory and Norfolk Island. They provide for the proof of instruments, records and official acts with respect to Ministers and Legislative Assemblies of these Territories, complementing similar provisions in the Act relating to the States.
Amendments to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979
The Bill contains a number of amendments to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979.

First, amendments will allow approved members of the Australian Federal Police, when executing warrants, to be given technical assistance by civilian technicians employed by the AFP. It has been found that such assistance may be necessary when technical difficulties arise during the execution of a warrant.

Secondly, an amendment will allow lawfully intercepted information to be given in evidence in proceedings under the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987 in relation to offences for which the penalty is imprisonment for at least 3 years. Under that provision, the Attorney-General may authorise the taking of evidence or production of documents before a magistrate in Australia for the purposes of a proceeding relating to a criminal matter in a foreign country. Such proceedings are not ones in which information lawfully obtained by interception may currently be given in evidence. The amendment will allow Australia to give an assurance of reciprocity to other countries from which Australia may wish to seek intercepted information relating to prosecutions for Australian offences.

Thirdly, the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption is to be specified as an agency which may apply for the issue of warrants under the Act and to which intercepted information may be communicated by other agencies.
Finally, the Bill provides for the use of billing information obtained by Telecom by means of a technical interception to be used by Telecom in proceedings to recover a debt due to it.
Amendments to the Trade Practices Act 1974

One amendment to the Act will ensure that the Trade Practices Commission has adequate time to consider applications for non-merger authorisations. At present, the Minister has a power to limit to 4 months the time taken by the Commission to determine non-merger applications. The amendment will provide that the time taken by applicants in responding to requests for additional information by the Commission will not be included in that four month period.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Banking Act 1959 and other banking legislation to reflect a number of developments in the past several years. The major changes proposed are to provide the Reserve Bank with formal authority for the prudential supervision of banks; to remove the distinction between trading banks and savings banks; to replace the Statutory Reserve Deposit requirement on trading banks with a new Non-Callable Deposit requirement on all banks; and to make the arrangements for collection and publication of banking statistics more flexible.

The banking system is central to the operation of the financial system and has an important contribution to make to the wider economy. It is therefore important that the stability of the banking system be promoted through the observance of high prudential standards by banks.

The Reserve Bank has a statutory obligation under the Banking Act to protect those who deposit funds with banks. In keeping with this obligation and its general responsibility for the stability of the financial system, the Reserve Bank has developed arrangements under which each bank is encouraged to keep itself in a sound financial position and to conduct its business in a prudent and professional manner.

The prudential requirements observed by banks in Australia, like those applying in other developed countries, relate to such matters as the adequacy of capital, the structure of assets and liabilities, management of exposures to risk, the capacity of its directors and senior management, and the representation of shareholders by directors.

These arrangements for prudential supervision have relied heavily upon the co-operation of individual banks. This system has worked well but in the light of the increased number of banks now operating in Australia, changes in banking activities and the more competitive and demanding environment in which banks operate, it is desirable for the Reserve Bank to have a clear statutory basis for its prudential supervision of banks.

The Government considers that prudential arrangements for banks should be related to specific powers within the Banking Act and that the role of the Reserve Bank as prudential supervisor of banks should be recognised formally.

The Bill will amend the Banking Act in a number of ways to achieve this. In particular, it will provide for the Treasurer, having consulted with the Reserve Bank, to recommend that the Governor-General establish requirements in relation to prudential matters by way of regulations. This power will be supplemented by an increase in the scope already permitted in the Act for the Governor-General to place conditions on banking authorities.

The Bill will also establish formally the role of the Reserve Bank in the prudential supervision of banks and transfer to the Reserve Bank the powers currently resting with the Auditor-General to conduct investigations of banks.

As consequence of the Reserve Bank's continuous conduct of prudential supervision, and the publication of its prudential rules, its present requirements are well known and understood by the banking sector.

It is not the Government's intention that the amendment of the Act should alter the prudential standards being met by banks or the way in which they are administered. Rather, the Government considers that the power to make regulations relating to prudential requirements should be seen as a reserve power to be used when circumstances require it.

The amendments proposed in this Bill will also give legislative effect to the Treasurer's announcement in the Budget last year of the removal of the distinction between savings banks and trading banks. The general nature of these amendments is to make the provisions currently applying to trading banks apply to all banks, and to repeal specific provisions relating to savings banks.

The maintenance of a distinction between savings banks and trading banks no longer serves any policy purpose. In recent years most savings bank subsidiaries of banks have existed not as distinct physical or managerial structures but as different sets of accounts within banking groups. From a customer's viewpoint there is no effective difference between savings and trading banks.

Removal of the distinction between them will enable banks to have better use and allocation of funds, more simple funding and accounting arrangements, and greater flexibility in servicing customers. These gains will ultimately benefit bank customers through a lower cost of bank services.

As a result of comments which have been received from the banking industry consideration is being given to some further amendment of the Banking Act to facilitate the integration of the accounts of savings banks and trading banks.
This change will not change the extent to which banks now lend money to customers for housing purposes, nor will it affect the price of housing loans.

The third major change proposed in this Bill is the removal of the Statutory Reserve Deposit (SRD) requirement on trading banks. Both the Campbell Committee and the Martin Group recommended that this outmoded measure should be modified.

The SRD requirement has had distorting effects on the financial system because it has increased the cost of trading bank lending, diverted business to savings banks and other non-bank financial institutions, and encouraged banks to fund their operations through sources other than Australian dollar deposits, such as commercial bills, offshore borrowing and foreign currency deposits.

As the Treasurer announced at Budget time the SRD requirement is being phased down over a three year period and replaced with a system of Non-Callable Deposits which banks will be required to maintain with the Reserve Bank as part of their obligations as authorised banks.

By the end of the transitional three year period all the banks affected will hold Non-Callable Deposits with the Reserve Bank equivalent to one per cent of their liabilities. The effect of the new arrangements will be to remove the distorting effect of the SRD arrangement and generally reduce the burden on banks and their customers.

The new arrangements represent a further and significant step in the process of financial deregulation which the Government has brought about with a view to raising the overall efficiency of the banking sector and thereby increasing the scope for it to contribute to the broader economy.
The change is estimated to involve a cost to revenue of $100 million each year, or roughly half the SRD revenue in 1987-88, by the time the transitional period is completed in 1991-92.

Precise costs will of course depend on a number of variable factors such as the level of interest rates and the rate of growth in banks' assets and liabilities. The Government proposes to review the Non-Callable Deposit arrangements before the end of the transitional period and, in particular, to consider adopting a lower maximum rate than that currently proposed in the Bill.

The Bill proposes a number of other changes to the Banking Act and to related legislation with a view to ensuring that the legislative framework is relevant to the present banking system and flexible in its administration.

The Bill proposes that arrangements for the collection and publication of statistics about banks should be simplified and made more flexible by allowing the details of these arrangements to be determined through regulations rather than spelled out in the Act as at present.

The latter arrangement has proved to be inflexible in the light of the significant and rapid changes which have taken place in the nature of financial markets and the types of financial instruments used by banks.

The Government's ability to monitor the financial sector will be improved by the scope which it will have under the amended Act to adjust the form of statistical returns which banks are required to make. We shall, however, keep in mind the continued need for consultation over such changes and for minimising reporting burdens.

There should be some resource savings both for the banks and the Government from these amendments, since unnecessary requirements will be able to be dropped more rapidly and the obligation on the Australian Statistician to receive and publish banking statistics, which duplicates work undertaken by the Reserve Bank, will be removed.

The First Schedule to the Act which lists authorised banks will be updated and a procedure will be introduced to allow the Treasurer to amend the First Schedule through publishing information in the Gazette. These changes will allow the public to be better informed as to those financial institutions which are authorised as banks.

Provision has been made in the Bill for a banking authority to be revoked by the Governor-General where a bank requests it and the Governor-General is satisfied that there is no objection on grounds of national interest.

The new provision will allow greater flexibility since, in contrast to the present section, it will allow an authority to be surrendered or removed where a bank has not ceased to carry on business but wishes to continue as a financial institution without having the status and obligations of a bank.

Section 66 of the Banking Act, which requires that consent be obtained from the Treasurer for the use of the word ``bank'' in a business name or as a descriptive expression in relation to the business of a financial institution, has been revised in the Bill to clarify the meaning and scope of the provision. The purpose of the more detailed provision would remain as before-to avoid confusion on the part of the public between banks authorised under the Banking Act and non-bank financial institutions.
The Bill proposes that a new provision be introduced into the Banking Act to provide a clear legislative basis for regulating the establishment of representative offices by international banks.
Under the new provision it is intended that such banks should be required to seek the Treasurer's consent to open a representative office and to observe any conditions which he may establish.

This provision would formalise arrangements which now operate on an informal basis. It would not imply any change in the Government's policy of welcoming the establishment of representative offices to undertake purely liaison activities on behalf of international banks.
The Bill also includes some proposed amendments to the Commonwealth Banks Act and the Reserve Bank Act.

The proposed changes to the Commonwealth Banks Act would widen the Board's power over the Commonwealth Bank's capital structure in line with the revised definitions of capital announced by the Reserve Bank in 1988, and streamline the Commonwealth Bank's reporting requirements.

The proposed changes to the Reserve Bank Act are to simplify its internal accounting arrangements by abolishing the artificial separation between the note issue and central banking functions, and to remove some redundant reporting obligations.
Finally, the Bill addresses the fact that penalties for offences against the Banking Act have been unaltered since the Act came into force in 1959 and provides for them to be revised.

It is intended that the relevant sections of the Act be amended to establish penalties for breaches of the Act or of its regulations which are consistent with penalty levels imposed on corporations in other significant legislation.
I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill, and I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the revised explanatory memorandum and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The Bill would implement administrative assessment of child support obligations under a formula set out in the Bill.
It would implement stage 2 of the child support scheme.
The Bill would have an entirely prospective operation-affecting only people who separate or have a child born on or after its commencement.
Under stage 2 of the child support scheme:
Procedures to obtain child support would be dramatically simplified;
The level of child support obtained would be directly in line with the capacity of parents to provide it;
There would be annual updating of child support levels;
The processes of application for sole parents pension and child support would be closely integrated;
The rights of parents to apply to the courts to resolve disputes in their particular case would be retained;
The facilities for parents to make private agreements between themselves about child support would be enhanced.

Mr President, the need for reform of child maintenance was identified by the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act. In 1980, only 4 years after the commencement of the Family Law Act that Committee identified four key problems with the system of child maintenance:
The levels of maintenance were inadequate;
The enforcement of maintenance liabilities was ineffective;
The system of updating child maintenance liabilities was cumbersome and seldom used;
The maintenance and social security systems were poorly integrated.

On the question of child maintenance the Joint Select Committee's major recommendation was the implementation of a scheme under which the amount a liable parent should contribute would be administratively assessed in line with his or her capacity to pay. This contribution would have gone to the Department of Social Security.

Experience in other countries has shown such schemes to have limited effectiveness-only the revenue benefits so neither parent has any reason to assist in administration of the scheme. Intrusive and expensive mechanisms are, therefore, required to make them work.
Further, because such schemes operate only where a custodian is in receipt of pension, difficulties arise when the custodians find work or repartner.
The Hawke Government, therefore, has not fully endorsed the approach of the Joint Select Committee.
I imagine it was for similar reasons that the Fraser Government did not act to implement this aspect of the report.
After the Joint Select Committee reported the next major development was the establishment by the then Attorney-General, Senator Evans, of the National Maintenance Enquiry.
That enquiry recommended in 1985 the establishment of a national maintenance collection agency to improve the enforcement of maintenance orders.
Following work by the Family Law Council the Government decided not to proceed with the National Maintenance Collection Agency because it would not have addressed the issues of:
Levels of maintenance;
Updating of liabilities; or
Interaction of the maintenance and social security systems.

A more fundamental reform that synthesised the best of both the Select Committee report and National Maintenance Enquiry report was required-a reform that adopted the principles of administrative assessment, integrated private and public provision for children and achieved effective collection of liabilities.
In 1986 the Government published ``Child Support: A Discussion Paper on Maintenance''. It proposed a system of:
Setting of child support levels under the formula related to the income of parents;
Initial assessment under that formula to be by the child support agency-part of the tax office;
Access to the courts in contentious cases;
Annual updating of assessment by the child support agency; and
Collection of child support liabilities by the child support agency.
Following extensive public consultation the Minister for Social Security announced in March 1987 the introduction of the Child Support Scheme in two stages.
Under stage 1 of the scheme, which commenced on 1 June 1988, maintenance orders and agreements made, registered or approved in the courts can be enforced by the Child Support Agency.
In his March 1987 statement the Minister announced that he would establish the Child Support Consultative Group to advise the Government on a legislative formula to apply under stage 2.
The group, chaired by Justice Fogarty of the Family Court of Australia, was established in May 1987.
This Bill would substantially implement the report of the Child Support Consultative Group: ``Child Support: Formula for Australia''.
In describing the formula which would be implemented by this Bill, Justice Fogarty said:
``The formula preserves the right of parents to reach their own agreement (with suitable protection for the revenue when the custodial parent is on a pension or benefit);

It ensures that each parent has an unqualified right to have the matter determined by the court if he/she is not satisfied with the administrative assessment. It continues the right to go to court but will remove the need to do so in many cases;
At the same time it provides for the automatic updating of orders annually in accordance with any changes in the financial or other circumstances of the parties;

The percentages which have been chosen have regard to evidence of the proportion of income ordinarily spent on children who live with both parents and are aimed at achieving reasonable levels of orders proportional to income;

This approach, combined with the enforcement procedures already established under stage 1, should go a long way towards overcoming the unsatisfactory state of child support in Australia and benefit both Australian children and the Australian community generally.''
Mr President, under the Bill administrative assessment of child support would be available to people having the ongoing daily care of a child from the natural or adoptive parents of the child.

The Bill would apply only when the parents have a child born on or after the commencement of stage 2 of the scheme or the parents separate on or after that day; and provided that the applicant is not cohabiting with the parent against whom the claim is made.

In all other cases maintenance rights and liabilities will continue to be determined under the Family Law Act. For example applications by children in their own right would remain under the Family Law Act.

Following an application, the child support agency could proceed to issue an assessment against a person only if the person was a party to a marriage during which the child was born; the person has adopted the child; or the agency is satisfied that under the law of the Commonwealth, a state, territory or prescribed overseas jurisdiction:
the person is recorded as a parent of the child on a register of births or parentage;
a court has found as a fact that the person is a parent of the child; or
the person has acknowledged paternity of the child in writing.
The parties would be entitled to have any dispute about eligibility for assessment-such as parentage-decided by the courts.

Where an applicant is entitled to assessment under the Bill the basic formula to be applied by the child support agency would be: the income of the liable parent minus the liable parent's exemption multiplied by the relevant child support percentage.

For the purposes of the assessment the income of the parents will be the taxable income of each parent in the financial year ending on 30 June in the calendar year preceding the assessment. This would be adjusted by a factor prescribed by regulation to take account of inflation.
The liable parent's exemption would make provision for the support of the liable parent and any natural or adoptive children of whom the liable parent has ongoing daily care.
In accordance with recommendations of the child support consultative group the level of the exemption will be fixed according to the level of social security pensions.

The group recommended, and the Bill would provide, that where a liable parent does not have the ongoing daily care of natural or adoptive children the exemption would be equivalent to single adult rate pension; and where there are natural or adoptive children the exemption would be equivalent to the maximum rate pension payable to a married couple plus the additional pension that would be payable in the social security system for each of those children.

In accordance with this principle the Bill would provide that where a liable parent is caring for a 16 or 17 year old child additional allowance of 25% of pension payable to a married couple would be made for that child. This is close to the rate at which Austudy is payable for children of that age.

The child support percentages provided for in the Bill are as recommended by the child support consultative group. They would vary with the number of children in respect of whom child support is paid: for one child, 18%; for two children, 27%; for three children 32%; for four children 34% and for 5 or more children 36%.
In recommending these percentages the consultative group noted:

``In determining appropriate percentage levels to apply above (the liable parent's exemption) available evidence that might indicate the proportion of family income normally devoted to children in a two parent family was taken as a starting point. However in arriving at percentage contribution rates a number of other factors need to be taken into consideration. These include additional costs of rearing a child where parents do not live together, indirect costs of children to custodial parents, access costs incurred by non-custodial parents, retention of appropriate incentives to earn for non-custodial parents and the views of the community on what would be considered a fair level of child support.''
The Government accepts that, taken together, the exemption levels and percentages recommended by the consultative group produce a fair and equitable formula for child support.

The Bill would provide, in line with the recommendations of the child support consultative group, that the income of a custodial parent would be taken into account under the formula when it exceeds the sum of average weekly earnings and an allowance for child care costs.
The level of liability of a liable parent would be reduced having regard to the amount of this excess.
Mr President, the basic formula contained in this Bill would achieve a fair assessment of child support liabilities in the great majority of cases.
The Bill would make provision for a range of more complex cases such as where ongoing care of a child is shared between parents or where care of the children from one family is split between parents.

Other cases dealt with are where a child is cared for by a person who is not a parent of the child and both parents are liable to pay child support: and cases where one liable parent is liable to pay child support to two or more custodians.
The Bill would also make provision to take account of the changed circumstances of the parties such as changes in income or care arrangements for the child.

Mr President, the Bill would enable the continuance of private agreements about the amount and form of child support through a mechanism along the lines of section 86 of the Family Law Act. An agreement on child support matters in writing and signed by both parents could be registered with the child support agency. Registration would make provisions of the agreement enforceable and variable as if they were provisions of consent orders of a court.
The Bill would also retain the rights of parties to approach courts in child support matters.
Under the Bill the courts that exercise jurisdiction under the Family Law Act would have four functions.
First, they would determine applications for declarations that an applicant is, or is not, entitled to an assessment under the Bill.
Second, the courts would determine whether an assessment by the child support agency is, on the facts of the particular case, a correct application of the formula contained in the Bill.
Third, the courts would determine applications to vary assessments in cases where assessments in line with the formula would not produce a fair result.
To obtain a variation from a formula assessment an applicant to a court would be required to establish that the case falls within specified grounds for departure.

These grounds for departure broadly relate to cases where: first, a parent's capacity to provide support for a child is reduced by special needs or commitments of the parent or another person the parent has a legal duty to support; second, where the costs of supporting a child are affected because of the special needs of the child or because the child is being cared for, educated or trained in the manner that was expected by his or her parents or because of the high costs of access of either parent to the child; and, third, where the assessment is inequitable because the income, earning capacity, property or financial resources of either parent or of the child which have not been taken into account as ``income'' under the formula or because earlier payments and transfers or settlements of property made by the liable parent to the child, the eligible custodian or to a third person for the benefit of the child would mean that the formula assessment does not produce a fair result.

In assessing whether to vary an assessment the courts would consider in each case the nature of the duty of the parents to support their children, the proper needs of the child, the income, earning capacity, property and financial resources of the child and the parents, the commitments of each parent necessary to support him or herself or any other person that the person has a duty to maintain, the direct and indirect costs incurred by the custodian in providing care for the child, the relative hardship to the custodian or non custodian and their children in the particular case and whether, despite the clear primacy of the duty of parents to support their children, it is proper to make an order that could increase payments to the custodian under the social security system.

Mr President, the fourth function of the courts under the Bill would be to order that child support be provided in a form other than periodic amounts. A court would be required to state, when making an order that child support is to be provided in a form other than periodic amounts, whether child support ordered is to be credited against liability under an assessment and to give reasons for making the order and the statement. A court's power to make orders for child support in a form other than periodic amounts would be subject to the right of custodians who are pensioners to apply at any time to the child support agency for their entitlements to periodic amounts not to be reduced by more than 25 per cent.
Mr President, the Bill would also:
restate the availability of the counselling facilities of the Family Court or a Family Court of a State to parties involved in the administrative assessment process;

provide a secrecy provision to balance the need to protect the confidentiality of tax information and other information necessarily obtained in the administration of the scheme as it relates to each parent, with the need for all parties to be aware of the matters taken into account by the child support agency when making an assessment; and
consequential amendments to the Child Support Act, the Family Law Act, the Social Security Act and the Taxation Administration Act.

The Child Support Scheme has seen a unique display of unity of purpose among all legislators in Australia. Legislation for stage 1 of the Child Support Scheme passed through both Houses of this Parliament with unanimous support. Its full operation depends upon legislation passed by the parliaments of all six states.

This Bill would provide for stage 2 to operate pursuant to Commonwealth powers and pursuant to the reference of powers already made by Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania and New South Wales. Queensland and Western Australia would be able to have it fully operate in their states through a reference of power, adoption of the legislation or making a corresponding law that the Commonwealth agrees to have apply.
The Government looks forward to full national application of this legislation through these mechanisms.
We also hope that we will retain the unity of purpose within this Parliament on this most important area.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.
