SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —By now it is old news that on 16 August the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) sent members and senators a letter indicating that the Government had decided to increase the postage entitlement for members of the House of Representatives to $30,525 and to leave that of senators at $9,000. This attempt by the Government to change the administrative arrangements for postal allowances for senators and members is, in my view, nothing more than members of the Executive getting caught with their hands in the till-the whole lot of them with both hands in the till-to advance their own positions and the position of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: With that in mind I seek to make some remarks with respect to the reply tabled this morning by the Manager of Government Business in the Senate, Senator Robert Ray. The reply tabled this morning is totally inadequate in terms of addressing the concerns raised by the Opposition. It simply, in effect, restates the letter. It says, `We have decided this is what we are going to do. Take it or leave it; like it or lump it'. It gives no consideration to the real issues involved. I put it to the Senate that once a determination has been made by the Remuneration Tribunal it has force of law. That is reasonably clear from section 7 (5) of the Remuneration Tribunals Act, which states:
A determination of the Tribunal shall be in writing and shall come into operation, or shall be deemed to have come into operation, on such date as the Tribunal specifies . . .

For this particular determination-for the stamp allowance that senators and members alike have been getting up to 16 August-that was a date in January this year. That determination would have life-force of law, if you like-until a new determination was made. That is how the system has worked for many years. A Minister is now purporting to change that determination by simply sending around a letter. If we have come to that-if we bother to spend however much we do spend on the Remuneration Tribunal and the Government then decides it does not want to go along with that but can just send around a letter-it makes a total farce of bothering to have a Remuneration Tribunal in the first place. Secondly, it shows that the Government has no understanding of the force that Tribunal determinations have. That is probably no surprise to members and senators on the Opposition of the Parliament. But it does more than that. It gives us a glimpse of how this Government wants to conduct itself in the lead-up to the next election. As you, Mr Acting Deputy President, being a Government senator, will understand, this side of the Parliament needs to win 12 lower House seats in order to retain government. An extra $20,000 in postage entitlements to those seats is obviously a particular advantage to the Government members who now hold them.

What we have now is a situation where coalition candidates in seats will not have $30,000 worth of postage, but by virtue of a simple ministerial letter the sitting Labor member in those seats will have $30,000 worth of postage. That is what this whole move is about. There is no reassessment of priorities for lower House members as against senators; it is a reassessment of the Government's priorities, a reassessment of its chances of whether it can get back or not. That is the beginning and the end of the matter.

Of course, if we want to look at it a bit closer we ask ourselves: what does it mean if the Government gets back? It means that Ministers who might be sitting opposite and Ministers who might be in the lower chamber have got a chance of being Ministers for a bit longer. We all know what self-interest that entails. If it was a minor matter involving not much money and it was agreed by most people, on its face, to be a mistake or to be perhaps an intentional bending of the rules but in the interest of the nation as a whole or a particular group across party lines, one might understand it. One might say one was being a bit pedantic trying to insist that the rules were followed. But when one can see that the reason the rules have been broken, chucked out of the window, totally ignored, and wiped away by one simple letter is to advance the position of the Government, and in particular to advance the position of front bench members, we have to ask whether it is appropriate that the rules have been broken and not enough people seem to be complaining about it. The media do not seem to be very interested in the fact that this is a hands in the till, snout in the trough job to advance the Government's own position.

We heard today a small response by the Minister, Senator Robert Ray, to the limited debate we were able to have on this matter this morning. I had to pinch myself and wonder whether I was possibly going insane, because what we have had, what has been outlined in this chamber by a number of people, is a Minister--

TALK.START.PARA: —What was your conclusion?

—That I am not insane, Minister; that was my conclusion. I did not even need to think about it. What we have had is a ministerial letter trying to throw out a Remuneration Tribunal decision. The Government has thought about that, quite obviously. Senator Ray indicated that in his speech last week. The Government thought about it and decided it could do it. What does he have the gall to stand up here and tell senators today? Let me read what he says:

SPEECH.PARA: I put my comments on the record when this issue was first raised.
Well, he did. And when he did that he indicated that the Government had given consideration to this matter and believed it could do what it had done. Then he says:

This is the first time I have actually been asked in this chamber in all the hyberbole that has gone on to take the matter up. Senator Macklin has invited me to take up with Mr West the question as to whether the whole matter should be referred to the Remuneration Tribunal.

So where have we come in the last week? We have a letter from the Government saying, `It is out of the Remuneration Tribunal's hands, we are going to handle all this ourselves now', and then an off-the-cuff remark from a Minister saying, `Oh well, I will see if it all should go back to the Remuneration Tribunal'. Who is kidding whom? Is the Minister serious when he said that this morning, or was that meant to be a joke, and are we all meant to burst into laughter and say, `Ha, ha, isn't that funny'? I do not regard it as funny. As I have said, I would not use terminology like `hands in the till' if I did not think it was a very serious matter. The Minister says, `Oh well, I'll see whether we want to go back to the Remuneration Tribunal'. That is the first point.

A first-year law student could probably tell us that, once a determination has been made, it stands and the only way it can be changed is by legislation. The Government obviously understands that, because in 1986 a number of senators and members took part in a debate on the Remuneration and Allowances Alteration Bill 1986. That was a Bill to reject a salary determination made by the Remuneration Tribunal. The Government understood at that stage that, in order to change a determination, legislative action had to be taken-a Bill had to be passed. Now we have the situation where the Government, for its own greedy purposes, wants to give lower House members, in particular marginal seat members, $20,000 more postage. It does not want to have a Bill before both chambers of this Parliament to do that because it knows what the debate would produce. It would produce an unholy reaction from the taxpayer. The taxpayers, if more of them realised about this problem, would understand that this Government wants to give $2 a week to pensioners and hundreds and hundreds of dollars a week to members of parliament. That is the explanation that we have for not proceeding via legislation this time-because it would be inconvenient to have debate on the matter. That is why the Government has just tried to slip it through by ministerial letter. Anyway, I have made the point that I do not think that is the appropriate way to go about it, that the Government has not done this the right way, and that it has not given any proper explanation for the course that it has chosen to take.

There is a further matter, that is, parliamentary scrutiny of what the Executive is doing. After all, that is presumably what Parliament is meant to be about. Parliament looks at what the Government does, keeps a check on the Government and, in that sense, keeps a check on members of the Executive, who in this instance, as I have indicated, have got their hands very firmly in the till to the tune of $20,000 for each of their marginal seats. How can we do that? We can keep a check on the Government and Executive by watching what legislation they want to pass and, to the extent that something does not come up in legislation, check on it in appropriations.

It has long been settled-since 1965, I understand-that new policies not authorised by special legislation would be in Appropriation Bill (No. 2). There was a reason for that-a simple reason. It is to alert Parliament, in particular the Senate, to the fact that the Government is doing something new so that we can have a look at it and can exercise our right to amend that Bill, to set that matter apart from those matters contained in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) for the ordinary annual services of government. That is why it should be in Appropriation Bill (No. 2). Any decision, albeit a grossly improper decision, to spend money not authorised by special legislation should be in Appropriation Bill (No. 2).

For the Government to decide that, by simple ministerial letter, it can completely dispose of the Remuneration Tribunal is obviously a new policy-and it, therefore, should be in Appropriation Bill (No. 2). But what does this Government do? It denies Parliament, it denies the Senate, the opportunity to scrutinise what it has been doing by slipping the matter-that is, the appropriation for it, the grant of money-into Appropriation Bill (No. 1). We can look at the Estimates for the Department of Administrative Services and ask, `Where could this possibly be?' The examination of estimates is not meant to be a cat and mouse game; it is not meant to be `hide it if you can' on the Government's part, and `find it if you can' on the Opposition's part. It is meant to be a sensible, bipartisan appraisal of what the Executive is wanting to do. That is the whole purpose of it; it is not a game. If we wanted to play games, we could go out and buy Monopoly boards. It is meant to be a sensible appraisal of what the Government is doing, a sensible outline to Parliament so that officers of departments can given explanations as to what is intended. Everybody is meant to have a better understanding of what it is all about.

With that in mind, we head off to the Department of Administrative Services to see where this money is and we find that it is under `Property Operating Expenses', subprogram 14.1. I will almost guarantee that the telephone bills for members and senators are not under `Property Operating Expenses'. That is not where stamps belong. Stamps for members of parliament under `Property Operating Expenses'! That should highlight how ludicrous this matter is. It is a case of those in government realising that they want to give themselves some extra money-and I say that advisedly-and then wanting to get away with it and so choosing a course that has the minimum oversight by Parliament. They do that, firstly, by not using an Act of Parliament to do something that they should use an Act of Parliament for and that there should be proper debate on so that the public are therefore aware of what their Parliament is doing and how the Executive is spending the taxpayers' dollar. The Government decides that it will not do that; that it will just send around a ministerial letter. Government by ministerial letter! This Government is famous for government by press release. Now it will be famous for government by ministerial letter. The Government thinks we cannot do much about that. Then, having decided to take that action, the Government chooses to place the appropriation for the funds into an appropriation Bill that cannot be amended by this chamber, totally emasculating this chamber.

It is no surprise at all that this Government does not want to give the Senate the opportunity to scrutinise what it does. Although I do not really believe it, I had mistakenly thought that the Remuneration Tribunal was meant to be the independent body to deal with these matters. Senator Macklin, in speaking earlier to this matter, properly identified the reason that we send our salaries and allowances to the Remuneration Tribunal. Let me outline, for anybody it has not dawned upon yet or for whom the penny has not dropped as to the reason for doing that, that it is to keep parliamentarians' snouts out of the trough. That is why we do it-for the public to have some confidence that the money spent on parliamentarians' salaries and allowances is not being fixed up by us behind closed doors, without parliamentary scrutiny. So, we send those matters off to an independent body. Senator Macklin rightly raised the point that a massive increase in allowances from $9,000 to $30,525 is simply being granted by ministerial letter. There was no independent scrutiny. Chuck the Remuneration Tribunal out the window. Let us all get our fingers in the till.

Senator Walsh should know something about this. He often stands up in this chamber and accuses members of the public in general of having their fingers in the till. I would be very pleased to hear what he has to say about this Government move, which has not only the Government's hands in the till but also the Executive's hands in the till. I remind you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that the concept of separating new policies not authorised by special legislation is not simply a function of a compact between the Executive and the Senate settled in 1965. This matter was re-endorsed in June 1976 by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs in a unanimous report on the ordinary annual services of government.

TALK.START.PARA: —What year was that?

—It was in 1976. Just in case the Government does not understand that Parliament is not the Government, in case its members did not pass Politics I in first year high school or did not ever do civics courses, let me point out to them, as I have made the point once before in this speech, that the Parliament's job is to scrutinise what the Government is doing. They are not simply one and the same thing; they never have been and, while some of us have breath in our lungs, they never will be the same thing. Even one of the Government's own members understood this. Let me refer to page 384 of Australian Senate Practice by Odgers. There is a debate basically as to what are the ordinary annual services of government and therefore what are not. Odgers states:

SPEECH.PARA: In a debate notable for new thought on an old problem, Senator L. K. Murphy, Q.C. (New South Wales) expressed the view that the Parliament is not an ordinary annual service of the Government . . .
At least he understood that. This is how Senator Murphy phrased his opinion to have people understand what he was saying:
It may be ordinary; it may be annual; it may even be regarded as a service; but it is not a service of the Government.

Parliament is not that. That ought to make it abundantly clear that postage allowances for members of parliament do not belong under property operating expenses, hidden away in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) for the ordinary annual services of government. That is not where parliamentary allowances belong. The Government should explain how it thinks it can get away with this. I conclude by saying that the allocation of money here is a substantial amount.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—This increase is worth millions and millions of dollars. If the Government thinks it can get away with this, it can think again. Members and senators on this side of the parliamentary spectrum understand that parliament is different from government. In this outrageous move, members of the Executive have been caught with their hands in the till and if we have our way they will get them well and truly jammed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a return made by the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray) today in regard to a motion by Senator Lewis as to the entitlements for postage allowances that have been determined by the Government for members of the House of Representatives. The motion that was put by Senator Lewis on 17 August 1989 called for particular details. I reiterate those requests. They were to explain in detail the reasoning behind the Government's decision to increase postal entitlement; to indicate why the Government chose to ignore the recommendation of the Remuneration Tribunal in its 1988 Review that members of parliament generally be provided with access to the full range of postal services provided by Australia Post subject to an annual limit of $9,000; and to explain why it is considered that while a significant increase in the existing postage entitlements of members of the House of Representatives is necessary with immediate effect, senators should continue to receive their existing entitlement indexed to changes in the mailing rate.

SPEECH.PARA: The response handed down today does not address those fundamental questions that were asked by the Senate. If we look at the reply that Senator Ray tabled earlier today, we find that, in respect of the request to explain in detail the reasoning, we have four brief paragraphs just setting out basically the facts. With regard to the second request, asking the Government to explain why it chose to ignore the recommendations of the Remuneration Tribunal, we basically have a very simple, stupid statement that just reiterates the facts the Remuneration Tribunal has offered. Thirdly, the area relating to the difference between the Senate and the House of Representatives is dealt with by the Government in an almost idiotic manner, in the way in which it has chosen to give an excuse for the decision it has taken with regard to the House of Representatives.

The point has been well made by Senator Vanstone, speaking before me, that it is very obvious that the Government is looking after its own political interests in this regard. It is choosing very deliberately to take over functions that in the past properly have been exercised by the Remuneration Tribunal. We need to ask why Senator Ray's statement says:
The Government has on 20 July 1989 and pursuant to subsection 7 (4) (b) of the Remuneration Tribunals Act 1983 withdrawn the matter from the Tribunal's jurisdiction.

Why then did we not hear about this decision in this Parliament for almost a month from when that matter was withdrawn from the jurisdiction of the Remuneration Tribunal? It poses a very serious question as to why the Government took action one month before it announced its retrospective application of granting a postal allowance of $30,525 to members of the House of Representatives. That the Government has chosen not only to withdraw this matter from the consideration of the Remuneration Tribunal where it very properly rests, but also to do it in such an underhand and sneaky manner, should be a matter of very major concern for this Senate.

With regard to the argument about the allocation for postage, let us look at the answer given with regard to paragraph (c), which seeks to justify these increases for members of the House of Representatives. The Government argues that this would enable a member of the House of Representatives to send a letter once a year to each constituent in an average sized electorate. I would argue that $30,525 will do much more than that. Anyone who can do simple arithmetic can work out the postage that will be available to House of Representatives members, particularly given the bulk postage arrangements now offered by Australia Post.

As I said, the idiotic and stupid explanation given by the Government as to why it cannot give a similar allowance to members of the Senate is that the costs would vary from $1.1m for senators from New South Wales to-and this is very interesting-a bottom line of $24,057 for a senator from the Northern Territory, that is, for Senator Collins or me, which points out the idiocy of the whole damned argument. Why is Warren Snowdon, the Northern Territory member of the House of Representatives, using the Government's very argument to be given a postage allowance of $30,525, when the Government argues that if it is to put the same principles into place that it has argued for members of the House of Representatives, then senators for the Northern Territory would receive some $6,000 less than Mr Snowdon?

I think it has been implied by other speakers in this debate that this is nothing but a ploy for marginal seats. The Government is switching the cost of campaigning in those marginal seats straight on to the taxpayers, rather than having the honesty to say that those costs are something that the Australian Labor Party-or any other political party-should pick up where it is directly involved in those matters. It is a matter of very serious concern that the Government has given us a flippant and totally inadequate response on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, you will be aware that we are debating the matter of the arbitrary, unilateral and peremptory decision of the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) to increase the stamp allowance for members of the House of Representatives from $9,000 to in excess of $30,000. The first question which rests uncomfortably in my mind is what has brought on this decision at this time in this arbitrary fashion. Of course, the answer is to be found in the polls. This decision has been stimulated by the panic of this Government-this tired, directionless, failing Government-which is clinging to the last vestige of hope for re-election. Searching around in a state of panic, the Government has drawn the conclusion that it has to develop a closer communication with the public. It has decided that to do that it will significantly increase the stamp allowance for members of the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason the increase is limited to the House of Representatives is that the Government has a majority of a score. The advantage for the Government is that more constituents will receive mail from Labor members of parliament than from Liberal members of parliament. It is designed as a direct marketing program, no doubt compatible with the Government's newly found knowledge it has acquired from its computer in regard to demography and other information regarding electorates. Labour House of Representatives members will be able to make direct contact with members of the electorate in quite specific and carefully calculated ways so as to persuade constituents to vote for the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, aren't you going to persuade them to vote for the Liberal Party? That is called democracy.

—Senator Collins tells us that giving a financial advantage to one part of the democratic process is an advantage. That is akin to Gareth Evans providing $2.1m for the Yes case in a referendum and saying that is democracy because everybody gets to have a vote.
—I knew I could stir you up, Noel.
—You haven't stirred me up, Senator Collins.
—People have, in fact, voted us into the majority.

—Senator Cook informs me, quite properly, that at the last election the Government was voted into office. The truth of the matter is that that is retrospective. Prospectively, the Government is in very real trouble. The polls are telling the Government that, as at today, it cannot win the next election, so what does it do? Government members resort to putting their snouts in the taxpayers' tough to recover the advantage that is presently to be found with the Opposition, and that is to be found through this grubby method of the Minister providing this gratuitous allowance.

SPEECH.PARA: One might ask the rhetorical question: Why has the same benefit not been given to the Senate? I am not advocating this position; it is a rhetorical question. The answer is to be found in the same numbers. The truth is that in the House of Representatives the Government has a majority of about a dozen-for the moment. In the Senate it is represented, at various levels of competence and capacity, by but 32 senators. Out of a total number of 76, we find that there are 34 members of the Opposition, three Independents and seven Democrats. If the Senate were to have the same allocation, the majority of people receiving mail as a result would be people who do not vote for the Labor Party. The majority of people would be receiving information from senators who would not be putting forward the Labor Party's position. That is the cold, cruel truth of the Labor Party's ambitions in this respect.

We are told by the Hon. Stewart West, the Minister for Administrative Services, that it is the Government's view that members of the House of Representatives, `who traditionally are in much closer relationship with their constituents, should have an increased capacity to communicate directly with them'. We have a Minister of the Crown telling the Parliament that there is some special intrinsic relationship between the voters and members of the House of Representatives that does not exist between-senators and their electors. One imagines that there is some archaic view locked away somewhere in the mind of the Minister that senators are in some way appointed by State governments-as if we are not responsible to the electorate, as if we do not respond to them, as if we are not elected by them, as if we do not represent them, as if we are not accountable to them. That demonstrates the distance this Government is removed from an understanding of how the democratic process operates. I will give the Senate an old example, which will not be relevant at the next election. Try telling Senator Vallentine that at the last election she was elected in spite of the fact that she was not to have any special relationship with her constituency. Try telling the Australian Democrats that they were elected in spite of having a benign relationship with their constituents. Try telling me that. I was elected in 1980 with a majority of just over 100 votes-the finest majority of any senator ever elected to this chamber. I was told by my colleagues in the party room that they had marginal seats and that I had a safe seat. Perhaps that is the general mentality of the House of Representatives.

I can tell the Senate that any senator who is not sensitive to the aspirations, the wishes, the desires and the views of his constituents is not doing his job. Yet clearly that is the view of the Government as if in some obscure, peculiar way senators are isolated from the main stream of public opinion, isolated from the views of their constituents. Every election we notice more and more that special, singular, specific and expensive campaigns are run by all the parties, particularly for the Senate. If communities were not responsive to their senators, would they waste the money? Of course they would not. Putting the political and pragmatic reality aside, I find it the height of absurdity and impertinence that a Minister of the Crown can put to the Senate in a statement that a special relationship exists between the constituents of the members of the House of Representatives that does not prevail in the Senate. It clearly shows an abysmal understanding of the Westminster system and the relationship that the senators have with their constituents.

We are told that it is the view that the members of the House of Representatives should have an increased capacity to communicate directly with their constituents. Nobody is talking about the capacity of members of the public to communicate with their members; it is all about the members having the capacity to communicate with their constituents. Nobody is talking about the cost of 41c for little old Betty Balger to write to her member, or the cost of a telephone call, or the increasing cost of transport to see her member. No-one seems particularly concerned about that. We are primarily concerned with the $3.185m needed for the members of the House of Representatives to communicate with their electorate. This is an absurd proposition.

I have not heard one member of the Senate stand up with conviction or feeling and say that this proposition is put to us in an altruistic way. All of the Government senators sit there with a sly, smug look on their faces, knowing that it was a slippery threat introduced by this Government to enhance its prospects at the next election. At the end of the day I have to say that they will be found wanting and that they will fail. I find it remarkable that the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, was able to sit here for the period he did, totally insensitive to the cost of this item when he, in the most impertinent and improper way, had the audacity to write to the President of the Senate as the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing and say that he was lopping $1.65m from the budget for the Department of the Senate without giving a reasonable or fair explanation except to say that it was the responsibility of the Government to raise revenue and the right of the Government to determine expenditure. He ignored the fact, of course, that it is the Parliament that raises the revenue. It is the Parliament that spends it, not the Executive Government and, least of all, Senator Walsh. Senator Walsh is telling us that the Department of the Senate can be trimmed by another $1.65m. If that means inadequate staff for select committees or standing committees seeking to inquire into legislation proposed by this Government, so be it. In other words, Senator Walsh is telling the Senate that he cares not whether the Senate is able to fulfil its functions at the same time as he is approving the expenditure of nearly $4m so that members of the House of Representatives can contact their constituents. It is rank hypocrisy.

I conclude by saying that I find it horrific that this Government has previously sought, through the appropriate and proper channels, to persuade the Tribunal that there is merit in the argument that is now manifesting itself through this edict. The Government has been to the umpire and put the arguments. It has sought to persuade the Tribunal that there is justification for this item but it has had its case rejected. It is horrific that it then says, `We don't like the umpire's decision. We're going to go ahead with the game plan anyway'. It is a cynical and, in my view, a very sick proposition by a government which in retrospect will be seen as rotten to the core in terms of its desperate endeavours to cling to offers at a time when it should be ignominiously dumped.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the 120 seconds left to me I want to gratify the desire of Senator Crichton-Browne by saying that I profoundly object to members of the House of Representatives being treated disproportionately to members of the Senate. I also say to Senator Crichton-Browne that I do not begrudge the additional postage allowance for members of the House of Representatives to communicate with their constituents, because if they do not use the postage allowance it will be returned to the exchequer; so it is not lost if they do not spend it on postage. However, it is not just by the fiat of the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) that members are treated disproportionately.

SPEECH.PARA: I advise the Senate that at the last round of the Remuneration Tribunal hearings I made what I thought was a very persuasive application for certain members of this Parliament to be provided with four-wheel drive vehicles. I am referring to a very limited number who service wild and woolly electorates-the last frontiers-and there are a number of us around. As Senator Grant Tambling said tonight quite correctly, in the case of the Northern Territory senators we behave and operate, in terms of constituents, precisely as members of the House of Representatives do. In the case of Senator Tambling, he is the only conservative Federal member of Parliament and is likely to remain so for a considerable period I might add. Therefore, the load on him is quite great. I put my submission-and all the reasons were based on my experience in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly where such vehicles were provided to us-of the dangerous nature of relying on vehicles from hire-car companies which turn out not to have spare tyres, that have 50,000 hard kilometres on the clock, that have no radios. To break down 400 kilometres across Arnhem Land without a radio with nothing in either direction is a dangerous position to be in. The need to have one's own vehicle and to service it is, I thought, a very persuasive submission.

I was telephoned afterwards by a certain person who said, `The Tribunal was very impressed by your arguments about the four-wheel drive vehicle and was entirely persuaded by it. You can expect some good news in the mail'. I put up the written submission. I supported it by oral evidence to the Remuneration Tribunal and Warren Snowdon got the vehicle. That is wrong. The difficulty for me is that since he got the vehicle I have borrowed it on two occasions to go into Arnhem Land, but I and other members of the Senate, such as Senator Tambling, should have our own vehicles.
