TALK.START.PARA: —On Friday 18 August 1989 Donald Kevin Moore died of a heart attack aged 52. Honourable senators will have been on the receiving end of letters and information circulars from Mr Moore. He was in fact the driving force behind the PACT Foundation, the Publicly Accountable Classroom Teaching Foundation. There is no doubt that he was a man committed to championing the pursuit of excellence in education.

SPEECH.PARA: Donald Moore was born in Leonora in Western Australia on 10 July 1937. Before coming to Canberra in the late 1960s he gained a degree in economics from the University of Western Australia. He also had a Bachelor of Theology degree. After a short career in the Public Service he obtained his Diploma of Education and taught at both the Telopea Park and Kambah high schools before retiring from full-time teaching in 1978 due to ill health. Don will be best remembered as the founder and driving force behind the PACT Foundation whose objectives are to promote accountable classroom teaching, a renewed awareness of the fundamental importance of literacy and numeracy and the restoration of objectivity and credibility to secondary school certificates. Don's championship of the pursuit of excellence through a disciplined approach to learning attracted wide attention in the local and national press. The seminars he promoted on vital educational issues were supported by notable educators and academics. He in turn was guest speaker at many educational forums. He was editor of the PACT Journal which has a wide and varied readership throughout Australia.

Don was a committed Christian, a man of great virtue and an active exponent of the principles of social justice. For many years he was the Pearce parish coordinator for the refugee resettlement scheme and was prominently involved in caring for the Vietnam student residents of Caritas House. It was indeed a fitting tribute to him that so many of Caritas House ex-residents attended his funeral. He was a member of the Knights of the Southern Cross and the St Vincent de Paul Society. Don is survived by his wife Judith and three young children-Jessica, Ivan and Bernadine-to all of whom is extended deep sympathy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak tonight on a matter of great concern to many residents of the Hastings Shire on the mid-New South Wales coast. I have to make it clear at the outset that I am not absolutely opposed to coastal development if it is properly planned and inflicts a minimum of damage on the environment and the local community. However, we do have the horrible precedent of the overdeveloped Gold Coast and we are all becoming aware that our coastal environment is a rapidly dwindling but valuable national resource.

SPEECH.PARA: The revelations of the Independent Commission Against Corruption inquiry are not reassuring on the actual process of development application decisions. Vested interests, personal friendships and some suspicious financial transactions all seem to have taken precedence over considerations of financial damage and the best interests of local residents. I should emphasise that members and associates of both the present New South Wales Government and the previous Government have been involved in decisions apparently biased toward sectional interests. An example is the Dunbogan Canal Estate near Laurieton. The proposal canal development has been a long-running saga that dates right back to 1973 and has always attracted a high level of community opposition. The development is on highly sensitive wetlands less than one metre above sea level. It is flood prone land and is bordered by the ocean, the Camden Haven River and sewage treatment works. Quite likely, it would sink beneath its own weight even before the greenhouse effect took its toll on coastal areas.

In 1982, the council concerned, the Hastings Municipal Council, adopted a flood plain management policy for the area in question. In conjunction with the New South Wales Department of Environment and Planning and the New South Wales Department of Public Works, extensive research was carried out and the area was classified as Rural Floodway 1 (A1). In 1983 the Hastings Municipal Council, along with the New South Wales Department of Environment and Planning, initiated the Hastings coastal development strategy and residential release program. One of the findings of this strategy plan was:
Government policy is based on the view that urban development is generally undesirable on any flood prone land if there are alternative flood free sites available.

I understand that other land was available for development. Despite the above decision, in 1986 the Hastings Municipal Council again moved to rezone the land for canal development. After much community outrage, the Council decided on 6 April 1987 to hold a public hearing into the canal development. Commissioner John Woodward, the Chairman of the Office of Commissioners of Inquiry, conducted the public hearing over three days during June 1987 at Laurieton. As far as I am aware, out of the numerous submissions received by Commissioner Woodward only three supported the development. Not surprisingly, one was from the developer, Matt Toussard of Jimneva Properties. The others were from Alderman Daphne Johnston, and Jim O'Brien, Secretary of the Port Macquarie Council of Trade Unions.

Jim O'Brien is a rather colourful character with alleged connections to the National Civic Council. He has a habit of favouring right-wing unions over militant left-wing unions on building sites, a trait no doubt warmly appreciated by developers in the Port Macquarie area. Given the number of complaints from unions affiliated to the Port Macquarie Council of Trade Unions about O'Brien's methods of operating, one may wonder whether O'Brien's submission reflected the views of all the affiliates.

In commenting on Alderman Daphne Johnston's submission supporting the development, the business paper to the Community Development Committee meeting of the Hastings Municipal Council dated 6 April 1987 stated that:

Because of the contentious nature of the proposal, it is considered a commissioner of inquiry should be appointed . . . This appears to be the only method to satisfy all the persons making submissions that an independent consideration will be made.

It would appear from this document that the Council had an open mind about the rezoning proposal and was prepared to accept the umpire's decision. Nevertheless, at least Alderman Johnston had already made up her mind in support of the development.

In his findings, Commissioner Woodward recommended that the rezoning of land at Dunbogan for canal development not proceed. Some of the main points with which Commissioner Woodward supported his findings were, firstly, that sufficient flood free land was available already in the area for development; secondly, a flood plain management plan should be in place before consideration was given to one-off rezonings; thirdly, the servicing amenities-that is, the sewerage and water connections-had not been adequately addressed by council staff; fourthly, the environmental study and other evidence before the public hearing did not address the potential cumulative impacts of developments on the Camden Haven River; fifthly, the lands concerned were in close proximity to the sewerage treatment works; and sixthly, the proposed development would represent a visual intrusion on the scenic views from North Brother Mountain.

Despite the findings of Commissioner Woodward, the Hastings Municipal Council, in a move that I believe is unprecedented in New South Wales, proceeded with the development. The mayor, Alderman Bob Woodlands, sought to discredit the findings of Commissioner Woodward before the Council had met to discuss them. On 1 December 1987, he stated on regional television:
I believe that he-
that is, Commissioner Woodward-

was given quite a degree of misinformation. There has been a lot of information that he should have considered that he didn't consider and I would also make the comment that maybe the Commissioner's mind was made up before he even started the inquiry.

This statement by the mayor was made two weeks before the council even met to discuss the Commissioner's inquiry. Two weeks later on Monday, 14 December, 1987, the Council met and, despite Commissioner Woodward's findings, voted to rezone the land for canal development. The following day Mayor Woodlands apologised to Commissioner Woodward on the ECN8 regional evening news.

The details of the submission made by the Hastings Municipal Council to the New South Wales Department of Environment and Planning on the canal development have never been released by either the Council or the Department. It was on the basis of this submission that the New South Wales Minister concerned, Liberal Party member of parliament David Hay, agreed to the rezoning. Despite repeated attempts by the local Camden Haven Protection Society to obtain the document, the Council has hidden behind section 68 of the planning Act, which states that it is not required to release the information. Mind you, the Act does not prevent the Council from releasing the information either.

The decision to withhold the information is a purely political one. Alderman Peter King, a former National Party member of the Legislative Assembly, has stated in the local press that to release the information would be `commercial dynamite'. That was reported in the Port Macquarie News of 27 July 1988. According to Alderman King, `the Council had consistently supported the proposed development'. That being the case, the public hearing by Commissioner Woodward was nothing more than a cynical public relations exercise to con the people of Port Macquarie. Alderman King is not the only member of the Hastings Municipal Council with National Party connections. Mayor Bob Woodlands and Daphne Johnston are also members. Pharmacist John Barrett and Woodlands both threw their hats into the ring for National Party preselection for the State seat of Oxley. Both lost to Bruce Jeffery, who currently holds the seat for the Nationals. The preselection was marred by allegations of branch stacking and vote rigging.

In relation to the Council's submission to the Department of Environment and Planning for the rezoning of Dunbogan, it is interesting to note that the Council did not forward the submission until May 1988, six months after voting to proceed with the rezoning. Why did it take so long? As honourable senators are no doubt aware, a significant event took place on the New South Wales political scene during that six months. Labor lost government and the Liberals and Nationals took over. Did the Council deliberately put the submission on hold, hoping for a change of government and a more sympathetic hearing? Was the Council told by its friends in the National Party that approval for rezoning would be granted if it won the election? What was contained in the Council's submission to the Department of Environment and Planning that convinced the Minister, David Hay, to find in favour of the rezoning despite the recommendations of Commissioner Woodward? If the evidence is so overwhelming, why has the Council not released the document?

Further evidence of the National Party's attitude to environmental issues in the Port Macquarie area can be gained from an incident at a National Party fund-raiser held late last year. The following events were related to me by the owner of the Local Leader newspaper, Neil Johnston: Alderman Daphne Johnston asked Deputy Premier Wal Murray about environmental groups getting legal aid. At that time the Camden Haven Protection Society had applied for legal aid for a case before the Land and Environment Court. Its opponents were the Hastings Municipal Council and the New South Wales Department of Environment and Planning. Mr Murray stated that he had first heard about the Camden Haven Protection Society's application for legal aid that morning from Mayor Bob Woodlands. Mr Murray went on to say that the Protection Society ought not to have been granted legal aid in order to challenge the Council and that he would look into the matter to see whether he could stop it. Fortunately, he was unsuccessful in his intervention. Interestingly, the secretary of the local branch of the National Party asked Neil Johnston to publish a retraction in the newspaper. As a result of the publication of that story, the local newspaper lost its advertising from the Council and from the services club at Laurieton.

Another interesting case involving the Hastings Municipal Council is the proposed bridge over the Hastings River at Settlement Point, Port Macquarie. Like the Dunbogan canal estate, the bridge proposal is surrounded by controversy. The Council, along with some of its supporters in the local media, has claimed that the bridge project is based purely on the need to replace the present ferry service. The Council intends to outlay some $20m of public funds to replace the ferry service, which costs less than $150,000 per annum to run. Currently, there are 120 people living on the north shore of the Hastings River, which means that the bridge proposal works out at a cost of $166,666.66 per person-hardly the sort of cost efficiency that would please Premier Greiner.

While the Council has repeatedly denied that the true intention of the bridge project is to open up major land holdings for urban development, it stated in a 1986 environmental impact statement that one of the objectives of the bridge proposal was `to remove one constraint to possible future urban and tourist development of the area north of the Hastings River'. According to the Council's 1984 report, the need for the bridge arose from, among other things, `pressure from land owners on the northern side of the Hastings River to permit further development of the area'. As I understand it, there are only four major landowners in that area. According to the report, this land development would accommodate a total population of 20,000 people-15,000 at North Hibbard and 5,000 on the north shore. It was suggested in the report that a bridge across the river would create an `unprecedented boom in the area'. The report even suggested that it would be desirable to review the proposed extensions to the Limeburners Creek nature reserve because `they will have an extremely limiting effect on the future development of Port Macquarie'. It would seem clear that, despite the Council's denials, its plan is to rezone land on the north shore currently zoned for inclusion in the Limeburners Creek nature reserve to urban and tourist development.

In July 1987, R. B. Smyth, Director of the Department of Environment and Planning, examined the Council's environmental impact statement on the bridge and found that there were `serious shortcomings in the EIS which reflected upon the acceptability of the proposal'. In his report, Mr Smyth made 51 direct references over 28 pages to severe inadequacies in the environmental impact statement prepared by the Council. Some of the terms used by Smyth were `inadequate', `unconvincing', `misleading' and `unreliable'. Despite the scathing nature of the assessment, the Council's Chief Engineer offered the Council this advice in a report on 14 December 1987:
A further option would be to wait until after the next State Election in anticipation of a new State Government adopting a more liberal approach to conservation issues.
For anyone who had any doubts about where the National Party stood on the issue, Mr Murray said in an election speech at Port Macquarie on 1 March 1988:
We will bridge the Hastings River and the work will be completed in our first term of office.

Mr Murray went on to say that he was not concerned at the `greenie' opposition to the move and dismissed this as a myth. Clearly, the Council and the National Party intend to open up the north shore of the Hastings River for development and have no intention of preserving the land earmarked for the Limeburners Creek nature reserve.

There is a close association between Alderman Peter King, a National Party member, and Mr Roger Dulhunty, who has extensive land holdings on the north shore of the Hastings River. Alderman King is a principal of the firm King and Campbell Pty Ltd, which is engaged in surveying, engineering and consultancy on land development in the Hastings area. One of his clients is Mr Dulhunty. Not surprisingly, both are outspoken supporters of the north shore development and the Hastings bridge. While King has in the past declared pecuniary interests in respect of development applications lodged by Dulhunty companies, Alderman King moved and voted in support of a motion at an ordinary Council meeting on 3 April 1989 to grant consent to the filling of wetlands on the Settlement Point peninsula for the proposed bridge. It is not unreasonable to suppose that, should the bridge and the land rezoning go ahead, Alderman King would stand to make money carrying out surveying and consultancy work for Mr Dulhunty on his north shore holdings.

I am also concerned that undue political pressure may have been placed on the Department of Environment and Planning to withdraw or otherwise reassess aspects of the Department's previous director's report. What leads me to consider this possibility is a recent statement by Mayor Bob Woodlands that he had been able personally to `resolve' differences between the Council and the Department of Environment and Planning. Given the scathing attack on the Council in the July 1987 report from the Department of Environment and Planning. I wonder whether Mayor Woodlands used his National Party connections to persuade the new Minister, David Hay, to change the Department's position.

While collecting information for this debate tonight, I heard a rumour that the Port Macquarie News has promised to `crucify' me if I reveal the facts and the sequence of events that I have just described. I hope that this message has been garbled in transmission. If not, I look forward to my martyrdom. Whether I am around or not, I still say: let the tumbrils of ICAC roll south.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My remarks this evening are directed to address and question some of the comments made by Senator Jenkins over recent months. Unlike Senator Jenkins's practices I have in fact informed her that I will be making these comments and have given her the opportunity to be present in the chamber when I make them. This is in stark contrast to the lack of courtesy that she extended to my colleagues Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator Panizza when she made extensive and far-reaching accusations about them in the last sitting week. I am confident that both Senators Crichton-Browne and Panizza do not need me to come in here and defend them. However, there are some important questions and principles that need to be articulated in virtual condemnation of the wild rampage that Senator Jenkins has gone on.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, Senator Jenkins in her adjournment speech on 17 August referred to the subject of child migrants and in doing so said:

Mrs Pearce reiterated to me today that she and other members of the society had previously approached Labor and Liberal members of parliament in Western Australia but these members were not willing to give them support.

Mistake No. 1. As is so often the case with Senator Jenkins, she is barking up the wrong tree. She has no foundation whatsoever to the comments that she cares to make and has scant regard for whether there is any basis of fact associated with those remarks. After a very careful examination of correspondence files and files dealing with telephone inquiries, I wish to state here quite categorically that I have never received an approach from Mrs Pearce of the Child Migrant Friendship Society of Western Australia and that Senator Jenkins is just clearly playing politics in her vicious attempt to push her own rickety barrow down the road to her inevitable defeat, and it cannot happen soon enough. If this is the type of conduct that we can expect from Senator Jenkins from here on until the next election, heaven help us all.

It actually fascinates me how Senator Jenkins would have any idea whatsoever as to who does or who does not write to me or who does or does not telephone me in my office, both here and in Perth, and yet she has got the gumption to come into the Senate and simply try to score cheap political points without any foundation whatsoever to ingratiate herself with some group in Western Australia. Why would she dare to do that when she would not have a clue what goes on in her own office, let alone what goes on in our offices? But it did not stop her making the accusations.

Senator Jenkins went on to accuse my colleague Senator Panizza of various wrong doings, which I might add not only has he refuted strongly here in the Senate but he has also taken appropriate actions should they ever be repeated outside of parliamentary privilege, which of course Senator Jenkins has not been brave enough to do. But Senator Jenkins has also sought to incriminate other Western Australian senators by saying that one or all of us used child labour on family properties. I challenge Senator Jenkins on this occasion to try to be honest and tell the Senate to whom she was referring as her words are directly quoted from Hansard:
He is not the only Western Australian senator on whose family property they work.

Now who was that, Senator Jenkins? Is she game to say who it was or is she going to hide yet again? Senator Jenkins did not refer to a former Western Australian senator; she just referred to Western Australian senators. She was not vague about the accusation at all but it will be interesting to see whether she has the courage of her convictions to stand up in this place and tell the Senate who it is she is accusing, because it is certainly not I. Senators Chaney, Durack and Crichton-Browne, like me, all have family properties but the clear distinction is that they are all suburban home.

Those of us familiar with the people in the Senate can quickly judge for ourselves the absurdity and unfairness of this scurrilous generalisation implicitly accusing unnamed senators of not only employing child migrants but, by extension, of contributing to their neglect and alleged ill-treatment. This holier than thou attitude that Senator Jenkins spruiks off about as if she, and only she, has a mortgage on decency, propriety and honesty, could not be further from the truth. That was clearly demonstrated Friday week ago when the same Senator Jenkins actually came into the Senate and admitted that she had tried to commit what is effectively known as a cardinal sin in the Senate, and that is to try to change Hansard. Her attempt to do that, and it has been clarified--

TALK.START.PARA: —She did change it, or attempted to?

—Senator Watson has in fact interjected to ask whether she did change it or attempted to. She actually attempted to but Hansard would not allow her to do so. Senator Jenkins's memory, as we all know, is very selective at most times but it would do her well to recall only a few short months ago that there was actually a censure motion moved and carried against a Minister in this place for doing the same thing.

SPEECH.PARA: One could not really even excuse Senator Jenkins on this count of being naive. All she was attempting to do was to change the record that is etched in stone for ever more because she knew that she had not told the truth about Senator Panizza and she had subsequently been caught out. Senator Jenkins also went on to say many other rash, foolish and rather irrational things that same evening. But another which she mentioned which I in fact found quite amusing was that she, Senator Jenkins, was actually accusing the coalition party senators of filling voids because they lacked principles and policies. If this is not the case of the pot calling the kettle black, what is? Come to Western Australia, Mr President, and you will know all about it.

I can cite the case of a recent delegation that came to Western Australia and was supposed to be briefed by Senator Jenkins on behalf of the Australian Democrats. The members of that delegation left in utter amazement to repeat to other people who they met in further meetings during the course of the week in Western Australia that she could not answer most of their questions. Secondly, she could not provide them with party platforms and policies. Thirdly she had to have her husband, who works for her as her speech writer, according to the West Australian article of 16 August 1989, answer most of their questions in her presence. Even though the Democrats might claim to have policies, one needs to question whether they are worth the paper they are printed on. It is well known to the electorate that their policies are built a bit like a winding road, which in their case simply fits to the camber of the electorate at any given time. They are not based on the responsibility of winning government, because that will never be achieved, thank heavens for Australia. They are simply based on winning a vote at any cost. I think the sad thing is that here is a person who condemns others for not having policies, who cannot enunciate her party's own policies, that is, if they have any.

While it is certainly not my role nor desire to advise Senator Jenkins, it is timely, considering her very personal attacks on many colleagues in her attempt for survival, to suggest that Senator Jenkins in fact familiarise herself with material prior to attempting to slander others in this place. While I am not prepared simply to say that Senator Jenkins in this instance did not know better, because she should know better, it was quite evident to me, like on so many other occasions, that this has been prepared for her and she is simply the mouthpiece of her speech writer.

Therefore, Mr President, I reiterate my challenge to Senator Jenkins that she come into the Senate and she not only apologise to those whom she has maligned but she also apologise for her attempt to ingratiate herself with an organisation by condemning me and others for something of which I know I am not guilty. It is actually Senator Jenkins who must now bear the responsibility for making the question of the child migrants a political play thing. What else can she expect when she uses cases of genuine individual unhappiness to make unsubstantiated allegations against colleagues? I think it is very sad that she has used that organisation because I do not think anyone in this place would deny the fact that there has been quite genuine individual unhappiness among many people, but it is a shame that Senator Jenkins sought to make it such a play thing and sought to malign so many others.

Bear in mind, Mr President, as I said before, that Senator Jenkins did not even refer to former Western Australian senators, quite apart from the fact that this would have been equally unfair to most recent former senators from the Liberal Party whom I have known. It rings distinctly hollow for Senator Jenkins to expect us to believe here denials that her irresponsible and unsubstantiated slurs do not constitute using this issue as an electoral bandwagon and that she has not sensationalised a matter that may constitute tragedy for individuals, but does not create a class of villains. I hope that, if Senator Jenkins has the courage to apologise, she will also give a commitment to the Senate and to the electorate of Western Australia that she will cease spreading untruths about other people in an attempt to extend her cheap political exposure.

We have been given every reason to question the sincerity of someone who, at best, is content to make irresponsible statements without checking the facts and, at worst, has sought to create a false impression that coalition senators bear some vague responsibility for actions taken 30 or 40 years ago. I might add that 30 or 40 years ago I did not even live in Western Australia. Thirty years ago I was eight; 40 years ago, therefore, I was not even born. Simple arithmetic cannot even save Senator Jenkins in this instance. It is very sad that Senator Jenkins has put across a very tragic issue in such an uncaring manner. I strongly resent and deny implications that I refused to help constituents on this question. Senator Jenkins needs to learn some very elementary facts about courtesy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise the matter of Tasmanian listings for World Heritage. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Graham Richardson, has stated that he expects these listings to be finalised this week because `he has other things to do'. Does the honourable senator believe that by magic he can suddenly complete the arrangements for Tasmania's latest nominations for extending the World Heritage area by next week? By setting such an early and arbitrary deadline, he is causing dire consequences for Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned that the Minister is causing the State Government to rush the nomination for these listings. That must not be allowed to happen. The decisions will have enormous economic and social consequences for the future of our State. Senator Richardson should allow adequate time for proper consideration and for correct decisions to be made. The areas to be listed have not even been publicly released. An aura of secrecy surrounds the entire affair, despite the State Labor Government's promise of open government. Neither Mr Field nor the independent candidates in Tasmania are saying what the boundaries are to be. Neither side is prepared to say even where they differ on World Heritage issues-and they do differ. According to the Hobart Mercury of today's date, there are growing tensions over the unresolved World Heritage nominations between the Greens and the Field Government. We now find that Senator Richardson wants a decision from a government which cannot make up its mind and which has not yet published the areas to be nominated. Tasmanians need to know what areas are involved and what mineral, forestry and hydro resources they contain. These new boundaries are to be finalised by tomorrow and then handed on to Canberra next week so that they can reach the World Heritage Committee in Paris by 15 September.

Once these areas go on to the World Heritage listing they will be taken out of the State Government's hands and put into the Federal Government's hands. As Geoff Howe of the Tasmanian High Country Trial Riders Association stated:
They talk about selling Queensland to the Japanese, but we are just giving these areas away.

It is disgraceful. Large areas of Tasmania may be locked up without parliamentary approval and without a mandate from the Tasmanian people. Mr Field made no mention of further World Heritage listings during the election campaign in Tasmania. His plans were formed only afterwards as part of his deal with the Green independents, so we have no idea of the resources that these areas contain. Mr Max Buchanan, the Chairman of the Launceston Chamber of Commerce, states:
It is sheer madness to give away large tracts of Tasmania without knowing their true economic value to the State.

By the end of this week up to 20 per cent of Tasmania will be already locked up or nominated for World Heritage listing. Senator Richardson should delay requiring the nominations until thorough studies have been made and the land users consulted. There could not possibly be adequate assessment of the impact on resource industries or public recreation. Any mistakes will not be able to be put right, as control would have been handed over to the Federal Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —We did have the Helsham inquiry into that area, you know.

—I will come to Senator Cook because some of his observations may prove to be a little astray in relation to mining areas in the State, but perhaps that should wait a little while. The Federal Government's own Bureau of Mineral Resources has also made a plea for a comprehensive study of mineral potential to be made before any new areas are to be locked up anyway.

SPEECH.PARA: An area of grave concern is the probably listing of the central plateau. This area is being considered by the Labor-Green accord as a matter of priority. Included in this area are large sections of land which are presently used for agricultural and rural purposes. The area extends from South Mole Creek west to the Mersey River, north to Mayberry Road, and south to the Western Tiers. I have had representations from quite a large number of constituents whose rural properties are in this area. They are concerned that there has been no consultation with them about their properties. There are unanswered issues and questions concerning how, for example, their properties could be transferred and how the owners could be compensated. If the central plateau is to be put on Senator Richardson's list without prior consultation with the owners, what sort of society do we live in? Can a person's property just be snatched away without parliamentary approval, without parliamentary debate? The central plateau cannot be considered in the same light as the Franklin River because not all of it is a wilderness, if the definition of the World Heritage Committee is taken. Its definition of a wilderness area is:

A large tract of entirely natural country . . . (that) allows(s) natural evolution to continue with little disturbance from modern humanity. Major biological processes can be maintained. Rare and endangered species are safeguarded by their remoteness from destructive activities.

I remind the Senate that the central plateau is a multi-use area and should be kept that way. The Aborigines used it as part of their hunting grounds and often put fires through it. The area already has a horse riding code of practice which the High Country Trail Riders Association abides by. The Association works for the preservation of horse trails in Tasmania and encourages riders and others to protect and conserve native flora and fauna.

If Senator Richardson wishes to continue to insist upon receiving the World Heritage list by early next week it will cause great economic and social hardship for Tasmanians individually and as a whole. For example, a large part of the area is made up of productive rural land. Some of the farmers involved own thousands of acres. If they decided to sell their land and break it into parcels of about 50 acres for the hippies, what would that do to World Heritage prospects? Would they be allowed to change the land use? Would they be restricted in the way they conduct their agricultural pursuits? The Tasmanian Ministers are not prepared to answer these questions. The Greens are not prepared to talk about these issues. Rather, in secrecy, they want to rush the nominations through Senator Richardson to the World Heritage Committee. The whole issue has been shrouded in a cloud of secrecy and haste. More time must be granted in order that all areas can be properly assessed and the individuals involved can be correctly contacted and, if necessary, compensated.

I mentioned earlier the necessity of there being an assessment of the economic potential of the area. I was concerned about the impact of this accord some time ago. In fact I raised it by way of question on notice with Senator Cook because of implications of mining for the future of our State. I was very grateful for the senator's response, which I will quote. He said:

It is not appropriate for me to speculate on what effect, if any the accord will have on the mining industry. With the exception of a number of specific areas identified in the accord such as Denison's spires, Hart's Mountains National Park, Little Fisher Valley, and the boundaries of any additional areas for gazettal as national park or nomination for World Heritage list are not defined and are matters which have yet to be considered by the Tasmanian Government.

Well, that Government still has not considered them, and yet they are to be pushed in haste without parliamentary approval, through Senator Richardson, and they involve areas which include large areas of productive rural land. The good senator then goes on:

It is certainly true that as the currently producing mines are depleted the mining industry will increasingly depend on new mineral discoveries to remain viable. It is evident from discussions I have had with the Premier, Mr Field, that he is well aware of this and I would have expected in addressing this issue the Tasmanian Government will strike an appropriate balance between conservation of Tasmania's unique natural heritage and the definition and development of its undoubted mineral resource potential.

So here we have a potential listing going ahead without an identification of the development of an undoubted resource potential. I ask you, Minister, what role you are now playing in relation to ensuring that there is some assessment of the mineral potential, that there is some assessment of the agricultural land which could well be covered by this World Heritage Commission. What rights can Tasmanian landowners rely on in the future if this World Heritage listing goes ahead involving substantial areas, particularly in the Mole Creek area?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope not to take too much of the Senate's time tonight but, because of events, the main subjects today seem to have been the downgrading of the Australian credit rating and the disastrous pilots dispute. But a matter that has not received very much exposure today, although I am sure it will in the near future, and which is something of very great concern to me and, I think, to all Australians, is the latest episode in the continuing and concerted all-out attack on Australia's pharmacists by this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: We all know that the stated aim of the Government was to reduce the pharmaceutical benefits scheme by something like $300m, but what has happened over the last year or so has been nothing short of all-out war against the pharmacists. We all know that the pharmacists are our primary health care providers, and that but for them the Medicare system would be much more expensive to run, because the pharmacists provide that primary health care that turns a lot of people away from doctors. People can get the sort of assistance they want from pharmacists.

Over the last 18 months, the history trail of what has been happening to pharmacists is well worth noting. We would all remember the Government's efforts to transfer their payments system onto a computer based system, and as a result of that, the delays that occurred in payments. That in itself had quite a significant financial effect on pharmacists. On top of that we saw the removal from the scheme of widely used drugs and their replacement by generic brands, which not only caused the pharmacists to lose money or to have reduced profit margins, but also caused a lot of inconvenience to the public. Then on top of that we had the doubling of the maximum quantity of many prescribed items, which also had the effect of reducing pharmacists' incomes. It has been a totally frustrating exercise for the pharmacists. We have seen the public itself being inconvenienced, particularly pensioners and old people who have had drugs changed at the whim of the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett). We have had drugs coming off the list and going back on the list, and I do not know where it will all end.

The fact is that since January 1988 the Federal Government has slashed pharmacy income from pharmaceutical benefits scheme dispensing by some 12 per cent in real terms. There can be no argument about that. Over the past five years the cost of pharmacy goods has increased by 101.5 per cent and the labour costs have increased by 87 per cent. The pharmacists also contend that Government meddling, which has reduced their wholesale margins, has resulted in the surcharge of 5.2 per cent on all pharmaceutical benefits sold to community pharmacists. As I said earlier, the doubling of maximum quantities of many of the commonly prescribed items is another piece of interference introduced outside the pharmaceutical benefits pricing tribunal which itself reduced pharmacists' profits by quite considerable amounts.

The pharmacists themselves have attempted to increase their productivity and in fact they have achieved productivity gains of something like 5 per cent for the last 20 years. This industry, or a group of professional people, has achieved productivity gains. All they have received from the Government for their efforts is continual harassment and attempts to reduce their profit margins. At the pharmacists' own initiative they put in place this computer system, replacing the old failed Pharmpay system developed by the Department. In fact, the Department actually received a productivity award for adopting this initiative, which in itself was quite incredible.

The latest development, if it goes ahead-when you take note of some of the inflammatory statements made by Mr Staples today I can understand why the pharmacists are so distressed-is that over 1,000 pharmacies could shut down.

TALK.START.PARA: —And in the country areas first of all.

—All around Australia, and the proposal is to slash dispensing fees by something like 23 per cent. That cuts $1.05 from every prescription fee and abolishes the 25 per cent mark-up on the wholesale price of drugs. I am sure a lot of Government backbenchers are concerned about this. I have heard comments from Tony Lamb and another former pharmacist, Jim Snow. They have hopefully tried to convince the Government that the provocative actions it is taking should not go ahead, because the pharmacists, unlike the airline pilots, have for the moment anyway, ruled out a national strike. If ever anyone had a reason to strike, the pharmacists have because of the continual harassment, loss of profit and reduction in profit margins that this Government is forcing upon them. The likelihood is that 1,000 pharmacies will be forced into closure with a consequent loss of jobs particularly among females. To be told by Mr Staples that the Pharmacy Guild must bear much of the blame for the pharmacists' plight really is the sort of statement you would expect to hear from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).

SPEECH.PARA: I could quote some of the figures from my own small State of Tasmania which would show the effect in quite a few country pharmacies there. There are 153 community pharmacies in Tasmania and if this recommendation of the Remuneration Tribunal goes ahead, one in three-or approximately 50 of those pharmacies-will be forced to close. That will mean the loss of 250 jobs for females alone working in the pharmacies. At the moment an average Tasmanian pharmacy would write about 100 scripts per day. The loss of $1 per prescription will mean a loss of $500 a week or $25,000 a year for the average pharmacist. I do not believe any businessman or worker would accept that cut in salary when everybody else is looking for increases.

It was interesting to note that the Government submitted to the Tribunal that a pharmacist's notional salary should be $15 an hour. This is less than half the equivalent hourly rate for the middle range government salaried pharmacist. The Government also claimed that pharmacies dispensing less than 30,000 prescriptions per year are inefficient. If one looks at that more closely, one will find that a pharmacy dispensing 30,000 scripts a year, open for 50 hours a week, would dispense something like 11 scripts an hour, or one every five minutes. What more does the Government want? For a great number of our Tasmanian pharmacies the 12 per cent reduction has already meant a loss in income of something like $40,000. Surely, on top of this, it is unreasonable to expect them to absorb another $25,000 cut in profits.

The sad thing about all this is that at our local university in Tasmania we have 75 students who are currently studying for their Bachelor of Pharmacy degrees. It is critical that, over the next 12 months, they receive work experience, because that is part of their course. They have to have that practical experience before they can obtain their degrees. If these pharmacies are forced to close it will make it a lot more difficult for those students to get practical experience. If they are to gain that, they may be forced to head for the mainland, like a lot of our unfortunate young people are being forced to do by government action. The closure of these pharmacies will just about deny them any chance they will ever have of qualifying to be pharmacists in their own State.

The Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal's case, the pharmacists state, is based on a database study that is completely unacceptable to them and has been shown to have significant statistical and methodological flaws. For instance, the figures that were used in this database study are out of date; the survey results represent less than one per cent of the pharmacies in Australia; and the key costings, such as wages, were based on unrealistic figures. We will hear a lot more about this over the next week or so.

TALK.START.PARA: —It wouldn't hurt if you read the report in total.

—I believe that some of Senator Colston's colleagues are most concerned about this also. With all the efforts being made to direct-mail and to get the Government into election mode, I think this Government can ill afford to have the pharmacists of Australia in a position to cause a backlash against it. They have every reason to. For instance, the secretary of the Retail Pharmacy Employees Association has said that the Tribunal has been aided and abetted by the Federal Government. The Victorian branch, for instance, has stated that it is likely to lose up to 2,000 jobs in the State of Victoria and 400 pharmacies will be forced to close. That is something which the Government will certainly be taking notice of over the next week or two.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have sat in this Senate chamber for some two years now and have heard all sorts of insults, both personal and otherwise, coming from the coalition side of the chamber. I am told and, indeed, one of its members said only the other day that this is part of the cut and thrust of politics. What distressed me tonight and when Senator Panizza made his speech the other week was that the real attack was upon the ex-child migrants-people who have suffered dreadfully. I hesitate at this stage to bring forward more evidence to refute some of the things that are said because I really do not think it will do their cause any good at all to continue along that particular path. I certainly will put some documentation in the way of Senator Knowles so that perhaps she will have a little more understanding of the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Knowles did, indeed, warn me that she would be addressing some remarks in my direction this evening-and I certainly acknowledge that courtesy-unlike Senator Panizza, who did not do so the other week. However, if Senator Knowles and Senator Panizza care to look at Hansard for the following day, they will see that I actually stated then that I would be addressing some remarks that particular evening in response. I do not intend to respond to the personal insults and onslaught that have been made, but I would like to address one or two points. Some of the child migrants--

TALK.START.PARA: —Thanks for letting me know again; you have done it again.
—I remained in the chamber. I stood up, and I thought it would have been quite obvious.
—You didn't tell me you were going to do it, did you? No.

—Mr President, through you, may I say that I had no idea what Senator Knowles was going to say, so I feel her remark is unjust. As far as the child migrants are concerned, it is on record that both the official group, which has formed itself into the Child Migrant Friendship Society, and other people who have chosen not to join the Society have approached other members of parliament.
—Name them. Who?
—Who?

—In fact, they did not give me the names and I did not ask for them, but it is on record and I will produce the record, if that is felt to be appropriate. I think it is inappropriate for a senator in this place to threaten to put million dollar writs on constituents-on a senator, maybe, but on a constituent it is really out of place. Senator Panizza has agreed to meet the group of child migrants face to face. I appreciate that.
—I have done no such thing.

—When I spoke with Senator Panizza outside the chamber after his last remarks, he agreed to meet the child migrants face to face. If he is still interested, I will certainly arrange that meeting. I have some documents here which I could read from, but I see no point in prolonging what could develop into a slanging match, so I do not propose to do that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want very briefly to bring this episode to a close, if I can.
—Amen!

—It is a serious matter. The position was very well summed up this evening by Senator Knowles. What I wish to point out to Senator Jenkins is that after she endeavoured to change Hansard, and was not able to do so, it remains exactly as it was on 17 August 1989 at page 359. I will read that part again. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: It certainly would have been well know to Senator Panizza at the time, as boys from Bindoon worked on the Panizza family property. He is not the only Western Australian senator on whose family property they worked . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Who are the other ones?
—We do not know. Senator Knowles asks tonight, quite politely, who the other senator was. It has to be a present senator because she did not say former senator. Then Senator Jenkins went on:

SPEECH.PARA: but I chose not to allude to that because I had no reason to address any personal remarks. But she said her hand was forced.

The point I bring to your notice, Mr President, is that that Hansard remains as it is. It remains a total slander upon me and my family. I do not mind a certain amount of slander because I am proud to answer it, but some of my family are not around to answer it-the ones who have worked and developed our property from virgin bush since 1929. It has been in our family all along. I grieve for those people who are not around to defend themselves. In times to come people will read this Hansard and form the opinion-and I cannot see why they should not form the opinion-that certain members of my family had child migrant slave labour on the property. So I ask Senator Jenkins, if she has any decency and for the sake of the deceased members of my family, to withdraw the imputations that she has made.

TALK.START.PARA: —And name the other Western Australian senator.
—And name the other Western Australian senator whose property--
—Was it Walsh?

—I do not care even if it was Senator Walsh. I think he is entitled to know if an imputation was made about him. Even Senator Cook is entitled to know. No matter who it is, I think they are entitled to know who they are so they can defend themselves.
—Senator Cook?
—Yes, even Senator Cook could be in that one. But, Mr President, I wish to leave that point there.

SPEECH.PARA: If I may just continue a little further, I was not going to say any more on this matter-in fact this afternoon I told the Secretary of the Catholic Migration Centre of Western Australia that I had said my last words on it-but considering what Senator Jenkins has said tonight--

TALK.START.PARA: —The lack of what she said.

—Yes, certainly the lack of what she has said. She did not have the courage to withdraw the imputations about this other senator from Western Australia who had child migrant slave labour on his place and then went on to further back up the argument that she has taken on in the last few weeks. Senator Jenkins is quite entitled to put whatever arguments she has on behalf of child migrants, but by the same token I have all the rights on earth to put up any opposing views.
—Who has threatened the million dollar suit?

—That is right; I certainly have not been told who has threatened the million dollar writ. I do not know where Senator Jenkins got that from but I would like to know who threatened that. As Senator Knowles pointed out, I certainly did make certain arrangements in case this accusation was made outside of Parliament. But I do not have a habit of putting figures on any of those sort of things; I just leave it to my legal advisers and have them advise me. I would still like Senator Jenkins to answer that one.

SPEECH.PARA: I would certainly like to try to balance up some of the arguments that have been put here. I have a letter here that the sender requested me to read into the Hansard. I had decided this afternoon not to do that, in deference to the discussion I had with the Secretary of the Catholic Migration Centre of Western Australia but, Mr President, if you will allow me a few minutes I will read it into the Hansard. It is written by a fellow I do not always agree with, whose name is Brian G. Tennant, a social and law reform campaigner of Western Australia. I do not agree with everything he says, but I will just read out what he had to say on 20 August 1989. The letter, headed `Allegations of mis-treatment and or child abuse must be put in perspective', states:

My objective is not to discredit any of your correspondents allegations of child abuse in many of the orphanages but to suggest some of the alleged abuses are open to interpretation, such as slave labour and child abuse, and to give a balanced view.
At the age of one I was declared a State ward and spent the next 15 years in three orphanages: St Joseph's Orphanage, Castledare Boy's Home and Clontarf Boys Town.

During my experiences at Clontarf Boy's Town I was required to work Saturdays, after school and during the holidays either in the stock yard or in the kitchen. It was hard work. Looking back my interpretation of such work was simply a contribution to ones up-keep. I was also given the strap (referred to as corporal punishment) mainly in school for not doing my homework and for obtaining low marks. I don't believe this helped my schooling at all-but in those days corporal punishment was the norm in orphanages, colleges and public schools. Educational authorities in recent years have realized that this practise was not helping and decided that such punishment be outlawed and quite rightfully so.
It must be understood, child abuse is not restricted to orphanages for example, recently a teacher in a public school was convicted of abusing some fifty children.

In September 1988, over 250 former child migrants and their families from the Christian Brothers Agricultural School Tardun, gathered in Geraldton to celebrate fifty years that have apparently brought more migrant joy than misery.

At Castledare in February 1989 several hundred ex-pupils from Clontarf, Castledare, Bindoon and Tardun, gathered with their families to pay tribute to two former teachers in recognition of 50 years of `unpaid service' in the Order of the Christian Brothers for the underprivileged children.
I feel indebted to both the good sisters and the brothers for doing the best they could with such limited resources.
Yours faithfully,
Brian G. Tennant. J.P.

Mr President, I read those comments into the Hansard to try to give a balanced view of what went on 40 or 50 years ago. I believe that if these things happened then they should have been brought out, just like the war crimes. I think it is slightly late to worry about what happened. If there is any way that the Government of Western Australia, the Catholic migration organisation or the Federal Government-I have written to Senator Bolkus requesting help on behalf of the child migrants of Western Australia-can help the poor unfortunates that did not make the best of their chances in Australia, then I am all for it and I am working in that way. But please let us have a balanced argument. Let us not have any more arguments after 40 or 50 years about what was supposed to have gone on.

Mr President, I intend to wind up my remarks and I certainly would like Senator Jenkins to consider what I asked her to do this evening. If she has any decency at all she will withdraw her comments in respect of the people she named-the senators other than me and also the ones that are not around today to defend themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, earlier this evening when I was performing chair duty a motion presented by my colleague Senator Foreman was declared to be a formal motion. It was therefore put without debate and passed on the voices without dissent. The motion was that the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure have leave to meet during the sittings of the Senate on Friday, 1 September 1989 for the purpose of hearing evidence in public session.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, had I not been in the chair I would not have objected to the motion being regarded as formal but I would have voted against it. My negative vote would not have made any difference to the passage of the motion and would have been directed not against my colleague but against the concept of public hearings of committees being held while the Senate is sitting. I have a strong conviction that when the Senate is sitting senators should attend the Senate or be in close proximity to the chamber so that they may attend when required. They cannot do this if they are attending public hearings. I mention this matter only to make it clear why there has until now been no evidence of my opposition to the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, there are certainly a lot of people on our side of the chamber who felt exactly the same way as Senator Colston. It was put to us though that it was necessary, that there was no alternative, that arrangements had been put in place and that the House of Representatives was not sitting. But, certainly, the honourable senator was not alone in feeling that way.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to speak just briefly, at the end of what has been a long adjournment debate, on a matter that was raised by Senator Harradine at the beginning of the debate, and that is the untimely passing of Donald Kevin Moore at the age only 52 years, which occurred on 18 August 1989. I shall not go over the matters that Senator Harradine has already placed on the record. I can say that Donald Moore was a man who came to my office frequently. He made certain that I, as with others, was well informed of the views that he had on education matters and other matters relating to refugee resettlement and the like. He was assiduous in pursuing the issues that the Publicly Accountable Classroom Teaching Foundation, known as PACT, believed in. He will be sadly missed by very many in this community and, of course, particularly by his wife and three children-Jessica, Ivan and Bernadine. I wish to associate myself with the comments made by Senator Harradine.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
